subject: Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-06 09:22:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

We're backporting the first part, so may as well backport the second part.
    
Looks like a scarey change, but it's actually straightforward.

Part 2 of 3 related swift backend fixes"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-06 14:30:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ewan Mellor actually rewrote this particular piece of code to be simpler and a bit more performant. I would prefer to backport his work instead (or on top of this patch?):

https://review.openstack.org/#change,2728"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-06 14:36:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd actually be more inclined to drop all the patches related to this stuff. If it's needed this much work since Diablo, it sounds like it was pretty much a non-feature in Diablo and fixing it fully would be more like backporting a whole new feature to Diablo."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-06 14:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No, it's not so dramatic :) Really, the existing code (and this patch) evolved the way it did because of an unfortunate series of discoveries about the Webob library -- or more specifically, how the Webob library determines the size of the request body.

At one point, we figured out that Swift did not accept objects larger than 5GB without using this "object manifest upload" method. However, at that time, we were still allowing the Glance client to upload chunked-transfer-encoded BLOBs without specifying the Content-Length header (as it is NOT required to be set for chunked-transfer encoded requests). In addition, we found out that if we attempted to make the Webob.Request.body seekable, that webob would ready the entire request body into memory, which caused some major OOM bugs for us with Windows images. Not good.

Unfortunately, what this meant was that there was no way for the Swift storage driver to tell if a request was going to exceed the 5GB limit and thus need to write segments of data to Swift and then an object manifest file. And so, we wrote code that, when seeing an image size of 0 (if no Content-Length was specified), we created a temporary disk buffer and wrote a chunk of the incoming image to disk and then supplied that seekable disk-based file descriptor to the Swift client's put_object() method, calculating the image's checksum along the way as we wrote the segments to the disk buffer.

This particular patch addressed a bug in that disk-buffer code that was incorrectly setting the image_size in the registry database to 0 if the image_size passed to the Swift driver was 0 (unknown).

However, when Ewan went to fix a bug that was introduced a few patches back, he came up with a simple and innovative way of getting rid of the disk buffer entirely. His solution removes the prior assumption that images <5G must be written to Swift using a single put_object() call and he removed the need for a disk buffer by adding a simple call to delete 0-sized chunks (which end up being created if the image_size passed to the Swift driver is 0 (unknown))

Long explanation, but that's the story of why this code looked the way it did and why I'm happier with Ewan's patch to replace this bit of code :)

Cheers,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-11 06:43:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Ok, I'm going to abandon this for now and see how Ewan's version settles down on master."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-11 06:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Waiting for this area to settle down on master'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-06 08:54:18.000000000', 'message': 'Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without a
known image_size will fail to be segmented and hence fail to be added
to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each
  chunk read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be
  used for the registry.

Test Changes:

- Fixed bug in fake_put_object which was highlighted by Jay when
  reviewing this changeset.
  The put of the manifest object needed to be moved inside the
  check for previous existence of a key.

- Added test_add_large_object_zero_size to
  glance.tests.unit.test_swift_store:TestStore.

  This unit test demonstrates the bug and will test for regressions. It
  mirrors test_add_large_object but specifies an image_size of 0 to
  excercise the new code path.

(cherry picked from commit 98b1ef337ee63f239829b44aec4d05cea99f98ad)

Change-Id: Ic8b78be5dce2281c80372ed446499f6d0bc07f40
'}]
commit_message:
Secondary iteration of fix for bug 891738

A problem exists that images larger than large_object_size without a
known image_size will fail to be segmented and hence fail to be added
to swift.

This patch alters the chunking process slightly:

- Instead of reading min(large_object_chunk_size, bytes_left) from the
  stream, simply read large_object_chunk_size until we reach EOL(None).
  This works even when there is less than large_object_chunk_size bytes
  amount available.

- The image_size can be determined from the combined length of each
  chunk read. If we are passed an unknown image_size this value can be
  used for the registry.

Test Changes:

- Fixed bug in fake_put_object which was highlighted by Jay when
  reviewing this changeset.
  The put of the manifest object needed to be moved inside the
  check for previous existence of a key.

- Added test_add_large_object_zero_size to
  glance.tests.unit.test_swift_store:TestStore.

  This unit test demonstrates the bug and will test for regressions. It
  mirrors test_add_large_object but specifies an image_size of 0 to
  excercise the new code path.

(cherry picked from commit 98b1ef337ee63f239829b44aec4d05cea99f98ad)

Change-Id: Ic8b78be5dce2281c80372ed446499f6d0bc07f40

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-03 02:31:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add renaming functions to the floating ip dns api.

Modify the dns driver definition for rename_entry().

The previous definition of this function was wrong; it required
us to rename an entry as determined by address, but address
cannot uniquely identify an entry; we need a name.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I766af01299b7b28ad8d9f6c072a8f3e049bd286b
'}, {'created': '2012-01-10 19:37:11.000000000', 'message': "Add a modify function to the floating ip dns api.

Removed the dns driver function rename_entry().  Since 'name'
is the unique identifier for an entry, trying to rename things
causes various confusions.  Better to leave the user to
delete and recreate.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I766af01299b7b28ad8d9f6c072a8f3e049bd286b

commit_message:
Add a modify function to the floating ip dns api.

Removed the dns driver function rename_entry().  Since 'name'
is the unique identifier for an entry, trying to rename things
causes various confusions.  Better to leave the user to
delete and recreate.

For blueprint public-and-private-dns.

Change-Id: I766af01299b7b28ad8d9f6c072a8f3e049bd286b

While this definitely works, it's got a problem of leaving the user with no help text if javascript is disabled.

To that end, if you reworked this so it used the original form rendering layout, but hid the help text with javascript and then pulled the title from the contents of that span tag we'd get the best of both worlds.

commit_message:
Create a Tempest conf from a Devstack env

Adds a new script in tempest/tools/conf_from_devstack
that constructs a Tempest configuration file based on
the values in a devstack directory and its localrc
file.

Change-Id: I44626b0e5a10aaae22f03176cf21b6835e9f2500

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-06 18:50:34.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #894683: nova.service does not handle attribute specific exceptions and client hangs

As Sateesh points out nova.service.Service.__getattr__ throws an AttributeError exception when the upcall method is not available.

However nova.rpc should catch all exceptions. This does not happen in this specific case because the following statement was outside the try-catch-all:

node_func = getattr(self.proxy, str(method))

Change-Id: I437c88783bca037e4054078d2687ef41c8fc2b83
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #894683: nova.service does not handle attribute specific exceptions and client hangs

As Sateesh points out nova.service.Service.__getattr__ throws an AttributeError exception when the upcall method is not available.

However nova.rpc should catch all exceptions. This does not happen in this specific case because the following statement was outside the try-catch-all:

node_func = getattr(self.proxy, str(method))

Change-Id: I437c88783bca037e4054078d2687ef41c8fc2b83

subject: libvirt: implements boot from ISO images
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 1805, 'name': 'Michaël Van de Borne', 'email': 'michael.vandeborne@cetic.be', 'username': 'mikemowgli'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-15 18:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Nice fix.  I wonder if we should be attaching an empty root drive to the instance in addition to the iso?  It seems like it would be useful to boot from a cdrom, do some kind of installation onto a root drive and snapshot it.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-16 08:54:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This does not sound like a good idea, because you would bypass what the user request. I don't think its the job of this code to do something that that the user did not request via the API.

Typically, you can use the API to attach a persistent volume or an ephemeral one to install your system (tested & validated) with block device mapping."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-16 09:53:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I add that if your flavor add an local storage disk, you can install it from the ISO (which is probably weird since its ephemeral but he).

So actually what you want is done by the flavor I guess. :)'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-16 09:57:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-16 09:58:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Patchset 2 fixes disk_bus.

We only set it for the root device, because there's no need to use IDE everywhere, it's only needed for the CDROM drive."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-16 19:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So I chatted a bit with Ewan about this.  the plans for the xenapi driver are as I suggested: to attach the cdrom and boot off of it, but to still have a blank disk of the size specified in the flavor.

FYI, the flavor definitions are being expanded according to this blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/disk-configuration-parity

We will have two fields for local disk.  The first value will be for the size of the root drive, and the second value for the size of the ephemeral storage.  If you specify a regular image, it will be resized to the value of the local disk. Boot from iso should attach the iso and set it to be the boot device, but still create an empty disk of the size specified in the flavor.

This seems like the most useful implementation of boot from iso and lines up with what is being done in the xenapi driver.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-16 19:56:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(currently, since we don't have a field in the database for size, we should probably use the --minimum_root_size flag for the size of the empty root disk which defaults to 10G)"}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 02:41:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-19 08:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> So I chatted a bit with Ewan about this.
> the plans for the xenapi driver are as I suggested:
> to attach the cdrom and boot off of it, but to still
> have a blank disk of the size specified in the flavor.

This is exactly what my code does.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:51:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

> This is exactly what my code does.

Not exactly, unless I'm reading the code incorrectly

If you boot from a regular image you get:
base image resized to 10G > path/to/disk > /dev/vda
ephemeral storage from the flavor (e.g. 20G) path/to/disk.local > /dev/vdb

If you boot from an iso (current code) you get:
iso > path/to/disk > /dev/hda (? not sure where it shows up in the guest)
ephemeral storage from the flavor (e.g. 20G path/to/disk.local > /dev/vda

I'm actually suggesting the following:
iso > path/to/disk.iso > /dev/hda (? not sure where it shows up in the guest)
10G blank disk > path/to/disk > /dev/vda
ephemeral storage from the flavor (e.g. 20G path/to/disk.local > /dev/vdb

After the earlier blueprint hits, the 10G above will be set from a new column in the instance_types table.  This is important because snapshotting won't be supported for ephemeral storage.

Please tell me if I'm misreading the code."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

messed up my formatting.

Pastie here is formatted correctly:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3896/'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-20 09:22:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

You understand correctly, and now I do understand you too. :)

From that I understand, the reason you want that is because snapshoting is not supported for ephemeral devices.

But by doing this I somehow have the feeling you're doing things the user did not request and break its expectation somehow. Wouldn't be more useful to add snapshoting to ephemeral disks ? Unless it's impossible for some reason.

(And FYI the CDROM is usually detected as sr0 with a Linux guest, the ephemeral local drive being vda)"}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-12-20 12:17:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I understand that the approach Ewan suggests is convenient, and probably in many cases what the user wants, but I agree with Julien that it's not actually what the user asked for.

If the root disk image the user asks for happens to be a cd-rom image, the only effect that should have is telling the hypervisor that the image in question is a cd-rom image.
Any other change in behaviour (like adding an extra disk) should preferably be explicitly requested or at the very least be governed by some other bit of meta-data (i.e. so the logic that decides whether to attach an extra disk looks more like "if root_image['attach_other_disk_as_primary']:" than "if root_image['type'] == 'cdrom'").

Explicit is better than implicit.'}, {'account_id': 1805, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I tested this patch. Works very well (at least for KVM, haven't tested for LXC or Xen). thanks Julien."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-28 18:11:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Wouldn't be more useful to add snapshoting to ephemeral disks ?

Sorry for the slow response. I was away on vacation.  The decision from the summit was to divide the instance type into two disks: one for the root drive and one for a second ephemeral disk.  The definition of the ephemeral disk is that it does not save data. Therefore snapshotting will only be supported for the first (non-ephemaral disk)

This allows deployers to create instance types with plenty of space but still keep snapshots small.  As a user if i give a command to boot of off an image that happens to be a cd-rom, I would expect to still have my hard drive attached.  For example, assume the following instance types
TYPE / ROOT / EPHEMERAL
tiny / 10G / 0G
small / 20G / 40G
LARGE / 80G / 140G

I would hope to be able to boot a tiny instance from a cd ans still have some disk to work with.

The fact that I'm booting from a CD should not change the amount of storage I have on my root drive IMO."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-29 08:47:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"As a user if i give a command to boot of off an image that happens to be a cd-rom, I would expect to still have my hard drive attached."

As a user maybe, but we are talking about internals here, not about the user interface.
Not being able to snapshot all the devices is probably not a good decision, but eh it has been made so…

But since you are the final decision-maker for this, and I don't have any other argument, please tell me if I should amend this patch with another disk added like you described (and with which size ?).'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-30 20:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I was hoping to get some feedback from soren on why he thinks differently, but in my mind the default should be:
boot from cd should still get root device and the ephemeral from the flavor, and it can be overridden with block_device_mapping

Please change it.  For now, use the minimum_root_size (10G) as the size of the root drive.  Johannes is working on adding the extra field to the flavor for root size and it can come from there once it is in.

When soren gets back from vacation, we can have a chat on irc about why he thinks the other is better and change it in a following patch if necessary.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-02 11:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> When soren gets back from vacation, we can have a chat on irc about
> why he thinks the other is better and change it in a following patch
> if necessary.

I'm not sure which part of my previous review comment wasn't clear?

We're not adding a new API call to "install an instance from an ISO". If
we were, I'd be much more comfortable having it come with different
semantics than the regular "boot an instance" call.

Having behaviour branches in the code based on image types is hideous.
At the very least, make it a secondary attribute on the image that we
can branch on instead. I.e. make it explicit through an attribute rather
than implicit in its image type that this particular image needs an
extra disk attached (presumably because it wants somewhere to install
something).

Not only is overloading image types with decisions about behaviour wrong
in and of itself, but the need for a secondary disk is orthogonal to the
image type. A "live CD", for instance, has no use for a persistent
root disk at all, and disk images are completely valid install media
(think USB sticks) that certainly should have a root disk to which they
can install.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-02 20:06:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Can we rename disk_bus to epehemeral_disk_bus or something in the template?  Having disk_bus sort of clobbers root_disk_bus, and I'd like to have the variables more descriptive.  This isn't a show-stopper though.

Also, I'd like to see tests that show the template (or at least the data passed to the template) is being generated correctly.  This is why I'm rating -1.

I like the idea of installing from ISO or the like, but I think the best way to do it would be some sort of ephemeral disk promotion / block device mapping during a reboot or similar command.  I don't think assuming that ISO = include a new root disk is the best way to approach it.  But this can/should be handled in a separate change, so not a blocker for this one."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-01-03 15:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-01-03 16:52:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-03 19:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I'm not sure which part of my previous review comment wasn't clear?
> We're not adding a new API call to "install an instance from an ISO". If we were, I'd be much more comfortable having it come with different semantics than the regular "boot an instance" call.

The regular boot an instance call takes an image and has a flavor which specifies a size for the hard drive root partition and ephemeral partition.  So perhaps the issue is that we shouldn't overload this call to allow for booting from an ISO.

> Having behaviour branches in the code based on image types is hideous. At the very least, make it a secondary attribute on the image that we can branch on instead. I.e. make it explicit through an attribute rather than implicit in its image type that this particular image needs an extra disk attached (presumably because it wants somewhere to install something).

I don't think it makes any more sense to have the ISO image type clobber the root drive with a cd.

> Not only is overloading image types with decisions about behaviour wrong in and of itself, but the need for a secondary disk is orthogonal to the image type. A "live CD", for instance, has no use for a persistent root disk at all, and disk images are completely valid install media (think USB sticks) that certainly should have a root disk to which they can install.

I agree that behavior based on the type of the image is ugly, but it is the only way to support boot from ISO without adding a new api.  The assumption of image and flavor (instance_type) is that the image is expandable to the size in the flavor.  This doesn't work for ISOs, so we either have to:
a) attach the iso image in addition to the root and ephemeral drive
or
b) replace one of the drives with the iso image.

a) is preferrable to me because I think it is much more valuable, but I can see a valid argument for b) as well.  I do know that the folks implementing this for xen selected a), so it makes sense to do it that way at least initially.

If you think b) is better or that we shouldn't overload the api call at all, and only allow a cd to be attached via a different api, maybe we should take it to the ML?'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-03 19:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

>> I'm not sure which part of my previous review comment wasn't clear?
>> We're not adding a new API call to "install an instance from an ISO".
>> If we were, I'd be much more comfortable having it come with
>> different semantics than the regular "boot an instance" call.
> The regular boot an instance call takes an image and has a flavor
> which specifies a size for the hard drive root partition and ephemeral
> partition.  So perhaps the issue is that we shouldn't overload this
> call to allow for booting from an ISO.

I honestly don't see how you can refer to it as overloading. We have a
number of different image types. When you want to boot an instance, you
tell Nova what you want it to boot. Why would booting from an ISO not be
allowed this way? Booting an ISO is a perfectly valid operation. I must
have done it literally thousands of times.

>> Having behaviour branches in the code based on image types is
>> hideous. At the very least, make it a secondary attribute on the
>> image that we can branch on instead. I.e. make it explicit through an
>> attribute rather than implicit in its image type that this particular
>> image needs an extra disk attached (presumably because it wants
>> somewhere to install something).
> I don't think it makes any more sense to have the ISO image type
> clobber the root drive with a cd.

I don't follow at all. I tell Nova to boot an image that happens to be
an ISO. I think the correct thing to do is to go ahead and do as it's
told. Nothing more, nothing less.

I might be pursuaded into skipping the disk resize step if the image
type is an ISO. It's supposed to be a read-only medium after all. This
is all starting to feel really sketchy, though.

>> Not only is overloading image types with decisions about behaviour
>> wrong in and of itself, but the need for a secondary disk is
>> orthogonal to the image type. A "live CD", for instance, has no use
>> for a persistent root disk at all, and disk images are completely
>> valid install media (think USB sticks) that certainly should have a
>> root disk to which they can install.
> I agree that behavior based on the type of the image is ugly, but it
> is the only way to support boot from ISO without adding a new api.

Wait, what? Then I don't understand the rest of the conversation we've
just had.

> The assumption of image and flavor (instance_type) is that the image
> is expandable to the size in the flavor. This doesn't work for ISOs,
> so we either have to: a) attach the iso image in addition to the root
> and ephemeral drive or b) replace one of the drives with the iso
> image.

You're not "replacing one of the drives with the iso image". You're
using the ISO image to boot from, exactly like you would use anohter
image to boot from, if that was what you were told.

> a) is preferrable to me because I think it is much more valuable,

I'm fairly sure the EC2 API allows this to work out-of-the-box with a
correct blockldevicelmapping passed in. If we're resorting to
overloading API calls and similar hacks because we're hesitant to add
something to the API we're supposed to be in control of(!!), I'm about
ready to declare complete bankruptcy on that very API.

> but I can see a valid argument for b) as well. I do know that the
> folks implementing this for xen selected a), so it makes sense to do
> it that way at least initially.  If you think b) is better or that we
> shouldn't overload the api call at all, and only allow a cd to be
> attached via a different api, maybe we should take it to the ML?

I think this discussion very much belongs on the ML.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-04 16:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Chatted with soren in irc.  We agreed that it is fine if the default behavior is to "replace" the root hard drive with the cd-rom drive in absence of other info, but there should also be metadata in the image to allow for the other  behavior if desired.

Something like:
image_meta['attach_separately'] = True/False

If attach_separately is set, the image will be attached separately from the root hd.  This requires a bit of extra logic and perhaps a flag to ensure that it can't be abused (max_separate_disk_size?), so it is fine if we add it in a subsequent patch.

Therefore I'm ok with this going in.  We need to add the subsequent patch soon though, because we're adding another disparity between the kvm and xen implementation of iso booting.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-04 19:51:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

awesome'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-10 19:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Approved

sending this in.  Hopefully it still is the same'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-10 20:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/388/ : SUCCESS

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/452/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2215/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-10 20:08:21.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
libvirt: implements boot from ISO images

This allows to boot correctly ISO images. We just set the device type in the
XML template to 'cdrom' if the image is in ISO format, and the bus type to
IDE so it has maximum compatibility.

This implements the blueprint support-kvm-boot-from-iso.

Change-Id: I4d1ea52a17f6f24e944b10020d54aaec9e86c95c
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

subject: Isolate certain images on certain hosts.
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-09 01:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems straightforward enough. Any chance to get a blueprint or bug for this, though? Just for tracking purposes...'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-09 17:56:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Have you thought about how the isolated host check will play with snapshots of isolated images? It seems like you could snap an isolated image then boot it out of isolation, which I would assume we don't want to do."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-01-09 23:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-10 05:07:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian, I think booting a snapshot outside of isolation should be okay.

Most of the time I would image the isolated VMs not being run by an actual user account but by an admin project, so users won't be able to snapshot and re-run anyway.

Even if there are public images that should be isolated, allowing them to be snapshotted and re-run would probably trigger billing and metering them as normal instances, so that would probably be okay.

In the case of things like the ssh bastion host that is up for review now, while the instance is owned by the project, a snapshot loses its utility since the bastion-specific bits (getting a public ip) are handled by a flag that specifies a specific image id, so running a snapshot of it just gives you another vanilla instance."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-10 18:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Works for me.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-10 19:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-08 20:37:00.000000000', 'message': "Isolate certain images on certain hosts.

This implements a [hosts] <=> [images] mapping in the simple scheduler
that partitions your host resources into the part that services a
particular image set, and the general cloud.  This is useful, for
example, if you want to specify a set of hosts to run utility VMs
(cloudpipe, bastion, etc) that you don't want consuming resources from
your generally available pool.

When specifying a host with --isolated_hosts flags (comma-separated
list) those hosts will only run the images specified in
--isolated_images, and will not run any other images.  The isolated
images will not run on any other hosts.

You can specify --skip_isolated_core_check to allow overcommitting of
the isolated hosts.  This allows utility vms that are not cpu bound to
avoid the resource cheks the scheduler usually performs (based off of
--max_cores).

Change-Id: Ib2db5a605cb7560a169af9ff2a6dadb649da9c1d
"}]
commit_message:
Isolate certain images on certain hosts.

This implements a [hosts] <=> [images] mapping in the simple scheduler
that partitions your host resources into the part that services a
particular image set, and the general cloud.  This is useful, for
example, if you want to specify a set of hosts to run utility VMs
(cloudpipe, bastion, etc) that you don't want consuming resources from
your generally available pool.

When specifying a host with --isolated_hosts flags (comma-separated
list) those hosts will only run the images specified in
--isolated_images, and will not run any other images.  The isolated
images will not run on any other hosts.

You can specify --skip_isolated_core_check to allow overcommitting of
the isolated hosts.  This allows utility vms that are not cpu bound to
avoid the resource cheks the scheduler usually performs (based off of
--max_cores).

Change-Id: Ib2db5a605cb7560a169af9ff2a6dadb649da9c1d

commit_message:
Split notification strategies out into modules.

1) Add a Strategy class that defines the interface that a particular
notification strategy must implement.

2) Split each notification strategy out into its own module.

This is in part just an attempt at some "code cleanup", but it also has
an advantage that it is easier to make a particular notification
strategy be optional and not impose a hard dependency on all of glance.

Change-Id: Iab658637c56e764e2b3ec54c67e752db0cbfbe5c

for custom filtering.

commit_message:
Use megabytes instead of bytes.

The defaults for swift are supposed to be interpreted as megabytes, not
bytes. Without this change, default glance talking to swift will fsync
every 200 bytes during an image upload.

Change-Id: I3a6a22df6615ba45af0ef2874a8f612f638bb484

commit_message:
Adds support for floating ip pools

 * Implements blueprint multiple-floating-ip-ranges
 * Adds pool and interface fields to floating ip tables
 * Adds extension to get a list of available pools
 * Optionally allows a pool to be specified when allocating
 * Changes nova-manage command to allow pool and interface
 * Ip binding uses the interface from table instead of flag
 * Adds default pool flag to use when pool is not specified
 * updates test to work with new fields
 * adds tests for extension

Change-Id: Ieb4cbbf07b211697d08178b1cf2252caf75049a2

[{'created': '2012-01-04 02:01:06.000000000', 'message': "PEP8 python-novaclient cleanup

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly

Change-Id: Ia5571e58e2662c652f0e996d8c1a1acb4531623d

Fixes bug #911552

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()

Change-Id: Ia5571e58e2662c652f0e996d8c1a1acb4531623d

commit_message:
PEP8 python-novaclient cleanup

Fixes bug #911552

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly

Change-Id: Ia5571e58e2662c652f0e996d8c1a1acb4531623d

In test_002 you removed the user_data script in favor of scp? Any reason for this change. Testing that user data works is a good thing right? I think passing that script in via user data so that we can run subsequent metadata tests is probably a good thing right?

Also, It looks like test_005 is failing in SmokeStack now. Apparently the implementation matches the test for that case.

Can you have a look?'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-01-06 12:20:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

and
test_004_can_access_metadata_over_public_ip

Since they will always return true.

test_004_can_access_metadata_over_public_ip will return true
because:
            result = self.conn.disassociate_address(self.data['public_ip'])

test_005_validate_metadata will return true

as the line below:

But I chose to follow what it is done int test_0004 and test_006

Fix bad test cases in smoketest.

Fixes bug #912650.

smoketests/test_netadmin.py:SecurityGroupTests:
    'test_004_can_access_metadata_over_public_ip'
    'test_005_validate_metadata'
    'test_999_tearDown'

commit_message:
Fixes incorrect URI scheme for s3 backend

Fixes bug #912094.

URI scheme for s3 backend should be 's3+https', not 'swift+https'.

Use s3.amazonaws.com instead of s3service.com to follow RFC2606.

Indent reason for BadStoreUri exception in s3.py.

Comments added for the following option in etc/glance-api.conf
    's3_store_host'

Change-Id: Id456b287d82fe61711f0d738e61ccb599f0b5684

commit_message:
Add comments for swift options in glance-api.conf.

Fixes bug #771465.

Comments added for the following two options in
glance-api.conf
    'swift_store_auth_address'
    'swift_store_user'

Indent reason for BadStoreUri exception in swift.py.

Change-Id: Ife28e01a4e2344cf1e5a179752d244b68e45d348

I still would prefer even in the non-cached case that the 2 rpc calls were 1 rpc call.  :-/  It would at least help 'list' in the non-cached case.   Also, how far off is the cache from being ready after this merges?  I still don't like the fact that this will destroy performance in the meantime, even if I feel it's a good idea to split huge merges up.   It feels like we're doing this in the wrong order. '}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-12-15 16:48:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

>I still would prefer even in the non-cached case that the 2 rpc calls were 1 rpc call. :-/ It would at least help 'list' in the non-cached case.

We have a plan for this. When making an RPC call we will add an eager=True flag to the params. That will cause the network managers to eager-load the model pieces downstream from the called point prior to returning the portion of the network model that is being requested.

> Also, how far off is the cache from being ready after this merges? I still don't like the fact that this will destroy performance in the meantime, even if I feel it's a good idea to split huge merges up.

Trey reports the cache merge should be proposed tomorrow. So we can wait on this until that goes in, as soon as I get a ChangeId for it I'll rebase off it it.

>It feels like we're doing this in the wrong order. The cache should go in first. And then we untie and use the cache.

I hear yea, unfortunately we fell into the Mythical Man Month and as the scope of the model and cache crept, maintaining these unties for the past month has gotten more and more painful. Since it takes a while for the reviews to all get done since these are radical changes, I figured we could at least get the ball rolling."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-15 16:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-16 06:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Do not submit

Jason: Ah, I see.  I'd really like to hold off then, until Trey's goes in.  In fact, I feel strongly enough about it to bump this to -2 for others reviewing.  Sorry.  Thanks for working with me a bit on this ;)   I can forgive the 2 rpc calls vs 1 as long as this merges in the correct order."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2011-12-16 15:03:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Cool beans.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-10 00:08:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

foll='}]

commit_message:
Bug 885267: Fix GET /servers during instance delete

There is a period during an instance delete when GET /servers
will fail occasionally.  The race condition is during GET /servers
between the initial get_all() and when the extended_status extension
re-retrieves individual servers via compute.api.routing_get().
We log a warning and remove the offending server from the list
as it no longer exists.

Change-Id: Id75723a21c0d6dc20f446560847e5b8522ec3262

commit_message:
Implements blueprint separate-nova-volumeapi

 * Moves openstack/v2 directory to compute and fixes tests accordingly
 * Moves some code from api/openstack/compute to shared location, for use by volume api
 * Implements basic volume functionality for types, volumes, and snapshots
 * Changes service name from osapi to osapi_compute (and adds osapi_volume)
 * Renames nova-api-os to nova-api-os-compute, adds nove-api-os-volume
 * Separate extension mechanism for compute and volume
 ** Removes flag osapi_extension and replaces with osapi_compute_extension and osapi_volume_extension
 * Updates paste config

Change-Id: I3d0f4d9f1009b68fe3b1dfa8625fc7d77220c1b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-02 01:21:25.000000000', 'message': "Bug #909533: Swift uploads through Glance using ridiculously small chunks

Remove the use of a temporary disk buffer when streaming to Swift.  This
was added on the assumption that it was not possible to stream chunks to
Swift direct from webob.Request.body_file.  That's not true -- a simple
file-like object wrapping body_file does the job perfectly.

This removes the need for swift_store_object_buffer_dir in the config file.
It is also significantly cheaper, since there is one copy fewer.

Fix the parsing of the swift_store_large_object_size and
swift_store_large_object_chunk_size options.  These are
specified in MB in the config file, but needs to be in bytes internally,
because they are compared against the image_size parameter given to add().

Update the unit tests to match.  This includes an additional check that
put_object is called the correct number of times.  The unit tests missed the
latter problem problem because there was no check that a small object is only
uploaded in one chunk, and despite the comment to the contrary there was no
check that the right number of chunks were written in the large-object case
either.  Added these in all places where store.add is called.

Change-Id: Ieb4cf68516b53bd16d2671e49e805b26118b3671
"}, {'created': '2012-01-02 01:26:30.000000000', 'message': "Bug #909533: Swift uploads through Glance using ridiculously small chunks

commit_message:
Bug #909533: Swift uploads through Glance using ridiculously small chunks

Remove the use of a temporary disk buffer when streaming to Swift.  This
was added on the assumption that it was not possible to stream chunks to
Swift direct from webob.Request.body_file.  That's not true -- a simple
file-like object wrapping body_file does the job perfectly.

This removes the need for swift_store_object_buffer_dir in the config file.
It is also significantly cheaper, since there is one copy fewer.

Fix the parsing of the swift_store_large_object_size and
swift_store_large_object_chunk_size options.  These are
specified in MB in the config file, but needs to be in bytes internally,
because they are compared against the image_size parameter given to add().

Update the unit tests to match.  This includes an additional check that
put_object is called the correct number of times.  The unit tests missed the
latter problem problem because there was no check that a small object is only
uploaded in one chunk, and despite the comment to the contrary there was no
check that the right number of chunks were written in the large-object case
either.  Added these in all places where store.add is called.

Change-Id: Ieb4cf68516b53bd16d2671e49e805b26118b3671

commit_message:
Remove doc/Makefile.

Use "python setup.py build_sphinx" instead.  There are some things that
the Makefile did that setup.py does not do, but they will be easy enough
to add later if anyone misses them.

Change-Id: I430dcc027bac207af515fb7d927500db18320ba5

commit_message:
Add Fedora clauses to the installing document.

This change resolves 2 Fedora-related todo items in installing.rst.

It also cleans up a bit:
 - fixes weird grammar
 - fixes improper list numbering
 - uses proper name for Red Hat, where space is necessary
 - replaces A/B syntax with A, B

This is my first commit and I am adding myself to Authors file
on a suggestion by Brian Waldon.

Change-Id: I398ae8150d7912e0b61375a7bdc5aab1101f34bc

commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug #912596 - image_ref_alt not found

* Adds skippers to tempest to enable skipping tests
  that don't meet certain conditions
* Adds a check in test_list_servers.ServerDetailsTest.setUpClass
  that checks if the image with ID image_ref_alt actually exists
  and if it does not, marks a specific test as skipped.

This is what the resulting test run looks like after adding
the skip:

jpipes@librebox:~/repos/tempest$ nosetests -sv tempest.tests.test_list_servers
Return the full details of a single server ... ok
Filter the detailed list of servers by flavor ... ok
Filter the detailed list of servers by image ... SKIP: Only one image found
Filter the detailed list of servers by server name ... ok
Filter the detailed list of servers by server status ... ok
Return a detailed list of all servers ... ok

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 6 tests in 108.909s

OK (SKIP=1)

Change-Id: Ia6178ca8201acc03566b785ec096eda51d0425c9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-09 16:38:56.000000000', 'message': "Show useful traceback if manage command fails

Currently, if a keystone-manage command raises an exception, the
exception object is reraised which overwrites the original traceback.

Use plain 'raise' to preserve the original stack trace. Refactor
the error handling to not use a nested try/except.

Change-Id: I86f3ad945018b32a50e7d09e354b1990d0d0ecf3
"}]
commit_message:
Show useful traceback if manage command fails

Currently, if a keystone-manage command raises an exception, the
exception object is reraised which overwrites the original traceback.

Use plain 'raise' to preserve the original stack trace. Refactor
the error handling to not use a nested try/except.

Change-Id: I86f3ad945018b32a50e7d09e354b1990d0d0ecf3

subject: Refactors utils.load_cached_file
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-05 03:50:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-05 05:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Honestly, I'm not too crazy about this patch.

On the plus side, I like use of the `with` statement to close the file; it's not absolutely necessary since the file will automatically be closed when the file-reference goes out scope, but nonetheless, it's definite style improvement.

My main objection is with changing the signature of the `load_cached_file` function to return whether the file was served from cache or reloaded. AFAICT this was done just to aid testing, which I can understand from a pragmatic POV.

Still, I think this is leaking information that shouldn't be available to the caller: conceptually the function is smart-enough to do the right thing, and the caller shouldn't ever get to know if the file was reloaded or not.

To test, I'd opt for an approach that uses stubs to assert whether the file was reloaded. I'm not sure if it's possible to stub out the open builtin, but if it's not, we should be able to do a small refactoring to get a stub point.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-05 05:59:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah, I see `open` being mocked already, that looks perfect for asserting that `open` was called...'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 06:54:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It actually is not for testing.  I needed an efficient way to know if the contents had changed for the change here:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,2766

If I am doing some intensive loading based on the data in the cache, I only want to do that loading if the data has changed. I can keep a local copy of the data and do an == every single time, but if that is a 4000 character string that quickly becomes inefficient.

I could peek into the cache_info object and store the mtime and check it vs a stored version, but that violates the opaqueness of cache_info. All i really need to know is that the data has changed so it seemed reasonable to return that information along with the data.

If you have another suggestion for how to accomplish this I'm all for it.

If you have"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-05 07:48:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Vish:

Ah, I see, yeah, that's a tricky case--hmm, can't really think of a cleaner approach at the moment.

Practicality beats purity, etc, etc, so,  I'll go ahead and remove that -1.

Going to think a bit more before moving two whole places up to a +1 though :-)."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-01-05 15:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-05 15:37:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Having thought about it some more, the only I alternative I can come up with is a callback approach.

def read_cached_file(path, cache_info, reload_func=None):
    """
        :param on_reload_func: function to be called with filedata when file is reloaded due to a change.
    """
    changed = cached_info["mtime"] != os.path.getmtime(path)
    ...
    if reload_func and changed:
        reload_func(data)


Then it can be used as:

def update_policy_brain(data):
    policy.set_brain(policy.HttpBrain.load_json(data))

data = utils.read_cached_file(_POLICY_PATH, _POLICY_CACHE,     reload_func=update_policy_brain)

I think I like this *slightly* better, but don't really have strong opinions either way.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:07:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The (result, loaded) thing is kind of hacky. I'd prefer to see a mock that checked that the load was occurring, but what evs. :)"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:13:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Rick: I like the callback approach.  Will change.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:30:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

messages:

Yeah, sorry for the huge chunk; this was pretty difficult to chop up into smaller pieces…plus, once I got going, it was hard to stop :)'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-06 17:37:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm seeing unit test failures. Not sure if it's you, or me, but worth pointing out. Minus one'ing for the moment. Let me know what's going on here.

http://paste.openstack.org/show/4129/

Otherwise, great work. This is actually a bit easier to grok than the previous implementation"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-06 17:49:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure why you'd see that failure from the unit tests.  I certainly cannot reproduce it, and smokestack agrees that the unit tests pass.  Could you re-run and see if it happens again?  (I'd also suggest making sure you rebuild .venv and blow away all *.pyc files, just in case it's some kind of left-over cruft...)"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-06 19:58:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yeah, you're right. Missed that smokestack was cool with it"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-09 16:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-09 16:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just a rebase on current master.  I ran unit tests successfully before pushing up for review.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-09 16:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-09 18:13:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (10 inline comments)

Really nice work here, Vek; love the decorator approach.

One thing that jumped out at me was a tendency towards abbreviated variable names, like `defcode` and `_bind_meth_arguments`.

I'm a bit worried that we're sacrificing some readability down the road for the  expense of a few characters now.

`default_http_code` or `_bind_method_arguments`, to me at least, would make quite a bit more sense, and be far more self-documenting if I were to run across it a year and a half later.

I realize this very much a personal style thing, but I think that there is some precedent in Nova already which tends towards a verbose/readability-over-conciseness style, so wanted to get your thoughts on that."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-09 18:47:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (10 inline comments)

Yeah, I have a tendency toward doing abbreviations, and to be honest, I've never had any trouble figuring out what they meant years later.  That may be a legacy of how I really got into programming—working on old code with lots of obscure abbreviations ('sptr' == 'server_pointer').  In any case, it doesn't cost anything to go with the more verbose style you advocate, and I'll upload a new patch shortly..."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:14:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I guess that's fine"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:20:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

commit_message:
Serialization, deserialization, and response code decorators.

Sets up decorators for linking serializers, deserializers, and response
codes directly to implementation methods, rather than using parallel
object methods.  In addition, methods are now able to return an instance
of a ResponseObject class, binding alternative serializers; this is
particularly useful for actions, as it enables the action processing
method to return different objects for different actual actions.

Change-Id: I8815590f29a935216dc766ce720ded638ebca0d0

Looks good still - but if we are going to default to creating a logfile, howzabout making a symlink to the most recent log so that the user doesn't have to fight with tab completion after stack.sh runs"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-01-03 15:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Improve log file handling:

* Elimiate subshells to produce logfiles (fixes bug 885091)
* Clean up log files older than 7 days (default)
* Append date/time to specified log file name
* Default LOGFILE='', now must set to get logging

This changes the default behaviour of stack.sh to not write a log file
unless LOGFILE is set.

Change-Id: I5d3fb65e12ccdb52fca5a41ee8f5777c046cd375

subject: Fixing bug lp:881794 -Making code changes to get rid of the default tenant concept. -Getting rid of cranky comments. -Fixed minor bugs that violates the api contract. -Migration script that supports the transition. -LDAP fixes
messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-10-24 21:50:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

can you please use a commit message that says what you did in the proper format?'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-10-24 21:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

See http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritWorkflow#Committing_Changes'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-10-24 21:54:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is the second schema change you've made - you should use migrations - not just change stuff"}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-10-24 21:55:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jesse are you on IRC cud u ping me?'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-10-26 04:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-10-26 04:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The schema changes would be handled as a separate bug.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/881796'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-10-26 15:11:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Yogi,

I hate to be a downer, but the schema changes absolutely must be in the same patch. Doing so in a separate patch means this commit will break all existing installations...

-jay"}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-10-26 15:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Thanks for the feedback Jay.This is the issue we have.We are yet to build the infrastructure to support DB versioning.We already have couple of issues that have schema changes.We want to build the infrastructure as well as accommodate these changes .This is significant chunk of work.We do understand the issues.We were under the impression that we need to get migration support we quantify this as a release.This one time we are going to tackle it this way.However once the infrastructure is build we would automatically start following your advice.The work that is here is an important piece and would allow us to progress parallely.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-10-26 15:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also schema changes are in the same patch.The migrations are not.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 08:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 15:15:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

This looks like it should be 3 discrete migrations to me.

1) Data migration to bootstrap the "Member" role
2) Data migration to assign "Member" roles to users on existing tenant_id's
3) Schema migration to drop User.tenant_id'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

All the changes are the side effect of a single change.
It did not seem ideal to clutter with too many migartion scripts
Wanted to do what other projects are doing
Check this similar change
https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/registry/db/migrate_repo/versions/003_add_disk_format.py'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-08 18:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

What happens with the second or third steps fail, then?

Upgrade and downgrade become completely useless, as the database is in a VERY inconsistent state in the middle of a complex migration.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-08 18:19:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Do not submit

XSD changes are also required to support:

1) Removing default tenant (RAX-KSADM-users.xsd)
2) Changing 'name' to 'username' (token.xsd)

This commit will also break horizon, and probably every other keystone client. The mailing list needs to be notified prior to merging."}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 19:27:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

1. RAX-KSADM-users.xsd 
The elements is this XSD are right now not used any where in the wadl.They don't have the name/id separation change as well.We need to decide whether we need to keep it any more.
Should be a bug on its own.

2. Token.xsd The user with the access as per contract has name.We have frozen the contract and we cannot change it right now.We could have a bug and fix the contract later."}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 19:29:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

This code attempts to model the code as per contract and not vice versa.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 19:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

1. The implementation of our legacy auth need to change, This is a seperate bug to track it. 
https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/887739

2. User has an attribute of username wherever it is used.However the user defined for service catalog within the token.xsd has name as attribute and not username.The code right now works as per the contract.Contract and code need to change to make this consistent.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/887740

3.Elements in RAX-KSADM-users.xsd are not used in contract.Contract need to be fixed in case there are gaps or xsd need to be removed if it is irrelavant.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/887740'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-08 20:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Based on what I see in the other projects the
migartion scripts are not singular in nature.
Wanted to do what other projects are doing Check this similar change 

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/registry/db/migrate_repo/versions/003_add_disk_format.py

Also other issues brought are not caused by this commit but exposed and need to be handled seperately.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-11-29 20:59:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

004 now collides with an existing migration"}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-11-30 04:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I shall repatch and submit.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

Blocking all merges until (unrelated) bug 900514 is resolved

https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/900514'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-06 03:31:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Unblocking'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2012-01-09 16:07:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Fixing bug lp:881794
-Making code changes to get rid of the default tenant concept.
-Getting rid of cranky comments.
-Fixed minor bugs that violates the api contract.
-Migration script that supports the transition.
-LDAP fixes

Change-Id: I45b8fd6bd2358b6ae3467ffd1729c33bbd70f2e4

commit_message:
Fixed Test Coverage Handling

- Coverage command was causing tests to
  stop after first run (OptParse was exiting
  so had to override the behaviour)
- Also added logging, error handling, and
  combining ot coverage files between runs.
- Output summary report at end of run

Change-Id: Ibec98009b16226de9a68da3be3d7b258d6d771a4

commit_message:
Front-end logging

- Added logging to Front-end components
- Replaced console logging with log info events
- Addresses some of bug 900451 (import exception
  mentioned will get logged to logger, but logger
  is not yet initialized by that time)
- blueprint keystone-logging

Change-Id: I1dce90b9876d7bc26c090d757b44f7321bc32f9d

commit_message:
Implement Role Model

- Replace logic.types.Role(s) with models.Role(s)
- Also impacts UserRoleAssociation since that is
  effectively a Role granted to a user
- Reorganized sqlalchemy.api.role file and grouped
  rolegrant separately from role calls
- Made rolegrant and role calls return models.Role(s)
- Deleted logic.types.role
- Added enhancements to models to handle class-level
  serialization hints and XML namespace
- Create AttrDict class to hold attrs and simplify
  set/getattr overrides
- Renamed test modules to lowercase (PEP8)

- Applies to:
      bp keystone-refactor-backend
      bp refactor-keystone-models

Change-Id: I33784caa75aba5bbba822dc7169259cab0b73115

Waldon: This is a fix because of the side-effect of having a synchronous API. A large instance list would destroy the API, and most likely time out. commit_message:
Bug #912858: test_authors_up_to_date does not deal with capitalized names properly

ensure we are not fooled by capitalized names, by turning emails and names into lower cases before the matching.

Change-Id: Idbb8535174c0f1451ad6fd0628f35508f0f1e466

commit_message:
Bug #894683: nova.service does not handle attribute specific exceptions and client hangs

As Sateesh points out nova.service.Service.__getattr__ throws an AttributeError exception when the upcall method is not available.

However nova.rpc should catch all exceptions. This does not happen in this specific case because the following statement was outside the try-catch-all:

node_func = getattr(self.proxy, str(method))

This changeset also fixes test_authors_up_to_date, which may fail when dealing with capitalized names present in .mailmap and Authors.

Change-Id: Ic586db9aa5b98e40ad5a0e878927f5fa736892fb

Change-Id: I394a183f303f41557a9cc75d370c628d6cb7b15c

commit_message:
xsd fixes

- use=optional applies to attributes. The way
  to have an optional element is to use minOccurs=0
  This was fixed in tenant.xsd (was failing validation)
- Updated api.xsd and endpoints.xsd (recursive references)
- Removed old, invalid entries from RAX extensions

Change-Id: I6264c3166fe6f5a93360f9c01020784feb2a69ce

Hi Stephane, after some discussion amongst the horizon core team we've decided to switch to a model of doing a proper "string freeze" at the end of the dev cycle (in this case E4) and handle all updates to the translation files at that time.

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 5, 'name': 'Ziad Sawalha', 'email': 'ziad.sawalha@rackspace.com', 'username': 'ziad-sawalha'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 112, 'name': 'Jesse Andrews', 'email': 'anotherjesse@gmail.com', 'username': 'anotherjesse'}, {'_account_id': 1063, 'name': 'Ed Leafe', 'email': 'ed@leafe.com', 'username': 'ed-leafe'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-21 17:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

having the files called manage2 seems a too literal?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 17:18:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 17:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 17:22:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

anotherjesse: intentionally literal.. the goal is to deprecate and remove 'keystone.manage' after everything is re-implemented, and subsequently promote 'manage2' to simply 'manage', all within essex."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 17:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-21 19:09:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I like:
- that existing scripts that use old ./keystone-manage won't break
- that we're not forced to support keystone-manage and leystone-manage2 indefinitely

I don't like:
- not enough documentation on the methods/classes.

Overall, good direction for the blueprint."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 20:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 20:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 20:56:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

ziad: not sure if you meant docs for developers or users, so I improved both. Command doc strings are now returned as part of the '<command> --help' response (see example session; updated link)."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-21 21:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-22 15:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2011-12-22 17:51:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

Logic looks sound; just some coding suggestions/questions.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-29 21:13:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I like the direction here. Not sure I dig the multiple ways to do a help of a command, but overall, I like the clean separation, the use of argparse, and the output buffering. I think that you might want to consider making the OutputBuffer a context manager as well, so you can do things like this:

 with buffoout.buffer_output() as ob:
    blah()
    blah()
    self.assertIn('blah', ob.read_lines())

and have the context manager enforce the stop()/clear() of the buffer. Just a thought.

[{'created': '2011-12-21 17:14:28.000000000', 'message': "Initial keystone-manage rewrite (bp keystone-manage2)

- Example usage: ./bin/keystone-manage --help
- Example usage: ./bin/keystone-manage version --help
- Commands are implemented as decorated classes
- The name of the command module *is* the name of the command
- Testing
  - Includes base testcase for testing commands, with the following coverage:
    - Unit test command classes directly
    - Unit test by passing parsed args (via argparse)
    - Use output buffer to make assertions on stdout
  - Includes tests for 'version' command
  - Includes tests for OutputBuffer
- Routing calls through bin/keystone-manage to manage2.
  - New command names use a different syntax, so none should collide.
    - Old: 'subject verb' (e.g. 'user add')
    - New: 'verb_subject' (e.g. 'add_user')
  - Implication: --help for original keystone-manage is now overridden
    by that from manage2

Change-Id: Iafd25d77df600ca70e19925936f3e997109f4d68

commit_message:
Initial keystone-manage rewrite (bp keystone-manage2)

- Example session: http://paste.openstack.org/show/3927/
- Example usage: ./bin/keystone-manage --help
- Example usage: ./bin/keystone-manage version --help
- Commands are implemented as decorated classes
- The name of the command module *is* the name of the command
- Testing
  - Includes base testcase for testing commands, with the following coverage:
    - Unit test command classes directly
    - Unit test by passing parsed args (via argparse)
    - Use output buffer to make assertions on stdout
  - Includes tests for 'version' command
  - Includes tests for OutputBuffer
- Routing calls through bin/keystone-manage to manage2.
  - New command names use a different syntax, so none should collide.
    - Old: 'subject verb' (e.g. 'user add')
    - New: 'verb_subject' (e.g. 'add_user')
  - Implication: --help for original keystone-manage is now overridden
    by that from manage2
- OutputBuffer captures stdout as a string for testing commands
  - Example usage:

      with buffout.OutputBuffer() as ob:
        print 'foobar'
        assert ob.read() == 'foobar\n'

Change-Id: Iafd25d77df600ca70e19925936f3e997109f4d68

commit_message:
Rename .glance-venv to .venv.

This simplifies a number of Jenkins jobs which currently, other
than directory names, could be the same for all OpenStack
projects.  By renaming the virtualenv directory, the redundant
Jenkins virtualenv build and copy jobs can be eliminated.

(cherry picked from commit 37fc2b00c0a8dd67221d83697609913aa78d89c7)

Change-Id: I7916783d863e5184bad8293c3aed5ba119e374a9

commit_message:
Configure swift logging.

Split logs by storage node proxy and don't fill up the
/var/log/messages.

Set proxy-server in debug.

Only one worker by proxy-server since we are usually in debugging mode.

Change-Id: If39f35b98ad821e8a62e36e4c22e723f83e01db8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-04 00:51:44.000000000', 'message': "PEP8 cleanup

Fixes bug #911531

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance() instead of comparing types directly

Change-Id: Ie1b3e18bad22a2baeb79d50928267a4cac0a55e4
"}]
commit_message:
PEP8 cleanup

Fixes bug #911531

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance() instead of comparing types directly

Change-Id: Ie1b3e18bad22a2baeb79d50928267a4cac0a55e4

commit_message:
Unified horizon and openstack-dashboard environments.

Buildout has been removed entirely, all dev installation is now
done via the single tools/install_venv.py script.

Django's manage.py script has also been updated to a newer
version/convention; this allows for less python path mangling
and makes things cleaner and more explicit. Note that, as such,
it has been moved up a directory level.

Change-Id: I62f9f06ee00568fc91e5ba7e1fd15d22ea849d1f

subject: First Implementation of Policy checking
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 693, 'name': 'Christopher MacGown', 'email': 'chris@pistoncloud.com', 'username': '0x44'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-04 00:48:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-04 00:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Notes here:

http://etherpad.openstack.org/rbac-brain'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-04 01:37:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-01-04 04:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-01-04 14:37:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

That should have been +1 with comments…'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-04 16:06:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

So I'm not quite sold yet on this patch. See my comments inline. I think you also need to add some testing of the new policies you're enforcing to prove this thing actually works."}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-04 18:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-04 19:53:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Very interesting stuff

I definitely agree with Waldon though. I'm concerned about the overhead associated with some of this implementation at this time. We're already seeing performance problems, especially considering the frequency with which we already call the other APIs."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-04 20:12:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I guess the comments show that people didn't read through the entire linked etherpad: http://etherpad.openstack.org/rbac-brain

Relevant bit:

The second commit shows how we can specify policies in a file and check them in the create instances call.  Please note that this is an example and we may need to actually move the check into the compute.manager instead of compute.api.  Ultimately all related data should be loaded in the api, rbac should be checked, and upon passing, all relevant data should be sent through the queue to the manager.  Unfortunately not all data is currently available at the api layer, so it requires extra rpc and database calls.  This is inefficient, wo we may need to put the rbac checking in compute.manager for now, and move it to api when the loading happens.

tl, dr;
Yes it is inefficient.

In response to the concern about blocks being added to all calls: I managed to do a decorator version in compute manager for all of the instance calls in an old version, but it was super hacky because we don't have the full objects upon entry to the methods.  So I think we are going to actually have to add explicit checks in various places for now."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-01-05 19:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 21:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-05 21:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

agreed that this stuff is too inefficient.  Will rework to make the checks in the manager layer.  Perhaps I will start with a simpler method as well.'}]

commit_message:
First Implementation of Policy checking

 * Second step of blueprint interim-nova-authz-service
 * Adds actions.yaml to define actions
 * Adds roles.yaml to define roles
 * Adds policy.json to define policy
 * Modifies create instance to do some checks
 * Cleans up tests

Change-Id: If6702873db3249921f931a42e889ee7d0338e4b9

commit_message:
Fix lp bug 897882

This moves the tree to having a standard setup.py.  For those who want to
build individual packages you'll need to use the setup_<package>.py files.

This allows us to support the traditional setup.py commands (i.e. sdist, etc)
that the openstack CI scripts will be using.

Change-Id: I7fe286d9973f43ae118a715276b0c089230f4f7e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-05 00:20:37.000000000', 'message': 'Remove small unneeded code from impl_kombu

If a publish fails, we reconnect to rabbit.  In this case, we try to
declare the publisher exchange... and loop around and do the same thing
again after grabbing a new class instance.  This removes the extra code.

Change-Id: I99089ccfb93bb860d5221c267f35a16c1faf3707
'}]
commit_message:
Remove small unneeded code from impl_kombu

If a publish fails, we reconnect to rabbit.  In this case, we try to
declare the publisher exchange... and loop around and do the same thing
again after grabbing a new class instance.  This removes the extra code.

Change-Id: I99089ccfb93bb860d5221c267f35a16c1faf3707

commit_message:
Update HACKING.rst.

Removes the requirement for a trailing blank line in multiline
docstrings, just before the closing '"""'.  This blank line is not
needed anymore, as the editors it was recommended for no longer
have the problem that this blank line was working around.

Change-Id: I4e532231f1d99e9f5048cbfcc791a4328fb1e8f5

commit_message:
Tell users what is about to be installed via sudo

Rather than just giving users the sudo password prompt immediately,
actually tell them what is about to be installed, so they know
whether it is reasonable to be entering their password.

Change-Id: Ic0c1de812be119384753895531a008075b13494e
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
