revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-05 19:47:57.000000000', 'message': "Cc: stable-maintainers

backport zone availability fixes from jenkins 2009 and 1986.

1986
----
Updates simple scheduler to allow strict availability_zone scheduling

This update adds strict availability_zone scheduling of new instances when
an availabity_zone option is not present in the creation call.  This patch
does not change the expected default behavior.

Previous behavior was to default the zone to None and only update the zone
in the scheduler if an availability_zone was supplied.  This incorrectly
allowed the scheduler to place new instances created without an
availability_zone onto compute nodes where the availability_zone had been
changed to something other than the default of 'nova'.

Setting default_schedule_zone to 'nova' will prevent new instance scheduling
into availability_zones other than the default 'nova' zone.  This change
defaults the zone to None but allows the user to override this with the
default_schedule_flag.

In practice, if you have 2 availability_zones (nova, megazone) you can
configure default_schedule_zone on the API node to 'nova' and any instances
created will be created into the 'nova' availability_zone if one was not
supplied.  Instances created with an availability_zone will be created as
normal into the availability_zone supplied.

2009
----
Add availabity_zone to the refresh list

The availability_zone column for a service record is not updated if the
availability_zone is changed after the record was created.  This patch
adds availability_zone to the update list in report_state if the
availability_zone stored in the database does not match the local flag

Change-Id: I8fbd68dda4a925144265663334e7b5973172e8cc

commit_message:
backport zone availability fixes from trunk

Cc: stable-maintainers

gerrit review 1986
------------------
Updates simple scheduler to allow strict availability_zone scheduling

This update adds strict availability_zone scheduling of new instances when
an availabity_zone option is not present in the creation call.  This patch
does not change the expected default behavior.

Previous behavior was to default the zone to None and only update the zone
in the scheduler if an availability_zone was supplied.  This incorrectly
allowed the scheduler to place new instances created without an
availability_zone onto compute nodes where the availability_zone had been
changed to something other than the default of 'nova'.

Setting default_schedule_zone to 'nova' will prevent new instance scheduling
into availability_zones other than the default 'nova' zone.  This change
defaults the zone to None but allows the user to override this with the
default_schedule_flag.

In practice, if you have 2 availability_zones (nova, megazone) you can
configure default_schedule_zone on the API node to 'nova' and any instances
created will be created into the 'nova' availability_zone if one was not
supplied.  Instances created with an availability_zone will be created as
normal into the availability_zone supplied.

gerrit review 2009
------------------
Add availabity_zone to the refresh list

The availability_zone column for a service record is not updated if the
availability_zone is changed after the record was created.  This patch
adds availability_zone to the update list in report_state if the
availability_zone stored in the database does not match the local flag

Change-Id: I8fbd68dda4a925144265663334e7b5973172e8cc

subject: Add Support to delete VMs in error state.
messages:
[{'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-03 01:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

While this is technically a new feature, its a feature necessitated by a change since Diablo was released..

+1 for that reason'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-03 14:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sure, why not.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-05 12:40:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Took a little bit of digging to understand Kiall's point

I10d607fd40953e334670cc39040a9a00ff6919ac was blamar's fix on master which made the instance be moved into ERROR state if spawn failed. As part of that fix he made it possible to shutdown a VM in ERROR state.

When we backported I7584b527e408c08014f1b6a8abda343f1e2aa3b8 to stable, we effectively also backported blamar's "move to ERROR if spawn fails", but didn't backport the second part.

Joe is fixing that oversight with this patch.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-05 13:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/303/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/822/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/434/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2197/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-05 13:23:17.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
avoid error and trace on dom.vcpus() in lxc

This fixes bug 903943.  If you used lxc, you'd eventually
see stack traces in nova-compute due to use of dom.vcpus().

Change-Id: I8ff4e973d33eef3df116feb237b2febc8e6a59b5

The  'collie  cluster  status'  default output  is  more  verbose  since

commit_message:
Pass '-r' option to 'collie cluster status'.

The  'collie  cluster  status'  default output  is  more  verbose  since
sheepdog 0.24.  The '-r' (raw)  option has  been added for  less verbose
output but won't be used to ensure compatibility with pre-0.24 sheepdog.

Change-Id: Ie31bdded928772250515e439016fc5c5beb00d83

subject: Specify -t rsa when calling ssh-keygen.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-04 20:44:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks like a plausible Solaris fix'}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-01-04 20:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-04 21:24:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey guys - I guess you're back-porting this to Diablo?  I think only Solaris / Illumos has this issue.

I did come across some other issues on Illumos, but I'm working through them.  So: do you really want to try to support Diablo on Illumos?  Is there another OS which doesn't default to RSA?  I think targeting Illumos for Essex instead is probably more reasonable (and I have some patches for Illumos coming "real soon now")!

That said, I'm pretty sure this patch is harmless :-)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-04 21:40:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey Justin - I figured I wouldn't penalize Solaris/Illumos by not backporting fixes only relevant to it.

If you think Diablo is irredeemably broken on Solaris/Illumos, I'm happy to drop them?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-05 12:21:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Abandoning for now based on Justin's comment"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-04 20:42:48.000000000', 'message': "Specify -t rsa when calling ssh-keygen.

Change-Id: I6f1364e6ff79a9c9a38007611b8df3af1b2dc645

commit_message:
Specify -t rsa when calling ssh-keygen.

Some operating systems (e.g. Illumos) don't default to RSA.  Probably safer to specify it anyway, even on Linux where it defaults.

Change-Id: I6f1364e6ff79a9c9a38007611b8df3af1b2dc645

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-05 00:17:01.000000000', 'message': "Remove install_requires processing.

This is based on a similar change to nova:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,2800

Loading install_requires with the contents of pip-requires
isn't getting us any real beneift and is causing issues.

a) It can conflict with installing keystone into an environment
where deps have been installed from packages (devstack)
b) It breaks the ability to use -e git urls in pip-requires
which we want to start using for python-novaclient and
python-keystoneclient
c) It causes spurious network traffic when we're trying to
test things.

At the same time, since we are not expecting anyone to install
keystone from setup.py for production, the normal benefit of the
feature is not needed.

Change-Id: I7235e1bff75a9fd1455daa684300a83c4295bd9c
"}]
commit_message:
Remove install_requires processing.

This is based on a similar change to nova:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,2800

Loading install_requires with the contents of pip-requires
isn't getting us any real beneift and is causing issues.

a) It can conflict with installing keystone into an environment
where deps have been installed from packages (devstack)
b) It breaks the ability to use -e git urls in pip-requires
which we want to start using for python-novaclient and
python-keystoneclient
c) It causes spurious network traffic when we're trying to
test things.

At the same time, since we are not expecting anyone to install
keystone from setup.py for production, the normal benefit of the
feature is not needed.

Change-Id: I7235e1bff75a9fd1455daa684300a83c4295bd9c

Hey there! Would you mind removing the 'swift+https' -> 's3+https' fix from this patch and submit another one? We also need to file a bug to track it. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-04 18:53:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Excellent work, Hu, thank you!

I do agree with Brian's comment about separating the S3-related changes from the swift ones. You can reset your local branch back to the previous commit, commit the relevant swift changes, and stash the S3 changes for a later commit, like so:

 git reset HEAD^
 git commit Authors glance/store/swift.py etc/glance-api.conf
 # Enter commit message and save/close editor
 git stash
 # The remaining changes to glance/store/s3.py will be stashed...
 git review
 # Your Swift-only changes should now be pushed up...
 git stash pop
 # Your S3 changes will now be in your working tree
 git commit -a
 # Enter commit message for S3 stuff and save/close editor
 git review
 # New changeset with S3 changes will be pushed for review
 
Note that you will need to abandon this specific changeset since a new changeset will be pushed with only the Swift changes.

Let us know if you need assistance, and welcome to the Glance contributor community! :)

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-01-05 02:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

split Swift and S3 changes'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-01-05 02:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

bug for s3 reported here:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/912094

fix for swift backend is here:
https://review.openstack.org/2826

fix for s3 backend will be done after swift fix been merged to master.'}]

commit_message:
Add comments for three options in glance-api.conf.

Fixes bug #771465.

Comments added for the following three options in etc/glance-api.conf
    'swift_store_auth_address'
    'swift_store_user'
    's3_store_host'

Fixes incorrect scheme for s3 backend, should be 's3+https', not
'swift+https'.

Use s3.amazonaws.com instead of s3service.com to follow RFC2606.

Indent reason for BadStoreUri exception in s3.py and swift.py.

Change-Id: I1d17bdbcf90e41e1db0b5be29df5e7601d4834bd

[{'created': '2012-01-04 00:41:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix help output for inverse of BoolOpt.

When a BoolOpt is used, it adds both the option and its inverse.  For
example, there is "--verbose", and "--noverbose".  Previously, the same
help text was used for both which didn't make any sense.

This patch modifies the help text used for the inverse option.  It
makes some assumptions about how the help text is originally worded, but
works for the options so far (--verbose, --debug, --use-syslog).

Change-Id: I3966fe9ec5ed6282d8a2902f06fc1487532064e0
'}, {'created': '2012-01-04 14:25:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix help output for inverse of BoolOpt.

When a BoolOpt is used, it adds both the option and its inverse.  For
example, there is "--verbose", and "--noverbose".  Previously, the same
help text was used for both which didn't make any sense.

This patch modifies the help text used for the inverse option.  It
makes some assumptions about how the help text is originally worded, but
works for the options so far (--verbose, --debug, --use-syslog).

Change-Id: I3966fe9ec5ed6282d8a2902f06fc1487532064e0
'}, {'created': '2012-01-04 15:58:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix help output for inverse of BoolOpt.

When a BoolOpt is used, it adds both the option and its inverse.  For
example, there is "--verbose", and "--noverbose".  Previously, the same
help text was used for both which didn't make any sense.

This patch modifies the help text used for the inverse option.  It now
simply says something like "The inverse of --<option>".  For example,
the help text for --noverbose says "The inverse of --verbose".

Change-Id: I3966fe9ec5ed6282d8a2902f06fc1487532064e0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix help output for inverse of BoolOpt.

When a BoolOpt is used, it adds both the option and its inverse.  For
example, there is "--verbose", and "--noverbose".  Previously, the same
help text was used for both which didn't make any sense.

This patch modifies the help text used for the inverse option.  It now
simply says something like "The inverse of --<option>".  For example,
the help text for --noverbose says "The inverse of --verbose".

Change-Id: I3966fe9ec5ed6282d8a2902f06fc1487532064e0

commit_message:
PEP8 keystone cleanup

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: Ic3dfcd81ae772fa8cccaa8c0bfa3a4e3a54ae05a

    * set mtu in ovs driver

    * Use None instead of '' for flag default

commit_message:
Set VLAN MTU size when creating the vlan interface.

When empty (the default) nova will not set any MTU parameters.  You can
specify a number as in --network_device_mtu=9000 to enable jumbo frames,
for example.

Updates:
    * change flag name
    * set mtu in ovs driver
    * empty string means don't fiddle with the interface mtu
    * Use None instead of '' for flag default

Change-Id: Ib4bccf7f96a836af18b4ea7e164b26f3c9104482

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-04 20:41:55.000000000', 'message': "Remove install_requires processing.

Loading install_requires with the contents of pip-requires
isn't getting us any real beneift and is causing issues.

a) It can conflict with installing nova into an environment
   where deps have been installed from packages (devstack)
b) It breaks the ability to use -e git urls in pip-requires
   which we want to start using for python-novaclient and
   python-keystoneclient
c) It causes spurious network traffic when we're trying to
   test things.

At the same time, since we are not expecting anyone to
install nova from setup.py for production, the normal benefit
of the feature is not needed.

Change-Id: I402f975c652dc1c2b54b0c362b8abbb6886f8844
"}]
commit_message:
Remove install_requires processing.

Loading install_requires with the contents of pip-requires
isn't getting us any real beneift and is causing issues.

a) It can conflict with installing nova into an environment
   where deps have been installed from packages (devstack)
b) It breaks the ability to use -e git urls in pip-requires
   which we want to start using for python-novaclient and
   python-keystoneclient
c) It causes spurious network traffic when we're trying to
   test things.

At the same time, since we are not expecting anyone to
install nova from setup.py for production, the normal benefit
of the feature is not needed.

Change-Id: I402f975c652dc1c2b54b0c362b8abbb6886f8844

commit_message:
Fix to correctly report memory on Linux 3.X.

If sys is compiled on a Linux 3.X system, it returns LINUX3 instead of
LINUX2 for sys.platform.upper().

Change-Id: I78dae37d4facbaf6513c0eab651b1a06b93949b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-19 03:36:04.000000000', 'message': "Support local target for Solaris, use 'safe' command-line processing

Solaris volumes were created over SSH; we could also be running the volume service locally, in which case we don't want to use SSH, but should call utils.execute instead.  Split commands appropriately.

Change-Id: I79dd0bdf527baf73a167ff210285a0ab65d0de4b
"}, {'created': '2011-12-23 07:47:01.000000000', 'message': "Support local target for Solaris, use 'safe' command-line processing

Solaris volumes were created over SSH; we could also be running the volume
service locally, in which case we don't want to use SSH, but should call
utils.execute instead.  Split commands appropriately.

Change-Id: I79dd0bdf527baf73a167ff210285a0ab65d0de4b
"}, {'created': '2011-12-26 17:39:50.000000000', 'message': "Support local target for Solaris, use 'safe' command-line processing

Solaris volumes were created over SSH; we could also be running the volume
service locally, in which case we don't want to use SSH, but should call
utils.execute instead.  Split commands appropriately.

Change-Id: I79dd0bdf527baf73a167ff210285a0ab65d0de4b
"}]
commit_message:
Support local target for Solaris, use 'safe' command-line processing

Solaris volumes were created over SSH; we could also be running the volume
service locally, in which case we don't want to use SSH, but should call
utils.execute instead.  Split commands appropriately.

Change-Id: I79dd0bdf527baf73a167ff210285a0ab65d0de4b

commit_message:
Call mkfs with the correct order of arguments

nova.virt.libvirt.utils:mkfs() takes fstype and partition arguments,
but _create_swap() calls it with the order reversed

Change-Id: Ib963425d71ce84889760f919d3b435a3d7d17eb0

subject: Add more man pages.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-04 14:41:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So I like that we can have man pages, but I'm not exactly sold on this approach. Is there a way we can automatically build these pages to match the help text? I think these will get out of sync as soon as the first change is made."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-01-04 14:46:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't feel great about it either.  Right now it just means that everyone needs to at least try to remember to update the man pages whenever options get changed.

It's certainly possible to build something that automatically generates them; it's just more work than what I did here.  I just figured this quicker start (that is at risk for getting out of date) was better than not having them at all for now."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-04 14:50:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Well, that's a reasonable thought. I'll approve this with the understanding that you file a bug in reference to automating this process :)"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-01-04 14:51:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Cool, thanks.  Yeah, I'll file a bug on it and keep it in mind as something to work on later."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-01-04 15:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For reference: https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/911805'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-04 19:55:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Thanks Russell! Nice work.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-04 20:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

output from each executable to seed a man page for the rest of the
executables, which include:

  - glance
  - glance-cache-cleaner
  - glance-cache-manage
  - glance-cache-prefetcher
  - glance-cache-pruner

commit_message:
Add more man pages.

A few man pages were already in place.  This patch uses the --help
output from each executable to seed a man page for the rest of the
executables, which include:

  - glance
  - glance-cache-cleaner
  - glance-cache-manage
  - glance-cache-prefetcher
  - glance-cache-pruner
  - glance-cache-queue-image
  - glance-control
  - glance-scrubber

Fixes bug 911291.

Change-Id: Ie0de990ff6617e7eb953f270a089c99bc340b4fe

commit_message:
Use --log-config with keystone.

Keystone does not support a log_config config file option.  It
only respects the command line argument.

Fixes bug 910436.

Change-Id: I276ad5da239d5d9b6a1dcdd1013972c7948c511b

commit_message:
Updated the swift-init manager for object-expir...

Updated the swift-init manager for object-expirer support since the
expirer doesn't not use the object-server.conf but does start with
object-.

Change-Id: If6e0e9af4c6c861fdf390370f271d9139c573ba2

subject: PEP8 type comparison cleanup
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1801, 'name': 'Duncan McGreggor', 'email': 'duncan.mcgreggor@rackspace.com', 'username': 'oubiwann'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2011-12-31 10:17:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/010_add_os_type_to_instances.py
nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/016_make_quotas_key_and_value.py
nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/030_multi_nic.py
nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py

The files above are not updated, fix is incomplete.

Checked with command:
find . -name "*.py" -exec sed -i -f pep8_equality.sed {} \;
git diff --name-only

pep8_equality.sed content:
/== True/ s/== True/is True/g
/!= True/ s/!= True/is not True/g
/== False/ s/== False/is False/g
/!= False/ s/!= False/is not False/g
/== None/ s/== None/is None/g
/!= None/ s/!= None/is not None/g'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2011-12-31 10:29:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh, I'm sorry. My bad.
I'll fix it and resend for review."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2011-12-31 11:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hengqing,

As I commented on the bug report, sqlalchemy filters won't work if you use "xxx is None".

You have to use "xxx == None" to generate the right query.

Apparently, I didn't see the last line of the pep8 and made all boolean comparsions use "is" or "is not".

I'll resent when I'm sure there are no typos.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2011-12-31 13:58:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Tried to enforce pep8 type comparsion by using the commands below, still have some difference with you.

find . -name "*.py" -not -path "./nova/db/*" -exec sed -i -f ../pep8_equality.sed {} \;

pep8_equality.sed content:
/ == True/ s/ == True//g
/!= True/ s/\([a-zA-Z_]\+\) != True/not \1/g
/== False/ s/\([a-zA-Z_]\+\) == False/not \1/g
/ != False/ s/ != False//g
/== None/ s/== None/is None/g
/!= None/ s/!= None/is not None/g'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2011-12-31 14:38:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, I haven't sent the second patch set yet.

And you have to know that some of the comments have "is True" to explain their code logic.

Right now I'm going through all the possibilities and confirming each and every string match.

Also the "== None" or "!= None" in sqlalchemy's and_(), or_(), and filter() have to kept that way.

I'll be able to send the new patch set before new years. :)'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2011-12-31 16:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-01-01 12:35:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

over commitment this time
I don't see the need to introduce is_bool_type_false and 
is_bool_type_true.

Take /nova/api/ec2/apirequest.py for example

If response_data is 1, the original code will do:        self._render_dict(xml, response_el, {'return': 'true'}).

But the changed code will do:
self._render_dict(xml, response_el, response_data)"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-01 13:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

There is a very good reason I did that there.

Try fixing that line to "if response_data:" and do "./run_tests.sh test_api"

Youl'll see that it does not pass the test.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-01 13:16:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also in nova/compute/api.py and nova/api/ec2/cloud.py, the original author intended to strictly check whether if it is or isn't <type 'bool'> True."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-01-02 06:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-02 08:28:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think we need is_bool_type_false and is_bool_type_true. They are exactly equivalent to "foo is False" and "foo is True", respectively.

Also, if we were to actually keep them, you don't need to compare to types.BoolType. Just compare to bool. Comparing to types.BoolType hasn't been needed since around Python 2.2.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 08:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Soren,

Yes, the if_bool_type_true part I struggled to find a elegant way to do it.

How ever it does say that "XXX is True", or "XXX is False" is the worst case you can do it according to PEP8.

Then came across this doc:
http://docs.python.org/library/types.html

I didn't know if I should use types.BooleanType
or
isinstance(val, bool)

Do you prefer using isinstance than types.BooleanType?'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 08:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Soren,

Apparently there are some places which use types.* to compare instance type.

And it is said on the doc that the preferred way is to use isinstance with the built-in factory functions.

I think they should be fixed also.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 09:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-01-02 10:07:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> How ever it does say that "XXX is True", or "XXX is False" is the worst case you can do it according to PEP8.

Yes, and I agree, but it's not because it doesn't look pretty, but because checking that a particular value actually *is* True (rather than it *evaluates* to True) is generally (though not always) a bad idea. Moving it into a function that does the exact same thing doesn't make it a better idea :)'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 10:21:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Soren,

I understand what you mean and I agree.

Also I'll continue with the db unittests.

I was busy at the year end implementing openstack requirements requested by our customer."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 12:17:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 12:39:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (6 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-02 20:59:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-02 23:23:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

Todd,

The comments you made in I think are reasonable.

However, that part in flavorextraspecs.py I'm not sure if it is a good idea.

I'll run tests and send another patch if there are no problems."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 02:06:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Todd,

assertIsNone and assertIsNotNone are included from 2.7

I'm not sure it is OK to use them."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 02:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 02:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-03 02:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm, thanks'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-03 15:13:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 21:40:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

I'll fix the part to 'not not ...' and resend the patch."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 23:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-01-03 23:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
PEP8 type comparison cleanup

Fixes bug #910295

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.

"== None", "== True", "== False", and "!= None" comparisons in sqlalchemy's
where(), or_(), filter(), and_(), and select() functions should not be changed.

Incorrect comparisons or evaluations in comments were not changed.

Change-Id: I087f0883bf115b5fe714ccfda86a794b9b2a87f7

commit_message:
Abstract Client building into novaclient.client

This prevents clients of the pythonic api from having to know the
internal module structure.

Change-Id: Idd5c522ac3ff6c2d7915f96ed327323ec83d54fc

commit_message:
Implement Endpoint, Endpoint Template, and Credential Managers

- removed api.ENDPOINT_TEMPLATE calls from service.py
- removed api.CREDENTIALS calls from service.py
- separated operations on Endpoints from operations
  on Endpoint Templates
- removed reference to backend api from imports
- Applies to:
      bp keystone-refactor-backend
      bp refactor-keystone-models

Change-Id: I81d34455f847e4a8b1a3bcdd2a2b2b6c581e769c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-04 06:54:04.000000000', 'message': "PEP8 swift cleanup

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: I47863c4862791022670619f19b8bc15d8a93fd81
"}]
commit_message:
PEP8 swift cleanup

The None, True, and False values are singletons.

All variable *comparisons* to singletons should use 'is' or 'is not'.
All variable *evaluations* to boolean should use 'if' or 'if not'.
All Object type comparisons should use isinstance()
instead of comparing types directly.

Change-Id: I47863c4862791022670619f19b8bc15d8a93fd81

[{'account_id': 512, 'date': '2011-09-13 04:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-09-15 14:26:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I tried to make a normal github diff < https://github.com/gholt/swift/pull/4/files > to see if that'd help visualize this monster. Is there something else that was done here, or just the separation?"}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2011-09-16 03:25:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's probably from I had to repeat a bunch of setup code from the proxy test module in the individual controller test modules.  All of the changes were pretty mechanical."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-09-27 07:33:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Just because nobody else bothered to comment yet ;) I'll just say I'm
ambivalent about this change. I'm torn whether it really makes things easier to
read or just makes for a lot of file flipping. It's only about 100 extra lines,
most of which is probably the new file headers, so that concern of mine is
gone. If others go for it, I won't oppose, but the following should be fixed:

swift/proxy/controllers/account.py:133:1: W391 blank line at end of file
swift/proxy/controllers/base.py:536:1: W391 blank line at end of file
swift/proxy/controllers/container.py:186:1: W391 blank line at end of file
swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py:203:1: E302 expected 2 blank lines, found 1
swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py:717:1: W391 blank line at end of file

And the docs only show the original swift/proxy/server.py and none of the new
stuff."}, {'account_id': 512, 'date': '2012-01-04 08:08:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Updates to Tests/Testing

Improve logging, error handling, messaging, and overall
functionality.

- Added '--only' as option as well as '-O' flag to select test
  suites (for consistency with other flags)
- Updated tracer to pop it's argument out of sys.argv (and
  refactored/optimized some code)
- Updated test cleanup so we can now run all suites in
  the same process (less messing about with Popen/Wait)
- Addressed many (handled) import errors showing up with new
  logging (many unnecessary in backend loader)
- Added logging along the way
- unittest.skip not working in test_middleware, so explicitely
  raised SkipTest exceptions
- Made test suites skip intelligently if test filter calls for
  client, functional, or unit tests
- Configured all suite config files to point to same log file
  to more easily debug when running multiple suites

bp keystone-logging

Change-Id: Ic05306c9b8e249c2cbcf92bda3c066031835901b

commit_message:
Bug #910494: Horizon still tries to load quantum.client when QUANTUM_ENABLED=False

Conditionally load api.quantum based on QUANTUM_ENABLED.  This means that
you don't have to have quantum.client installed if you're going to run with
QUANTUM_ENABLED=False.

Change-Id: I9abc08e18188a8fed681603ca2c0dd4534bc5135

commit_message:
Add cloudpipe/vpn api to openstack api contrib.

blueprint cloudpipe-extension

Updates:
    2011-12-19 #1: * Remove unused imports
                   * return uuid as the instance_id
                   * change state with bad config to "invalid"
                   * whitespace cleanup
                   * change top-level key on index to "cloudpipes"
    2011-12-22 #1: * add serializer
                   * change post body to be cloudpipe/project_id
                   * change admin api method
    2011-12-23 #1: * Change extension namespace
    2011-12-23 #2: * Fix failing extension test
    2011-12-23 #3: * Add xtoddx@gmail.com to .mailmap
    2011-12-27 #1: * pep-8
    2012-01-02 #1: * fix test stubs to not cause later test failures
    2012-01-03 #1: * fix test self.app to not traverse middlewares
                   * don't use not in for a single item list

Change-Id: I5710f8cea710fa09e5405c30d565144a7c10e112

subject: Adds documentation for Xen Storage Manager
messages:
[{'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-10-27 23:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-10-27 23:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-10-28 03:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Thanks for all the work on these. Just a few more cloud admin questions still unanswered:

- is XCP or XenServer required for this driver to work? Which version of each has been tested? (you just say Xen hypervisor-specific, I'd like you to be even more specific)
- what network configuration is required for SSH to the volume to work?
- the wiki page states that "the API changes required to create/delete a volume of a particular flavor will be deferred till the LUNR code is available. It is therefore not possible to create a volume for a particular flavor yet, although the code/design exists." To me, flavor is an overloaded term since it is already used in the Compute API. However it won't prevent me from accepting the docs but it is problematic so be sure to clarify this is not the same term as the Compute API flavors.
- how do you scale out this driver across multiple nova-volume nodes?
- do any of the volume management commands work with nova client? 
- can you give more details on Compute API equivalents for euca- commands? (I think volume management is in an extension but I don't know if it works.)

Once these items are covered in the docs and the code lands, I can review again.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-01 23:40:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-02 00:02:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-02 14:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I've added Razique to the reviewers to see if he can review this as well. I think this addresses most of my questions although networking and SSH configuration are still unclear to me, it's a little "hand-wavy" there "ensure all hosts have connectivity". :) Thanks for the efforts.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-02 16:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thanks Anne. Could you tell me what network connectivity details you are looking for. What I tried to convey was that the Xenserver hosts that run volume and compute, need to be able to reach the storage. For example, if this is an NFS backend, the storage should be able to reach the NFS server and have permissions to the exported mountpoint. So the definition of "connectivity" slightly varies based on what backend it is.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-02 18:06:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Renuka, thanks for the work.
Here is my feedback : 
- explain abbreviation, there are a lot ; I think that would help
- the nova commands are not native ones ; from where "sm" does come from ? I assume it means storage manager, is it related to the xenapi driver ? :
http://wiki.openstack.org/xenapi-sm-volume-driver

- Could you preprend the section by a procedure which explains how to install the XSM ?

- Add a schema or more detailled explanation about nova-volume and xenapi connection

"Restart nova-volume and nova-compute (if required) with the new flags. "
: When is this required ?
 
- Which storage plugin is used for the procedure you describe ?
- At lease, some docbook syntax rework needed. I think you should use <simplesect> instead of <section>
There are also syntax rework, but let's focus on the content here.
Thanks !'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-02 22:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-02 22:38:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-02 22:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I have a new patch set with abbreviations expanded. I have also described what storage plugin was used in the example, and corrected the restart sentence.

This documentation is wrt the blueprint here: http://wiki.openstack.org/xenapi-sm-volume-driver
The corresponding code is here: https://review.openstack.org/#change,897

sm for nova-manage has been added for the purpose of this driver and the new nova-manage commands are temporary and will be replaced with the next commit by API extensions. So I expect the documentation related to nova-manage commands here to change soon.

We do not need to install the Storage Manager driver in any other way than what is explained in the configuring section. Is there anything in particular that I am missing? 

I am not sure why the connection between nova-volume and xenapi needs to be explained in the context of Storage Manager. Xenapi has been used in the virt layer of nova for a fairly long time now.

I am not very familiar with docbook syntax. I used "section" so that I can create subsections with descriptions and configuration, and so that they will be enlisted under the table of contents. Could you please tell me what I should use instead?

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-04 22:44:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hi Renuka, it's clearer, thanks a lot for the work you did.

- Does a schema seems necessary, in order to present the interactions between nova and the storage backend ?
- for every plugin you present, will it be necessary to include a link to the official page for the plugin, so we know what we are talking about here. (or at least the blueprint, what do you think Anne ? )
- Do all the plugins work well, or does the user should choose one over another ?
If so, extra procedure could be required in order to integrate the plugin with nova ?

Here is your work reformatted : 
http://paste.openstack.org/show/3094/

If replaced all "sections" by "simplesect". Sections are reserved for main topics. Since your parts are all related to XSM, simplesect are more appropriate.
Razique'}, {'account_id': 1635, 'date': '2011-11-05 01:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Thanks for the feedback Razique.

The schema was used to describe the tables I will create for SM. I do not think they help in explaining the relationship between nova and the storage backends. Besides, only 1 table will stay, if at all, after I refactor this code.

The actual plugins are outside the scope of nova. They are Xenserver storage manager plugins. I have included a link to the admin guide for Xenserver for any setup help.

The user will choose the plugins best suited for their situation and design, what hardware they have, etc.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-11-05 19:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-11-10 13:46:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Thanks for the update :)
Here is your page with the docbook fix : http://paste.openstack.org/show/3240/
You missed some paras. Can I let you update with that syntax ?
The content is clear ; thanks for that nice update"}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-11-22 19:49:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm good with the content but would like Razique's suggested markup, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2011-12-21 09:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: No score

Anne, can I update for him the format and resubmit ? Or should we wait ?'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-30 17:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Yes, go ahead, thanks Razique.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-01-01 19:14:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1627, 'date': '2012-01-01 19:21:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-01-03 19:16:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-03 19:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/openstack-manuals/89/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-03 19:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Adds running_deleted_instance_reaper task.

This adds a periodic task to cleanup erroneously running instances. The
impetus of the patch was a XenServer specific issue bug #911366, where deleted
instances would remain running on the host machine.

The patch however is hypervisor agnostic and is generally useful as a
housekeeping task to make sure these 'zombied' instances are detected.

Change-Id: Iddc6a88920a537a3a115f8b9bc0039ec0e24a194

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-02 15:39:17.000000000', 'message': 'Remove type comparisons using the "types" module

Fixes bug #910763

According to PEP8,
- Object type comparisons should always use isinstance() instead
      of comparing types directly.

        Yes: if isinstance(obj, int):

        No: if type(obj) is type(1):

      When checking if an object is a string, keep in mind that it might be a
      unicode string too! In Python 2.3, str and unicode have a common base
      class, basestring, so you can do:

        if isinstance(obj, basestring):

Change-Id: I7c0fdecf99872f5b8f72b2c2ed4f5c539c33def1
'}, {'created': '2012-01-03 03:23:11.000000000', 'message': 'PEP8 remove direct type comparisons

- Object type comparisons should always use isinstance() instead
      of comparing types directly.

        Yes: if isinstance(obj, int):

        No: if type(obj) is type(1):

      When checking if an object is a string, keep in mind that it might be a
      unicode string too! In Python 2.3, str and unicode have a common base
      class, basestring, so you can do:

        if isinstance(obj, basestring):

Change-Id: I7c0fdecf99872f5b8f72b2c2ed4f5c539c33def1
'}]
commit_message:
PEP8 remove direct type comparisons

Fixes bug #910763

According to PEP8,
- Object type comparisons should always use isinstance() instead
      of comparing types directly.

        Yes: if isinstance(obj, int):

        No: if type(obj) is type(1):

      When checking if an object is a string, keep in mind that it might be a
      unicode string too! In Python 2.3, str and unicode have a common base
      class, basestring, so you can do:

        if isinstance(obj, basestring):

Change-Id: I7c0fdecf99872f5b8f72b2c2ed4f5c539c33def1

commit_message:
Bug #910045: UnboundLocalError when failing to get metrics from XenAPI hosts

Bail early if we fail to get bandwidth metrics -- don't fall through to
try and parse them when we don't have them.

Change-Id: Icb8919861245d4e04e76f1b6bad6d79cb4372151

Reply to comment.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:42:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Stuart!

So... I take full responsibility for this, but you can actually already do this using the configuration files, it's just not documented.

If you add a log_config=LOG_CONFIG_PATH to the config file, you can tell the server to use the logging facilities set in the LOG_CONFIG_PATH file. The settings in the LOG_CONFIG_PATH file override any other logging-related options in the main configuration file.

The structure of a logging config file is detailed here:

http://docs.python.org/library/logging.config.html#configuration-file-format

So, I'm going to -1 on this one and I'll edit the referenced bug to be a bug on documentation of this functionality. OK with you?

-jay"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-11-08 16:44:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Turns out that the log_config isn't actually settable in the main config file, but only via CLI options. This should be changed to allow log_config=PATH in the main config files..."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2011-11-08 17:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Jay,

Sure, no problem with a seperate config file for logging.

I see this in the code:

    if options.get('log_config', None):

I guess this just isn't 'active' right now?
If so do you want me to take a look?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-15 03:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ok, time to regroup here. Jay, Stuart: what needs to happen to get this in? I know we at least need a rebase.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 14:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Yeah, I take full responsibility for this blocker. I'm tempted to just say "let's push this through and try doing a full refactoring of the logging code in a fashion similar to what we just did for the configuration stuff from Mark".

Thoughts?
-jay'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-20 15:10:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm fine with that, Jay. Do you want to take point here? I can if you're busy."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:33:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-28 21:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
utils.find_resource fixes + fix for volumes

Nova volumes do not have a name property but a displayName one, therefore we
modify find_resource() so it looks for this. Then, we modify the test suite
for utils.py so it uses the novaclient.base.ManagerWithFind class for its
FakeManager rather than implementing its own find() method. This way we are
sure that the utils.py functions work correctly with ManagerWithFind and its
way to search in objects list.

FakeResource class is now used, whereas it was not before.

Change-Id: I4c4838250e6987e05022e1607e8d099eb8fb7fff
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

subject: Add list() method to ManagerWithFind
messages:
[{'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-13 16:06:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 19:20:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not certain I understand why this is necessary.  If the method does not exist, you'll get an AttributeError when you attempt to execute it.  Wouldn't that serve the same purpose?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-21 09:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, in both case it would raise, but the AttributeError is not the good one to raise and not the good way to raise it.


NotImplementedError:
This exception is derived from RuntimeError. In user defined base classes, abstract methods should raise this exception when they require derived classes to override the method.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-22 11:04:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-27 17:18:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I still don't understand why this is needed.  Is there a bug this fixes?  Is there something not being caught properly in the test suite?

I don't mind purity patches—I've certainly made several of my own!—but I really don't see how this can possibly fix anything.  (That said, I'm not -1'ing this, and if someone else wants to approve it, that's fine; I'm just trying and failing to understand the patch…)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-28 09:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Yes, this is a purity patch, it does not fix any bug.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-28 16:10:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

[{'created': '2011-12-13 16:03:45.000000000', 'message': "Add list() method to ManagerWithFind

ManagerWithFind.find() method wants to use self.list() but Manager does not
provides it. Therefore, it's better to implement it as an interface here,
and raise a NotImplementedError.

commit_message:
Add list() method to ManagerWithFind

ManagerWithFind.find() method wants to use self.list() but Manager does not
provides it. Therefore, it's better to implement it as an interface here,
and raise a NotImplementedError.

Change-Id: Iba6ef2c1f789c2eb12b210d42261d63796db3407
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

commit_message:
Use py.test in tox, along with trimming 2.5.

I started looking at tox based on this tree, and am really loving it so far.
As part of looking at that, I also found py.test. The output from running
tests in tox+py.test is OUTSTANDING. (oh hi tracebacks with code context for
each part of the traceback!)

Change-Id: I1e643978c52d6e590929dfc34a98b72cf91edd81

commit_message:
Implement Tenant Manager

- remove api.TENANT calls from logic.service
- move tenant.is_ampty call into backend and out
  of the API. It is only used by sqlalchemy and
  the check is used before a delete. The logic
  of whether you can delete a tenant with users
  in it should be in the backend and it should
  throw an error if it can't support it. So this
  logic did not belong in service.py.
- Added Wsgi test module as well

Change-Id: I7b1b0683aea92cd436297203cf085719af7ab2c8

subject: use github bin/swift
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 112, 'name': 'Jesse Andrews', 'email': 'anotherjesse@gmail.com', 'username': 'anotherjesse'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 866, 'name': 'Chmouel Boudjnah', 'email': 'chmouel@chmouel.com', 'username': 'chmouel'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-22 17:26:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2011-11-22 17:35:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Can we just use a different gerrit url instead of a github URL here? github is less reliable and has more of a chance of getting a 404 when we're running stack.sh as part of a an automated job, which would lead to false test failures."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-11-22 17:38:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Actually, since this is inside of enabled_services =~ swift, we should know that we have a local swift checkout.  Why not just symlink it from there to /usr/local/bin?"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-22 17:40:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Totally right, I forgot we have trunk checked out in there, thanks for pointing. Will rework this.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-22 18:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2011-11-22 18:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-22 18:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We checkout stable/diablo and the 2.0 support was only added in 1.4.7 the bin/swift utility is backward compatible with stable/diablo. This will be removed in the future.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-11-23 19:19:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

You might want to change this against stable/diablo then - we have a review in to make master essex'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-11-23 19:30:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I agree with Jesse, if this belongs, it probably only belongs in the stable/diablo branch.  If you're using git-review from pip, you can 'git review stable/diablo'.

However, I'd still like to know what's driving this.

My particular concern is that if we start hard-coding checkouts of tools in the script, we lose the ability to effectively test changes.  For instance, would this change mean that bin/swift never gets tested again because it is pinned at a particular version indefinitely?"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-23 19:43:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Well we need a swift cli that has support for auth_version 2.0 I am not sure how to do it in an another way, how would you suggest we are getting a swift cli compatible with 2.0 installed on a devstack installation ?

My hope is that this is only a temporary thing to make things work until we don't need that kind of hack."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-17 05:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

please abandon this review'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-12-30 21:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
use github bin/swift

Since this is now in official 1.4.5 we checkout the bin/swift that has
auth_version 2.0 support. Hopefully in the future we will have a swift
version that include auth_version and we won't need this hack.

Change-Id: If3e8ad14e364f6296b8a911c9cb405baca8e740c

commit_message:
Implement Role Manager

- removed api.ROLE calls from service.py
- cleaned up backend API function names to better
  reflect what they do (especially for
  differentiating between roles and roles-granted)
- Applies to:
        bp keystone-refactor-backend
        bp refactor-keystone-models

subject: Separate scheduler host management
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-30 18:59:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

was just testing something.  please review: 2552'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-30 19:00:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-30 18:58:32.000000000', 'message': "Separate scheduler host management

This is a bit of a scheduler refactoring to support future scaling work
as a part of blueprint scaling-zones.

With or without that blueprint work, this cleans a number of things up
and paves the way for combining a lot of the schedulers by using this
new 'HostManager' for filtering and weighing (future work :)

On to the goodies:

Introduces new HostManager, splitting code out from ZoneManager.
Zone communication and management is handlded in the ZoneManager.
Host filtering and weighing is handled in the HostManager.
ZoneManager is removed from the SchedulerManager and direct calls to it
  from the SchedulerManager now occur via the scheduler driver.  This
  simplifies a number of things.
ZoneManager and HostManager classes to use are now flags.  This allows
  one to extend the current classes and use them.
HostManager uses a HostState class to keep info about hosts.  This class
  needs to be extendable.  Since it's very much tied to the HostManager,
  the HostState class to use is not a flag.  It is, instead, a class
  variable in HostManager.
Filtering functions now accept a single host to filter.  This improves
  performance by not having to build a new array of hosts within every
  filter function.
Filtering functions now accept a more generic 'filter_properties'
  dictionary which we can fill with information available for filtering.
  Adding additional data to this 'filter_properties' can be done by
  subclassing.
Weighing functions now accept this 'filter_properties', also, although
  it's poorly named ATM.  Will be cleaned up in a future branch when I
  move some weighing functions into the host manager.
Filtering functions are now topic-specific, so we can support more than
  just compute host filtering.
Filtering tests are true unit tests now.
test_zones was moved from top level to under scheduler as zone_manager
  tests and refactored to be true unit tests.
Host tests are true unit tests now.
Other minor cleanups

Change-Id: Ic23a24d8acc6e16c4fe96d2c81661b42a52b66da
"}]
commit_message:
Separate scheduler host management

This is a bit of a scheduler refactoring to support future scaling work
as a part of blueprint scaling-zones.

With or without that blueprint work, this cleans a number of things up
and paves the way for combining a lot of the schedulers by using this
new 'HostManager' for filtering and weighing (future work :)

On to the goodies:

Introduces new HostManager, splitting code out from ZoneManager.
Zone communication and management is handlded in the ZoneManager.
Host filtering and weighing is handled in the HostManager.
ZoneManager is removed from the SchedulerManager and direct calls to it
  from the SchedulerManager now occur via the scheduler driver.  This
  simplifies a number of things.
ZoneManager and HostManager classes to use are now flags.  This allows
  one to extend the current classes and use them.
HostManager uses a HostState class to keep info about hosts.  This class
  needs to be extendable.  Since it's very much tied to the HostManager,
  the HostState class to use is not a flag.  It is, instead, a class
  variable in HostManager.
Filtering functions now accept a single host to filter.  This improves
  performance by not having to build a new array of hosts within every
  filter function.
Filtering functions now accept a more generic 'filter_properties'
  dictionary which we can fill with information available for filtering.
  Adding additional data to this 'filter_properties' can be done by
  subclassing.
Weighing functions now accept this 'filter_properties', also, although
  it's poorly named ATM.  Will be cleaned up in a future branch when I
  move some weighing functions into the host manager.
Filtering functions are now topic-specific, so we can support more than
  just compute host filtering.
Filtering tests are true unit tests now.
test_zones was moved from top level to under scheduler as zone_manager
  tests and refactored to be true unit tests.
Host tests are true unit tests now.
Other minor cleanups

Change-Id: Ic23a24d8acc6e16c4fe96d2c81661b42a52b66da

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-16 15:32:56.000000000', 'message': "if using lxc, use cirros rootfs image

The cirros 'uec' image contains a kernel, a ramdisk, and a rootfs.
However, the rootfs is empty. cirros copies its ramdisk to it on its first
boot.  That means, if you try this with lxc, there is no filesystem for
lxc to boot.

So, in the case of lxc, import the rootfs image, which is a populated
ext3 filesystem, which is what nova lxc expects.

Change-Id: I3ada380c61044a08697b0a964a962b269ea5224c
"}]
commit_message:
if using lxc, use cirros rootfs image

The cirros 'uec' image contains a kernel, a ramdisk, and a rootfs.
However, the rootfs is empty. cirros copies its ramdisk to it on its first
boot.  That means, if you try this with lxc, there is no filesystem for
lxc to boot.

So, in the case of lxc, import the rootfs image, which is a populated
ext3 filesystem, which is what nova lxc expects.

Change-Id: I3ada380c61044a08697b0a964a962b269ea5224c

commit_message:
Synchronize notification queue setup between nova and glance

Fixes bug 901376

Glance used a SimpleQueue which would end up with a direct queue with an
exchange named the same as the queue. This was different than Nova, which
uses a topic queue with an exchange named 'nova'.

This change makes Glance use a topic queue with a configurable exchange
name to match Nova.

Change-Id: Ia014e4c00060abc2345289a54e45bbfdc6b7e8e5

commit_message:
Ensure generated passwords meet minimum complexity

Windows has a complexity requirement of at least three of these
criteria:
- one or more upper case characters
- one or more lower case characters
- one or more numbers
- one or more special characters

In some cases, the passwords generated didn't meet three of these four
critera. This change enforces that three of these criteria will be
met in the generated passwords.

Change-Id: Ibe0055b8830b426aee1c9b722cc2fae2f5db4c5c

Looking at the code, lets take keystone/logic/service.py for example, it seems like some of the methods such as has_admin_role(), has_service_admin_role(), etc were moved out of IdentityService  class then got moved back in. There got to be very good reasons for doing this. Answering Yogi and Guang -

What we're doing is trying to isolate the backend code to make it easier to write, replace, and import backends. Right now, there are too many levels of indirection and the use of a lot of global variables throughout the code base to access the backends.

See the links in the blueprints (keystone-refactor-backend and refactor-keystone-models) for examples of what we are moving towards."}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-29 21:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8, 'date': '2011-12-29 21:32:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Refactor models and backends

Blueprints:
  bp keystone-refactor-backend
  bp refactor-keystone-models

This is a combination of 9 commits. Originals
here: github.com/ziadsawalha/keystone/commits/models

Move token calls in service.py to managers.token
- removed direct backend calls from service.py to token backend
- implementing blueprint keystone-refactor-backend

Refactor: move tenant calls to managers.tenant
- Not all calls removed yet

Implement models.Service in backends
- Adding functionality needed to models.Role
- Using models.Service in sqlalchemy.service
- additional serialization changes and tests.

Implement models.service
- remove logic.types.service:Service class

Implement user.manager
- remove direct backend calls to api.USER from service.py

Remove user_get_update from backend API
- No idea why that is there. It seems to be a
  duplicate of plain get.

Backend updates
- Document some user APIs
- Update user.check_password to take user ID and password only
- Implement more user.manager calls in service.py
- remove user.delete_ternant_user call (probably existed when
  we had the concept of users under tenants

Completed moving api.USER to user_manager in service.py
- Completed remove of api.USER
- Additional backend API documentation

Removed logic.types.service
- Completed moving to models.Service(s)
- Added basic test module for models.Services
- pep8/pylint cleanup

Added keystone-manage tests

Change-Id: Ife3e95974ab63c1c3a5999fd1ac558a3ef77e5ff

commit_message:
Date 28/12/2011 12:05PM IST

All changes are made for SolarisISCSIDriver class
1. Added a flag poolname that will define the ZFS pool on which the volumes will be created.
2.Added methods create_snapshot, delete_snapshot and create_volume_from_snapshot for SolarisISCSIDriver class.

Change-Id: I4be0c765467c89879749e02d37d2f69010bc5fc8

commit_message:
Intelligent programmatic table generation!

Implements blueprint reusable-table-component.

This is a major step in making Horizon a componentized,
reusable suite of tools for building awesome dashboards. It
allows people to define and work with tables representing
live data in Python, constructing all the appropriate actions,
data transformations, etc. once, and then rendering everywhere
consistently and without all the copy-paste duplication.

Includes extensive tests and a full set of documentation for
all public parts of the API.

Change-Id: Ia4521eb1361a7fe5ebb839fde891db8fd5414c2e

commit_message:
Move URL Normalizer to Frontends

keystone.middleware.url is a front-end filter for
keystone. It is not a service middleware. It should
therefore not be in the middleware directory.

This patch moves it and updates associated documentation
and tests. It also maintains a reference file and code
to allow existing configurations to continue to work.
They will receive a warning message in the log to
update their configuration.

Change-Id: Ib946bd3883df1cf5855b207771669f91d0dad1da

subject: Adding index to instances project_id column
messages:
[{'account_id': 998, 'date': '2011-12-27 22:12:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-28 18:18:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

I'm not sure I agree with the approach of adding indexes in migrations like this. This could cause some pretty major headaches when upgrading large deployments. The approach we've been taking so far is to only add indexes where absolutely necessary (PRIMARY, UNIQUE, FOREIGN), nothing for pure performance. I'd like to get some opinions of some community members before this gets in.

As a side note, I did verify that this index would get used by our queries, so it is useful."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-29 16:21:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm good with this. We are almost certainly going to need more indexes than this to make nova perform.

My vote is to have the migrations create them."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-29 16:26:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm cool with this, too. I think my concerns can be addressed by enhancing the nova-manage db functionality to be a bit more friendly (similar to what keystone does)."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 18:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I had a discussion with Gabe and others about this recently again.  I think we have to do this where it makes sense.  Waldon, I think your issue still applies for other types of migrations, not just adding indexes.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-29 19:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2152/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-29 19:03:24.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

subject: Ensure queue is declared durable so messages aren't dropped
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-28 23:08:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Minor thing inline.  Also:

Not sure the commit reason matches the change?

This doesn't change the fact that if the exchange and/or queue exists already with a different type... that an exception will be thrown.

What it does seem to address is just making sure a queue always exists so messages aren't lost.

Unless I'm missing something?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-28 23:53:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The kombu documentation says that durable defaults to False. The previous change removed explicit durable=False and depended on the default. That should be identical behavior before, but would result in an error from rabbitmq thinking one of the attributes on an already existing exchange changed. I didn't dig too deeply into why, I just wanted to make sure the behavior didn't change unnecessarily."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-29 00:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 08:21:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Aha... that explains what I missed.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 08:23:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-29 17:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-29 18:40:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2011-12-28 22:42:27.000000000', 'message': 'Be explicit with kombu to avoid redeclaring incompatible exchanges

In some cases, we could redeclare exchanges or queues differently
which would result in an error. This change makes further fixes to
388e2605358937211070d96cc6353097e465a270 so it tries harder to not
make this mistake.

Change-Id: I9f8dfd6eaf3996be58fecff6ad91508bdcef23f3
'}, {'created': '2011-12-29 00:00:37.000000000', 'message': "Ensure queue is declared durable so messages aren't dropped

Fixes bug lp901375

Ensure that a queue is declared durable so messages aren't dropped before
consumers are started

Change-Id: I9f8dfd6eaf3996be58fecff6ad91508bdcef23f3
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure queue is declared durable so messages aren't dropped

Fixes bug lp901375

Ensure that a queue is declared durable so messages aren't dropped before
consumers are started

Change-Id: I9f8dfd6eaf3996be58fecff6ad91508bdcef23f3

swift.common.utils.listdir call which returns an empty list for
non-existent paths.

[{'created': '2011-12-22 19:53:42.000000000', 'message': "Removed bin/glance's TTY detection.

The logic is sound: if location=XXX is specified, use that.

Change-Id: I057312becad59b3dd7a71f94d25ebd032e1a7b52
"}, {'created': '2011-12-22 20:25:50.000000000', 'message': "Removed bin/glance's TTY detection.

Fixes bug 907906

The logic is sound: if location=XXX is specified, use that.
If it's not specified, use sys.stdin to read image data. No need to
error when location=XXX is specified and stdin just happens to be a TTY.

Change-Id: I057312becad59b3dd7a71f94d25ebd032e1a7b52
"}]
commit_message:
Removed bin/glance's TTY detection.

Fixes bug 907906

The logic is sound: if location=XXX is specified, use that.
If it's not specified, use sys.stdin to read image data. No need to
error when location=XXX is specified and stdin just happens to be a TTY.

Change-Id: I057312becad59b3dd7a71f94d25ebd032e1a7b52

subject: Allow the ability to load images with spaces in the name.
messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-23 17:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Smokestacks'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-23 17:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/openstack-chef/40/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-23 17:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-29 13:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FYI, this really is not the way that images should be uploaded to Glance. The image file should be redirected to glance add, not piped in. The difference between piping and redirection is that in the latter case, an fseek(SEEK_END) will work, while it will not on the former, leading to problems with unknown content lengths.

Just FYI.
-jay'}]

commit_message:
Improve the test framework to handle urls with args.

Now a url like 'os-foo-bar/blah?arg1=apple&arg2=orange' will
invoke a fake function like 'os_foo_bar_blah' and receive
the arguments (arg1=apple, arg2=orange) as part of its
kwargs.

Change-Id: If2905ed0f335128ccd4100997354dfe12e0017fd

commit_message:
Simplifying get_console_output client interface.

Now instead of doing server.get_console_output()[0]['output']
You can do: server.get_console_output()

Change-Id: Ic8a3f435fa0111feaa0d5cd42943dd2c7c243fb9

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1998, 'name': 'andrewbogott', 'username': 'andrewbogott', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-15 22:37:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

This is only a partial implementation -- I've submitted it here for comments before I flesh it out."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-20 02:41:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-20 15:20:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

I'm curious what the difference is between the 'instance_dns_manager' and the 'floating_dns_manager'. What's the reason to have both?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 18:47:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Looks good, but I agree with Waldon's comments."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-20 19:07:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-20 19:14:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Brian Waldon wrote:

> I'm curious what the difference is between the 
> 'instance_dns_manager' and the 'floating_dns_manager'. 
> What's the reason to have both?

They're quite different.  An instance IP will generally be a private IP, and it will be assigned to a DNS address that is most likely also private.  The instance driver may simply modify /etc/hosts file or make some other minor, local change.  This registration happens automatically anytime an instance is created or halted.  There will generally only be a single instance DNS entry for a single instance.

Floating IPs are public, so the floating driver will need to act on a public DNS database:  a zone file, or a powerDNS back-end, or something like that.  Floating DNS entries can be created or deleted interactively at any time, and there can be multiple entries for a given IP."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 20:42:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-20 20:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

Can you also add some testing for the xml serialization?"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-21 03:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-21 03:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (6 inline comments)

serialization tests added, as well.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-21 22:33:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-22 05:09:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-22 05:09:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-22 14:13:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Can you write up an overview of the API interface you're creating in this extension? I think it would help everybody get a better understanding of what this is (an etherpad will do for now). I'll work with you to get the official documentation written when the time comes."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-23 06:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:11:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Looks great so far, Andrew. Just one inline comment on the interface. I'd also like to see some network api/manager tests with this patch."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2011-12-26 21:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 21:21:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Create notification queues as durable

Fixes bug lp901375

The notification system in Nova is built on top of nova.rpc. It uses a
set of defaults for queues that isn't ideal for notification queues.
This change makes the notification queue durable across restarts.

Change-Id: I14c4d5da8d8af027b7d11631f3ac7707f2611a20
