subject: Makes disassociate by timeout work with multi-host
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 17:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Vish: Just to check (as its a bit hard to tell from the commenst trail in the bug) - does this still leave the mechanism for freeing up IPs under the control of DNSmasq ?

The original bug report seemed to propose changing this, which would be a concern'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

BTW - is there a way to flag fixes which are good candidates for diablo.stable ?'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/325/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2088/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/713/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:31:36.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-27 17:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Any chance we can get an answer for Phil's first question, please?

Does this still leave the mechanism for freeing up IPs under the control of DNSmasq?

Phil, as for tagging stablo/diablo, I'm working on a solution for this... I'll send you an email later.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-28 19:14:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry about the slow response, was on vacation.

This does not free up ips under the control of dnsmasq, so the timeout will have to be longer than the lease time for this to work properly.

This patch restores the original timeout behavior, which was to timeout leases after a set time.  There is a "better" option that immediately releases ips from dnsmasq on terminate.  The flag is:
--force_dhcp_release

but it depends on an extra utility from the dnsmasq package that may not exist on all installs.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-28 06:58:56.000000000', 'message': "Bug #909255: Endpoint handling broken on SQL backend by portable-identifiers changes

When deciding whether to translate UIDs to integer IDs or vice versa, use
hasattr(api.TENANT, 'uid_to_id') or hasattr(api.TENANT, 'id_to_uid') in place
of isinstance(api.TENANT, models.Tenant).  This matches the code elsewhere
(e.g. user.py) and has the effect that the IDs will be translated correctly.

Change-Id: Ia036bf310d48f8f8aa5739cb3e09d1f7364ad1a4
"}]
commit_message:
Bug #909255: Endpoint handling broken on SQL backend by portable-identifiers changes

When deciding whether to translate UIDs to integer IDs or vice versa, use
hasattr(api.TENANT, 'uid_to_id') or hasattr(api.TENANT, 'id_to_uid') in place
of isinstance(api.TENANT, models.Tenant).  This matches the code elsewhere
(e.g. user.py) and has the effect that the IDs will be translated correctly.

Change-Id: Ia036bf310d48f8f8aa5739cb3e09d1f7364ad1a4

subject: bug 890411
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 5, 'name': 'Ziad Sawalha', 'email': 'ziad.sawalha@rackspace.com', 'username': 'ziad-sawalha'}, {'_account_id': 154, 'name': 'Liem Nguyen', 'email': 'liem.m.nguyen@hp.com', 'username': 'liemmn'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 1916, 'name': 'Guang Yee', 'email': 'gyee@suse.com', 'username': 'guang-yee'}, {'_account_id': 2106, 'name': 'Jason Rouault', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-01 21:52:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Guang - thanks for submitting this.

We can't introduce the serviceId parameter as mandatory. That will break compatibility with all existing deployments. Can you make that optional?

Second: we're trying to make sure our patches are focused on one item or bug. By including the LDAP and quantum fixes in this patch, you prevent others from cherry-picking those patches into their forks of Keystone. What we recommend you do (and we need to start doing this too) is to make a new branch off of master, make the fix, submit it for review, and then go back to your working branch and cherry-pick the fix. git-review will handle this workflow when you submit your working branch for review."}, {'account_id': 2106, 'date': '2011-12-01 23:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Guang, I like it.  Ziad- the whole point of putting this in essex vs diablo-stable is because it is not backwards compatible.  The point of the fix is to make this more secure.  If you like we can define a new interface GET /secure/tokens.  All kidding aside, I think there is a process problem here.  Why not rev the the API?'}, {'account_id': 154, 'date': '2011-12-02 01:21:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me from a coding perspective.  But, since this is a backward-incompatible change, we need to take into account rolling the rev.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-02 14:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm seeing a bunch of SQL issues when running integration tests on this:

sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError: (IntegrityError) column name is not unique u'INSERT INTO tenants (name, "desc", enabled) VALUES (?, ?, ?)' ('admin', None, True)

---- End output of /usr/bin/keystone-manage tenant add 'admin' ----

Presumably with this branch I'd also need to add serviceId as well. Is there any way to make this a bit more friendly and/or backwards compatible?'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-02 18:37:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Jason - we can rev the API if necessary, but the pain that would cause (and the amount of work needed to make it as painless as necessary) means we will only rev the API if we absolutely must.
I feel the code added to allow services to prefix their roles with a service name and the authorization enforced on that to prevent other services from using those prefixes provides a workaround that addresses the use case you raised where role name conflicts can happen between services.
I am ready to accept this patch for those who need more control/security than that provides, but I don't agree that it needs to be mandatory and force backwards incompatibility."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2011-12-02 23:28:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError: (IntegrityError) column name is not unique u'INSERT INTO tenants (name, "desc", enabled) VALUES (?, ?, ?)' ('admin', None, True)


This error happens when you run sampledata twice. Nothing to do with my changes. Its basically SQL way of saying data already exist.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-05 23:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Blocking all merges until (unrelated) bug 900514 is resolved

https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/900514'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-06 03:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Unblocking'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-06 04:29:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (21 inline comments)

On the topic of making this optional: I think it should be optional from a deployment perspective, not an API perspective.

So, the deployment would have two options:
A) the API supports this feature, but does not enforce it
A) the API supports this feature, and enforces it

We can even add a giant red box to the docs instructing  people to enable this for security purposes.

If we want to remove the relevant keystone.conf option (e.g. enforce_service_filters) if we're comfortable with the impact prior to essex, I think we can do that... and I think that will make everyone happy.

Additionally, we can default-enable it out of the box in keystone.conf, and if the config parameter is not present, assume disabled (existing installation that will probably break)."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2011-12-27 18:37:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

replaced by HP-IDM extension'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-01 20:37:32.000000000', 'message': "bug 890411

Fixed bug 890411. Introduced a mandatory serviceId parameter in
token validation to mitigate security risk with tenant role
conflicts/overlaps.

GET/HEAD /tokens/{tokenId}?[belongsTo=<tenantID>&][serviceId=<comma-separated service IDs>]

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/890411 for more details.

There are also two minor fixes not related to the bug.

1. fixed the LDAP filter where it was comparing serviceId string with
   serviceId numbers. It is not doing string to string comparison to
   ensure consistency.
2. fixed quantum_auth_token.py middleware where it was parsing role_ref['Id']
   instead of role_ref['id'].

Change-Id: Icb0d5eab5885a621ef8e2c42b938ff9dd68712d1
"}]
commit_message:
bug 890411

Fixed bug 890411. Introduced a mandatory serviceId parameter in
token validation to mitigate security risk with tenant role
conflicts/overlaps.

GET/HEAD /tokens/{tokenId}?[belongsTo=<tenantID>&][serviceId=<comma-separated service IDs>]

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/890411 for more details.

There are also two minor fixes not related to the bug.

1. fixed the LDAP filter where it was comparing serviceId string with
   serviceId numbers. It is not doing string to string comparison to
   ensure consistency.
2. fixed quantum_auth_token.py middleware where it was parsing role_ref['Id']
   instead of role_ref['id'].

Change-Id: Icb0d5eab5885a621ef8e2c42b938ff9dd68712d1

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-03 02:01:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed Bug 890411

This is an alternate solution ... Making serviceId optional instead
of mandatory to preserve backward compatibility.

If serviceId is absent, all roles associated with the user and
tenant will be returned.

If serviceId is present, it will be verified and only the roles
associated with the given service IDs will be returned.

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/890411 for more
details.

Change-Id: I27eed24bb29c35117cf5005b498df1f17efb9971
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed Bug 890411

This is an alternate solution ... Making serviceId optional instead
of mandatory to preserve backward compatibility.

If serviceId is absent, all roles associated with the user and
tenant will be returned.

If serviceId is present, it will be verified and only the roles
associated with the given service IDs will be returned.

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/890411 for more
details.

Change-Id: I27eed24bb29c35117cf5005b498df1f17efb9971

commit_message:
Return Endpoint IDs

- Implements blueprint endpoint-identifiers
- Returns a unique identifier for each endpoint when
  authenticating. This allows clients to reference an
  endpoint even if some of its attributes (such as
  region, version, etc...) change.

Change-Id: Ib26a73493262cce801a70681a7f279d91e85a417

commit_message:
Fix duplicate logging

- when running bin/keystone, duplicate FileHandlers
  were intialized. A check now prevents this.
- Fixes bug 844959
- Addresses some of blueprint keystone-logging

Change-Id: Ic017423091c35f37721dbda7af0fa253541647c6

[{'account_id': 97, 'date': '2011-12-14 02:28:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good. It's not necessary as the defaults will handle it, but it may be worth adding this setting to the sample config file to make its existence more explicit."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 12:45:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Donald!

Could you explain the use case for having a blank port?

Thanks!
-jay'}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2011-12-14 18:38:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

On our systems we go through a load balancer having an endpoint https://endpoint.com, so we are not using the port.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 20:45:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

No port over https is not null, it's 443...

So, if you set port=443, wouldn't that work without the port changes here?

FYI, the use_ssl is fine in my book... I just don't like the nullstring port default here...

Make sense?
-jay"}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2011-12-15 00:06:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-12-17 21:01:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

@property
    def port(self):
        """Listen port of the Nova service."""
        return self.get("port", "8773")

When I run pep8 on this file locally I don't get complaints on the white space after "port", 

Do I need to change this file to have no white spaces. All the other property settings have a white space, not just this one.'}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:10:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

You should put in a whitespace, as it's pep8 standard. pep8 should be the latest v0.6.1."}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1794, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-09-08 16:02:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Hi Johannes, great work overall. One little inline comment to remove a redundant test line.

Also, we will need additional test cases added to the test_private_images.py and test_shared_images.py functional test cases that validate behaviour that trying to delete protected images when the authenticated user is an admin, a regular user, an anonymous user, and a user in a shared image group.

Thanks!
jay"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2011-09-08 20:24:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I cannot get this to work. When I use this branch, glance crashes in a couple different ways. Could you manually test this and let me know if it works for you? Master works just fine for me."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-09-08 22:16:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I tested the code before submitting to Gerrit. I also tested it again just now and it works fine for me.

Did you perform a DB upgrade? Did perform a conflicting DB upgrade maybe (from testing another patch)?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-09-13 17:52:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Johannes! Did you get a chance to look into my review comments?

Thanks!
-jay'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-09-22 18:03:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hey Johannes, this is excellent stuff. I just had one comment on glance/tests/functional/test_bin_glance.py for you to address. There is an assert in there that was just copied from another test case that doesn't need to be repeated in this new test case. Other than that little thing, I think this is good to go."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-10-04 22:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-10-11 15:37:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I think you missed "git add" on most of your database migrations, and the one .sql that did get in has some trailing whitespace I'd like to see removed; otherwise, looks good!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-10-11 15:49:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have all of the database migrations checked in. Why do you think most of it is missing?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-10-11 16:01:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I only see 012_add_protected.py and 012_sqlite_downgrade.sql and I was kind of expecting that there would be at least 012_sqlite_upgrade.sql.  If I'm wrong, no problem; just thought there would be more."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-10-11 20:31:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-10-11 21:10:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

LGTM!'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-10-11 22:11:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I think we need to integrate authz with the ability to update the 'protected' attribute. Do you have any plans to do this?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-09 02:33:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Johannes: any progress here? Curious what the state is since this review hasn't been touched in a month."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-11-09 03:00:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've been waiting on Keystone to settle down.

I'll get back and add the requested functionality soon."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-11-09 03:19:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Excellent. That answers my question :)'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-13 21:35:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Johannes: do you think you'll have time to get this branch cleaned up sometime soon?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-15 15:43:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

It seems like every time I go get this branch back into shape, something is broken in Glance.

Right now, it looks like the new config stuff is broken. I can't run a db_sync because it can't register the SQL config options.

I spent some time trying to figure out what's wrong but ended up at a dead-end where the docstrings in glance/common/cfg.py are completely wrong wrt to the actual implementation. I have no idea how config groups are supposed to work with the code that's there right now.

I'll come back to this when glance has stabilized again."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:05:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Not sure I understand what "when Glance has stabilized again" means...'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:06:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I also don't think it's reasonable to expect Glance to not change during the course of 2 months while this patch has sat in the queue..."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-15 17:30:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I do believe it's reasonable to expect a trunk that works. It's horribly broken by the config changes that got merged. I'm generally for these config changes, but they don't appear to have been properly tested (glance-manage db_sync is broken) or reviewed (docstrings reference necessary features that aren't implemented).

While I don't work on glance much, I've had very bad luck with the state of glance the last few times I've tried working on it. So much that I'm still using a checkout from October so I can continue working on nova.

So when I say "when Glance has stabilized again", I mean when I don't have to wade through unrelated breakage to get stuff done.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 21:27:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm done arguing with you on this, Johannes. Perhaps we should just get another developer to do this.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-15 22:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think you're confused.

I'm willing to get this change updated, but it's very difficult when I can't even run glance.

I even tried fixing the breakage in trunk (see lp904863), but ran into problems with conflicting documentation and implementation. At that point, I can't go any farther, I have other work I need to get done.

I'll try again when trunk isn't broken and I have time (which I probably will in the next day or two)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-20 16:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 19:50:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-26 21:11:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Why isn't there a 003_sqlite_upgrade.sql file?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-27 15:26:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

It doesn't need an upgrade file. The downgrade is only to workaround bugs in sqlalchemy (see the comment at the top of the file)."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:16:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

So I'm confused why we needed a sqlite_upgrade/downgrade for migration 003 (https://github.com/openstack/glance/tree/master/glance/registry/db/migrate_repo/versions) but not here. The situation here seems quite similar to that one."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:33:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, approved

(1 inline comment)

There's a little thing that could be done to DRY up the bool from string handling, but that can be addressed in a later patch. Sending this through. Thanks, Johannes. Nice work."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:35:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

There are a lot of differences between 003 and 013. What are you looking at in particular?

You can run the tests to see that upgrades and downgrades work. If you rename to the downgrade file for 013 and run the tests again, you can see it fails because sqlalchemy has a bug dropping boolean columns (it doesn't remove the CHECK statement)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance/89399/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance-pep8/402/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/glance-merge/229/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-27 16:40:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I guess I was thinking they both just add a column, so why should they be different? But I'll stand down now that it's in. Somebody must know something I don't ;)"}]

commit_message:
Adds support for protecting images from accidental deletion.

Implements blueprint protected-images.

A new attribute 'protected' is now available to prevent an image from being
deleted. If the image is protected a HTTP Forbidden (403) error is returned.
The attribute can be changed via an update of the image.

Change-Id: I72ba1c6499065441dc73e5ec2fa873d76c7f60d1

commit_message:
Fix for bug 901609, when using v2 auth should use /v2.0/tokens path.

Added relevant V1 and V2 auth unit tests.

Also allow keystone authentication to work whether OS_AUTH_URL
has a trailing slash or not.

Change-Id: Ia94c759644c9394d72cc07999a1eb8eedda5ea3a

messages:
[{'account_id': 964, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:39:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Please also upload the source file for the PDF since it is Apache2 licensed."}, {'account_id': 143, 'date': '2011-12-23 19:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The source has been submitted in the identity-api project.  For some reason keystone submits the source and the PDF artifact.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-23 21:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

why do we put PDFs in git?'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-26 15:57:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

We put PDFs in git so Keystone can link to and return them when users query extensions. We return the WADL, version, and a link to a PDF.

By having it in the repo we can be sure we have the right version linked in.

We could (and probably should) stop doing this once the extension registry is formally in OpenStack. It still is not ratified.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-26 16:10:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful

subject: Add exit_code, stdout, stderr etc to ProcessExecutionException
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-23 09:48:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This looks sensible. Though it's usually best to treat the return code from external commands as a boolean.

Have you a particular use case. The example you gave; "file does not exist on a remove", might be best achieved with 'rm -f' ?

Note also the new utils.trycmd() function that can be used to avoid warnings, often emitted from commands.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-23 16:09:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-23 16:37:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Here's an example from code that is in my illumos support branch (not yet submitted as a patch):


        try:
            utils.execute(*cmd)
        except exception.ProcessExecutionError as e:
            if e.exit_code==1 and 'dataset does not exist' in e.stderr:
                LOG.info(_("ZFS dataset already destroyed: %s"), zvol)
                return
            raise

The alternative is to do something like this:

        if fmri:
            (stdout, stderr) = utils.execute('svcs', '-H', '-o', output_format, fmri, check_exit_code=False)
            if stderr:
                if "doesn't match any instances" in stderr:
                    pass
                else:
                    raise Exception(_('Error querying SMF service: %s.  %s') % (fmri, stderr))


It can be very useful to inspect the exit code for functions that signal their failure reason in the exit code, so that we can avoid the monstrosity that is text-matching against stderr (I guess that raises another question, of whether we should always be setting an en-US locale when executing commands if we're parsing textual output - if one of the non-English devs knows how this works that would be good to know!)'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:31:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well generally one should avoid parsing stderr, and just use it as informational messages. You've mentioned the locale issue, which one can avoid by prepending using LANG=C like:

utils.execute('env', 'LC_ALL=C', 'LANG=C', 'your', 'cmd')

There is also the undesirable coupling issue, where changes
in diagnostics messages will require changes in the code parsing those messages"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2011-12-23 20:55:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Knowing the reason for a non-zero exit code can be useful in determining appropriate responses.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-23 22:50:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

p-draigbrady: Thanks for the locale tip.

I agree that it's undesirable to have to parse stderr, but often there's no realistic alternative.  Without the patch though, if you want to ignore some errors, you have to ignore all errors and then parse stderr; I think this is cleaner (and you can consider the exit code if it helps).

I've tried wrapping utils.execute calls in methods that deal with parsing the return values, to try to keep the messy code self-contained and hopefully reusable."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-24 01:12:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

To be explicit, I was just provide more info previously.
It's better to make the return code available in the exception at least, so +1"}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-26 07:36:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-26 07:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Add exit_code, stdout, stderr etc to ProcessExecutionException

This means that we can now catch ProcessExecutionException and inspect the result, in order to handle "acceptable" exceptions e.g. file does not exist on a remove

Change-Id: I4f5dfe1f1d4601dafc50abc4c61f4b616f13c5ff

commit_message:
Implement Multiple Choices Response (bug 843051)

The bug allowed clients to call keystone without a version
in the URL (ex. http://localhost:35357/tenants). This will
prevent that behavior, but will break those clients.

Change-Id: I8fdf2738371a6ceff9729fdb47563fefa0f0ec79

commit_message:
Fixed error with database initialization

New versioning code was not creating tables in
database when database was not an in-memory database.
This broke existing behaviour, scripts (like
devstack).
Identified problem in backend tests where backends
were not being reloaded between tests.
This highlighted an issue where LDAP was not passing
tests and that was fixed.

Change-Id: Ib4eab7fe696bdc48c363032f078e5c535abc0849

commit_message:
Tests use free TCP/IP ports

- test.KeystoneTest loads server (in ClientTests only) on free TCP/IP
  port and sets globals in keystone.test.client to point to the server.
  Client tests pick that info up and use the provided server ports.
- All defaults to 35357/5000 remain

Change-Id: Ifc4ff023e3004cf886d26eaefeb42e1b469e9b81

subject: Serialize compute methods on instance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-15 22:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

A coward waits for smokestack. . .'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-15 22:19:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-16 14:29:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So this guarantees we won't have two actions happen at the same time, but should we think about guaranteeing ordering as well?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 16:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Smokestack is happy! (Well, actually it balked on unit tests, but that was because Pypi was acting up--I verified unit tests locally of course!)

Bcwaldon: I don't believe ordering is something we should be worrying about right now. We don't have any strong ordering guarantees at the publisher level (i.e. the api nodes). We also don't have any action sequences that I see where ordering matters particularly. But I would love to know any counterexamples. I can think of some other ways to get this locking that would do a better job of preserving order."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:33:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

step in the right direction. I'm worried not only about order, but also about action loss (not that the old way took care of this either). Say you have an instance with a few actions queued up and the compute node hiccups or goes down or something. Those actions are gone..."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:44:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:34:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 21:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 22:07:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Don't look now. . ."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-16 22:15:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

I know I wasn't supposed to look, but still... :)"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 23:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 23:12:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 23:44:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Trey,

I definitely agree that there are problems with messages being pulled down, blocking on the semaphore, and then disappearing during a restart. But I also have a branch in that should help with that--sorry I did not make it a dependency. (https://review.openstack.org/#change,2390)'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-17 00:16:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Is there a reason we can't use utils.synchronized or modify utils.synchronized. It looks to be doing basically the same thing.  Vladimir proposed a patch that allows sync to key off of args and kwargs which gets us partway there.

https://review.openstack.org/#change,1092

Adding another way of sync seems a little excessive."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-17 05:47:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Vish,

Sharing stateful locking helper functions seems like a bad idea to me. Any namespace conflict in the usage of utils.synchronized is probably going to cause deadlock (Yikes!).

Also wouldn't different resources need to be locked differently? At the moment the compute manager is using eventlet semaphores, but that seems likely to change for its own reasons, independently of whatever the other clients of utils.synchronized are doing.

I guess I also just don't see the cost in having this code in the compute module. Its not complicated, hard to understand, or hard to find relative to where it is used. Reusing utils.synchronized seems more likely to be costly to me, as you can't change it without affecting all of its dependencies."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-19 10:24:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'll stay out of the overall debate on whether to add another locking mechanism, but I do think it would be good to add a test that verifies this new mechanism works as advertised. I see no problems with the implementation, but would be good to have a unit test at the very least.

Cheers,
-jay"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-19 15:15:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Jay,

/agree

I'll see what I can come up with :-)"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-19 16:27:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Jay,

I've been thinking about this for a while, and I just can't come up with any way to unit test the code. I think maybe an integration test would be feasible however. Do you have any thoughts about how I should approach this? I'm just a little stuck. . ."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-19 20:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Alternative solution:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3897/

Advantages:

1) reusing locking code that is already written that does exactly the same thing

2) we already have tests for utils.synchronized

3) if we decide that we need to run multiple workers on the same machine we can switch to file locks by changing the flag on one line

Disadvantage:

1) a bit less readable (although I find the class based decorator syntax very cryptic)'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-23 19:34:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Working on a different implementation of shared synchronization that is safer than utils.synchronized but keeps project alignment.'}]

commit_message:
Serialize compute methods on instance

Stolen from a previous patchset submitted by Johannes Erdfelt. This
change will make it easier to have less restrictive state checking when
processing compute actions such as deletes. In particular, it becomes
easier in a future patch to support deletes or revert_resizes in the
middle of a resize.

The compute manager allows multiple operations on an instance to run at
the same time, creating a variety of interesting race conditions. This
change serializes compute methods to an individual instance. If an
instance is deleted while it is still being built, the delete will now
wait until after the build is finished.

Change-Id: Ia271199b4f3103b5ff4e227c7c64089f331743db

[{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-15 21:32:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Lazily waiting for Smokestack's verdict. . ."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 04:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Smokestack is happy!'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-16 14:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I like the new logic, Mark.'}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2011-12-16 17:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Debug print statement hanging around.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 17:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-16 17:49:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:43:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

eensy weensy comments inline :)"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Asking vishy - but I seem to remember the reason why the ACK happens there is the way rabbitmq works.

If you want to message ack after processing but the processing includes doing something that takes a while (for instance downloading a large image and then creating an instance) rabbit will consider the non-ack within a timelimit as a failure and re-send the message.

When we ran into the ack issue,  "scheduling" had a very different philosophy:

  * machines that can launch VMs should listen on a compute queue 
  * when someone wants a vm launched add the message to the queue
  * when a machine is "full" stop listening to the compute queue

Now that a scheduler decides which host it might not be an issue but it is something to be aware of because you might have the same message recv multiple times if you don't ack in time.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:57:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I believe the problem we were seeing before was when something would happen that would stop the ack from occurring, i.e. a network disconnect or an exception.

It looks like this should work according to:

http://lists.rabbitmq.com/pipermail/rabbitmq-discuss/2011-May/012994.html

The one issue is if there is a message sent to a general queue that happens to generate a state that crashes the worker.  In this case, the message will not be acked, and be resent, potentially crashing all of the workers.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-17 06:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-18 07:37:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yeah, my only concern would be that we're going to go from:

Possibly stopping a job in the middle of it being worked on... and it's lost

To:

Possibly stopping a job in the middle of it being worked on... and it starts over.

And maybe an even worse case:  If we're processing a long-running job and the connection to rabbit is lost in the meantime (without the daemon restarting, so the job continues to run).  Another worker will pick it the job in parallel."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-18 15:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think that in the majority of cases, we are protected from this right now by our vm state precondition validation in the compute api. So the approach I would like to take is to make a given command idempotent in the manager and driver in the same branch that proposes the removing the state preconditions in the api.

Do you buy that? Or, maybe,  is idempotency impossible on the manager for some reason I don't know about yet?"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-18 15:09:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Err, what I just said doesn't make sense--the full command isn't being resubmitted, just the message... please ignore!"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-19 10:25:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

thx Mark, lgtm.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-19 20:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-20 18:01:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

Looks OK, but see inline comments.  Also, I'm not 100% confident this is the direction we want to go yet, given the conversation, so I'm not +2'ing yet."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 11:40:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I like the concept, but I think we need to be clearer on the impact of messages being processed more than once  before we commit this - it feels like any work to make sure the system is idempotent shoudl come first.

At the moment losing a message isn't great but there is generally an external retry mechanims in that customers  / cloud apps expect to see things go awry with thier VMs and take corrective action.

I fully support moving away from that so that Nova becomes better and more relaible / predictable, but it seems as this on its own might move away from that in the short term."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-23 19:33:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Abandoned

I'm going to reconsider this approach and see if there is a way we can move forward while managing the risks of losing *and* repeating messages."}]

commit_message:
Acknowledge rpc messages after they are completed.

This change causes rpc messages to be acknowledged only after they
are processed rather than eagerly. The idea is that the messages are
not acknowledged during a shutdown.

This is not necessarily the ultimate model we should adopt for rpc.
For instance we really need to think about requeueing and retrying
messages that fail. But it is a step in the right direction that
makes it possible to accept an rpc message without necessarily
starting to process it immediately (as in the case where you need to
wait on acquiring a lock).

Change-Id: Idc11e3207f707e27f7295443f0e3776dba2beeb6

commit_message:
New complex type ServerWithOnlyIDLinks.  This is used in cases where we need to keep track of a server but we can only track the server ID and any related links, nothing else.

Change-Id: Id3de68da73399bcee7e65358a546a0b76669d6e5

commit_message:
Testing Refactor
- this is a squash of 6 commits
- original commits are vailable for cherry-picking here:
  https://github.com/ziadsawalha/keystone/commits/tests

Removed test dependency on sampledata
- added fixtures in FunctionalTestCase class
- updated tests to use created fixtures
- only kept boot-strap creations in KeystoneTestCase

Note: This has significantly slowed down tests, but this will
allow us to continue refactoring tests to not go through HTTP
and not require a running server (where not needed).

Backend test suites (SQL, LDAP, etc) can also now be run
separately and in parallel since they don't need a TCP/IP
port. These tests no longer use http(s).

Update to Tenant serialization

- Correctly handle description as an optional attribute
  of tenant
- added tests that fail where blank description was coming
  back as 'None' string.
- added fixes to handle None correctly (check for None
  before calling str(value)

Separated out test suites

- Unit, Functional, and Client (HTTP) suites can be run separately
- -O flag in run_tests now accepts UnitTests and ClientTests as options
- run_tests will run all suites (but end up executing less tests
  overall since Unit tests run once and client tests run twice; for
  HTTP and HTTPS/SSL tests

Fixed 'python setup.py test' not running

Change-Id: I3505740466abac0fbb35c822858c70a234893798

Minor pep8 errors:
tempest/exceptions.py:41:1: W293 blank line contains whitespace
tempest/tests/test_images.py:74:80: E501 line too long (82 characters)

Thanks for the exceptions changes!'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

pep8 fixed'}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm!'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2011-12-09 01:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Small pep8 issue still. Also, I'm concerned about the robustness of the change in direction on exception handling and use of setup/teardown fixtures. I'd really like to see the code stay consistent"}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-09 16:00:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

I actually have an alternate view. Having a project level base exception class that subclasses python's Exception class adds more simplicity while defining our own exceptions. Also, the hierarchical exception design is consistent with other 'core' projects.
My 2c."}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-09 16:12:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Though I do agree with you that raising rest client response exceptions should preferably be done by the base rest_client and not in methods of individual service clients.'}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2011-12-12 20:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Folks, 

I am really interested to know what direction we are taking for exception handling, as I am not sure about the status of this branch. I have a branch would need refactoring if this change goes through. Many of my tests would also need to be refactored if this scheme is used. Jay/dwalleck?

Cheers!'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:01:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I prefer the more standardized exception handling to align with other core projects, but I recognize the concerns Daryl has about not raising the exceptions in the base rest client. I will address those and re-push, and I will try to address the setUp() tearDown() stuff as well. Rohit, please don't wait for this branch. Go ahead and push your code and I will deal with any merge conflicts resulting from this branch.

Cheers,
-jay"}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2011-12-19 16:24:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Are you still working on merging this branch? I like the refactoring of the exceptions class, and I'd like to see this get in so we can use it. One thought though. Would it make sense to break out the exceptions by application? The use case I can think of where this might be helpful is for when someone wants to replace one piece of OpenStack with their own implementation."}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2011-12-19 16:38:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sorry, one more comment now. Now I get where you're coming from now with handling some exceptions in the client. Handling generic exceptions (500, 501, 400) from the rest client makes sense, but I think what you're suggesting is that by handling the exceptions at a higher level, we can provide more domain specific errors (FlavorNotFound over NotFound and so on). I can see this making the error output a bit easier to read and understand. What I'm wondering is if we could have a generic handler for each client that we could pass the response to and let handle any exceptions. If not, I'd still rather see this get in as is and deal with any optimizations later."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-23 18:35:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Hi Daryl, I'm abandoning this in favour of smaller patches. I'll work on refactoring of the exception stuff in a single patch and re-propose..."}]

commit_message:
Bunch of cleanups in images tests and clients

* Rework exceptions to be more robust and standardized
* Make clients raise relevant exceptions for common
  occurrences like 404 Not Found, etc
* Make the test_image_metadata test class methods parallelizable
  by making test methods idempotent and own their own fixtures

Change-Id: Idbbe0a878672993fe0eb77d27cc7f744648acc9f

Change-Id: Ibf22054ae3fb864242ff3df2b8066985a43803d7

messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-09 19:42:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-09 19:44:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This is kind of a scary set of changes for a stable branch but I think it is warranted. It fixes a known issue in rollback live migration which will cause weird rpc failures.  There also may be other rpc calls that are returning None which we haven't come across yet."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-09 19:52:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yeah.  The carrot changes are more involved.. to match some cleanup I did with kombu.  The kombu changes are more straight forward, I think, and that's the default rpc implementation for diablo, so the carrot changes should be less of a concern.  It's the correct fix for all of the AMQP channel exception issues... so I feel this is probably the appropriate way to fix stable/diablo.  The rpc tests around multicall are pretty decent and I added the test that shows the issue without the patch... so I think we're okay."}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2011-12-12 19:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (4 inline comments)

commit_message:
Fix RPC responses to allow None response correctly.

Fixes bug 897155

Cherry picked from 84693b4a16413830be61f465f602de9d13b45161

Also adds a new fake rpc implementation that tests use by default.
This speeds up the test run by ~10% on my system.  We can decide to
ditch fake_rabbit at some point later..

Change-Id: I8877fad3d41ae055c15b1adff99e535c34e9ce92

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-08 15:40:36.000000000', 'message': "Bug #886353: Faults raised by OpenStack API Resource handlers fail to be reported properly

In Resource.__call__, catch any faults.Fault that are thrown by the request
handler, and make those the action_result.  This means that the Fault doesn't
fall into the exception handler below (faults.Fault is a subclass of
webob.exc.HTTPException) and so we don't attempt to wrap a Fault in a Fault.

(cherry picked from commit 01150b5d0d482a83a1065c2a6d62f4963c9f838d)

Change-Id: Ica31723ddd621332ec4be75db0d675bc98905e43
"}]
commit_message:
Bug #886353: Faults raised by OpenStack API Resource handlers fail to be reported properly

In Resource.__call__, catch any faults.Fault that are thrown by the request
handler, and make those the action_result.  This means that the Fault doesn't
fall into the exception handler below (faults.Fault is a subclass of
webob.exc.HTTPException) and so we don't attempt to wrap a Fault in a Fault.

(cherry picked from commit 01150b5d0d482a83a1065c2a6d62f4963c9f838d)

Change-Id: Ica31723ddd621332ec4be75db0d675bc98905e43

commit_message:
Fixes bug 767947

If libvirt was restarted, a libvirt.libvirtError was raised with error
domain libvirt.VIR_FROM_RPC when trying to use the existing connection.

(cherry picked from commit 7c11490677bc49086271ee377e6a8076eebe15f6)

Change-Id: Ib3d4ff23aadf5a0c93dde0c37c5686bf404ce9de

commit_message:
Verify security group parameters

Introduced various sanity checks before adding security group rule
into the database. The checks have been implemented both in EC2 and
openstack extension code.
Implemented the suggestions made in first patch by Brian
Fixed the unit tests in security groups
Fixed pep8 issues in security group unit tests

Fixes bug 869979.

(cherry picked from commit 1a12349c056b52b488591abb1671ad94a6db6526)

[{'created': '2011-12-22 17:32:56.000000000', 'message': 'Help clarify rpc API with docs and a bit of code.

The intent of this change is to help make the rpc API a bit easier to
understand both for users of the API, and for implementors of the rpc
abstraction.

1) Add a Connection class in nova.rpc.common which defines the public
interface of the connection returned by nova.rpc.create_connection().
Update the existing implementations to inherit from this class.

2) Add documentation for the public methods in nova.rpc.

3) Rename get_impl() to __get_impl() in nova.rpc.  This function is a

Change-Id: Id78acb59474995b7c13b2b6e7c8cd5057ec8cb0f

commit_message:
Help clarify rpc API with docs and a bit of code.

The intent of this change is to help make the rpc API a bit easier to
understand both for users of the API, and for implementors of the rpc
abstraction.

1) Add a Connection class in nova.rpc.common which defines the public
interface of the connection returned by nova.rpc.create_connection().
Update the existing implementations to inherit from this class.

2) Add documentation for the public methods in nova.rpc.

3) Rename get_impl() to __get_impl() in nova.rpc.  This function is a
private implemenation detail and should not be used outside of this
module.  Also move it to the bottom of the file so that all of the
important public API stuff comes first.

Change-Id: Id78acb59474995b7c13b2b6e7c8cd5057ec8cb0f

subject: Bug #906105: run_tests.sh ignores -V option
messages:
[{'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 02:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-19 10:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Ewan,

I think I'd just prefer to get rid of -q and standardize on -V, which I believe keystone, nova, glance, and quantum all use?

As it is, it's a bit confusing, since I don't really relate "quietness" with "run in a venv" :)

-jay'}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-12-19 16:10:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I think I'd just prefer to get rid of -q and standardize on -V, which I believe keystone, nova, glance, and quantum all use?
> As it is, it's a bit confusing, since I don't really relate "quietness" with "run in a venv" :)

That's not my decision -- Devin would need to make a call as to whether he thinks anyone is using -q (or whether it matters if they do).'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 18:36:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I'm perfectly fine with standardizing around -V.  Makes life easier for the CI and QA teams."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:31:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

-V is cool with me.'}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Note: if we standardize around -V it should be made clear that this is a "no input" option, and the "always_venv" variable used to track it should probably be renamed for clarity.

The Jenkins job will need to be updated to use the -V flag instead of --quiet as well.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not submit

See my previous note, also the quiet variable is used many more places than that. We need to make sure the functionality is preserved.'}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:42:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The quiet variable is used in just one more place as far as I can see, and you added it today!

Please someone just choose.  Do we need to keep -q or not?  I've submitted both options now."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-21 23:45:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sorry, the additional instance of quiet happened due to problems we were having with the Jenkins server. Independent and unrelated to this change, but will have to be fixed one way or the other.

The main thing here is that we just need to be clear that always using a virtualenv and running non-interactively are being conflated here.

I don't feel strongly one way or the other about it. I just don't want to be confusing people."}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-12-22 00:07:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 271, 'date': '2011-12-22 00:10:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Third time's the charm?  -V does what it should.  -q implies -V, so Jenkins won't break.  -q -N gives a silent, non-venv run."}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-22 09:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-23 02:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-23 02:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-pep8/151/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-horizon-unittests/111/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-23 02:03:10.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-19 00:37:36.000000000', 'message': "Bug #906105: run_tests.sh ignores -V option

Make -V synonymous with -q.  We have both flags in the Usage
statement, even though we don't need two.  Preserving the behavior
of -V for compat with nova/run_tests.sh (and others) and -q in
case someone is using it.

Change-Id: I0179a00d614285faa17a0845a523b1bfd063aa11
"}, {'created': '2011-12-21 23:34:06.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #906105: run_tests.sh ignores -V option

Replace -q with -V for compat with nova/run_tests.sh (and others).

Change-Id: I0179a00d614285faa17a0845a523b1bfd063aa11
'}, {'created': '2011-12-22 00:07:41.000000000', 'message': 'Bug #906105: run_tests.sh ignores -V option

Implement -V for compat with nova/run_tests.sh (and others).  If -q is set
and -N is not set then assume -V, for compatibility with the
Horizon Jenkins, which is using -q to imply -V as well as its other meanings.

Change-Id: I0179a00d614285faa17a0845a523b1bfd063aa11
'}]
commit_message:
Bug #906105: run_tests.sh ignores -V option

Implement -V for compat with nova/run_tests.sh (and others).  If -q is set
and -N is not set then assume -V, for compatibility with the
Horizon Jenkins, which is using -q to imply -V as well as its other meanings.

Change-Id: I0179a00d614285faa17a0845a523b1bfd063aa11

commit_message:
Refactor Xen Vif drivers. Fixes LP907850

* Allows Vif subclasses to have an __init__ for setting up state
* Allows Vif subclasses to pass arbitrary kwargs to plug/unplug should
  they require more than what the interface specifies

Change-Id: I816aa1537d21005d4332af3477d9fd12f177f326

commit_message:
Add OFFLINE support to allow stack.sh to run cleanly without
Internet access after having initialized /opt/stack with access.
Good for those long flights on a Friday night.

Change-Id: If97c22eef91bbd88aed644f05c56bf815036e78f

commit_message:
Allow specification of SERVICE_HOST in localrc.  This is most immediately useful for aio integration tests, since the access to the public_ip can be unstable in such configurations.

Change-Id: I4864179a64dbc2694bafa8d82280b9859e466b4b

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-30 22:33:21.000000000', 'message': "Bug#898257 support handling images with libguestfs

http://libguestfs.org/ provides both utilities and libraries
to manipulate image files containing various operating systems.
It supports various image file formats and so will expand
the formats and guest types supported by openstack.
It does have extra overhead in that it starts a VM to
access the image. This has both advantages and disadvantages.
Also qemu-nbd is not supported on some systems like RHEL 6.

* nova/virt/disk.py (img_handlers): Add guestfs to the default list
of access methods to try, to act as a fallback.
(_guestfsMnt): A new mixin class to provide the access method.
Note we use the guestmount utility, as a non root user,
so the user will need the ability to use fusermount, which
is often provided by being a member of the 'fuser' group.
In future we might use the guestfs python module to give
greater granularity of control over the image.

Change-Id: I2e22c9d149fff7a73cd8cebaa280d68d3fb9096c

commit_message:
Bug#898257 support handling images with libguestfs

http://libguestfs.org/ provides both utilities and libraries
to manipulate image files containing various operating systems.
It supports various image file formats and so will expand
the formats and guest types supported by openstack.
It does have extra overhead in that it starts a VM to
access the image. This has both advantages and disadvantages.
Also qemu-nbd is not supported on some systems like RHEL 6.

* nova/virt/disk/api.py (img_handlers): Add guestfs to the default
list of access methods to try, to act as a fallback.
* nova/virt/disk/guestfs.py: A new plugin class to provide support
for libguestfs mounting.
Note we use the guestmount utility, as a non root user,
so the user will need the ability to use fusermount, which
is often provided by being a member of the 'fuser' group.
In future we might use the guestfs python module to give
greater granularity of control over the image.

Change-Id: I2e22c9d149fff7a73cd8cebaa280d68d3fb9096c

commit_message:
Fixed version response (bug 891555 and bug 843052)

891555: Version response was supposed to be wrapped in a
'versions' element, instead there was only one version
being returned at the root.
Fixed and added tests to validate that.

843052: requests for version ATOM were ignoring the
atom+xml as a valid content-type. Fix required
adding a new atom template file and adding a new
mapping for the content-type/extension in the
URL normalizer.
Fixed and added tests to validate that.

Change-Id: I259c060e592e11cfc06f59ac5a540178c7f2def2

commit_message:
Fix LDAP schema (bug 904815)

As per comments from Ralf Haferkamp (rhafer):
keystoneName should be a subtype of 'name' instead of 'distinguishedName'. 'name' is defined to be of the DirectoryString Syntax, which basically is UTF-8.

Change-Id: I29ec92f7974170875ad4bfa4dc009eea86b66839

(5 inline comments)

This is looking great. Apart from the nitpicks from Chris and me, I'd +1

I'm still not convinced by the error handling strategy here, though - you've gone to great lengths to avoid any exception raising or catching in the code, instead using a combination of success/failure booleans and error strings

i.e. if DiskImage::mount() fails, it returns False and error messages are available in its errors property. I'd expect it to throw a DiskImageMountError exception or something - that way, as the caller, I can use the same error handling code (e.g. delete the disk image) to handle predictable mount errors (e.g. a corrupted disk) and other not so predictable errors (e.g. straight out bugs in the code)"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-11 21:20:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (4 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-11-30 22:33:20.000000000', 'message': "Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods

Rather than providing two mutually exlusive image
access methods (loop and qemu-nbd), try each in turn.
This is to prepare for a follow up patch which will
add libguestfs as a method to try.

* nova/virt/disk.py(img_handlers): A new list of access methods to try,
with the order being honored.
(_baseMnt, _loopMnt, _nbdMnt): New mixin classes that abstract the
devce allocation, partition mapping and file sys mounting,
for each access type.
(_DiskImage): An internal helper class that uses the mixin classes
to provide the operations available on a disk image file.
When mounting, iterate over each access method until one succeeds.
If a hint is provided about a CoW format image, the list of
methods to try will be reduced accordingly.
Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, the last error is raised,
while interveining errors are logged.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7
"}, {'created': '2011-12-08 16:53:34.000000000', 'message': "Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods

Rather than providing two mutually exlusive image
access methods (loop and qemu-nbd), try each in turn.
This is to prepare for a follow up patch which will
add libguestfs as a method to try.

* nova/virt/mount.py: A new Mount class to abstract the
devce allocation, partition mapping and file sys mounting,
for each access type.
* nova/virt/loop.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide loop back mounting support.
* nova/virt/nbd.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide qemu-nbd mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk.py(img_handlers): A new list of access methods
to try, with the order being honored.
(_DiskImage): An internal helper class that uses the plugin classes
above, to provide the operations available on a disk image file.
When mounting, iterate over each access method until one succeeds.
If a hint is provided about a CoW format image, the list of
methods to try will be reduced accordingly.
Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, errors are collated and raised.
Interveining errors are logged in debug mode for successful mounts.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.
* nova/utils.py (trycmd): A helper function to both deal with,
commands that issue ignorable warnings to stderr,
and commands that EXIT_SUCCESS while issuing errors to stderr.

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7

Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, errors are collated and raised.
Interveining errors are logged in debug mode for successful mounts.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.
* nova/utils.py (trycmd): A helper function to both deal with,
commands that issue ignorable warnings to stderr,
and commands that EXIT_SUCCESS while issuing errors to stderr.

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7

commit_message:
Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods

Rather than providing two mutually exlusive image
access methods (loop and qemu-nbd), try each in turn.
This is to prepare for a follow up patch which will
add libguestfs as a method to try.

* nova/virt/mount.py: A new Mount class to abstract the
devce allocation, partition mapping and file sys mounting,
for each access type.
* nova/virt/disk/loop.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide loop back mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/nbd.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide qemu-nbd mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/api.py: A new file containing the nova.virt.disk
module interface.
(img_handlers): A new list of access methods to try,
with the order being honored.
(_DiskImage): An internal helper class that uses the plugin classes
above, to provide the operations available on a disk image file.
When mounting, iterate over each access method until one succeeds.
If a hint is provided about a CoW format image, the list of
methods to try will be reduced accordingly.
Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, errors are collated and raised.
Interveining errors are logged in debug mode for successful mounts.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.
* nova/utils.py (trycmd): A helper function to both deal with,
commands that issue ignorable warnings to stderr,
and commands that EXIT_SUCCESS while issuing errors to stderr.
nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py: Adjust for the moved virt.disk package

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7

subject: Remove unneeded broken test case.
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-22 06:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Very odd'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-22 06:22:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This actually tests the rpc/__init__ functionality, via somewhat integrated means.

How is it broken?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-22 07:01:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah, I'm still blind apparently.  I see now.  Well, I take the blame for it, but how come tests pass when run as a whole?

I can change it to be true unit tests of rpc/__init__.py if you don't want to bother."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-22 14:32:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm still a bit confused about how this could ever work :-). One note--a week or so ago I noticed these tests not passing when run by module, although the unit tests when run as a whole did pass for me. But recently, I did a find -name *.pyc -delete and now it doesn't work as a whole either.

Does the code in __init__.py need to be unit tested? It is a very small amount of integration glue that seems unlikely to break. This is an example of why I tend to prefer coverage targets just shy of 100%."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-22 18:01:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Yeah, I hear ya.  It's probably not completely necessary, and if it does break, I'm guessing a lot of other tests will fail anyway. :)

Either way, this test is definitely broken, so I'll go ahead and approve this and just not worry about it for now!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-22 18:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/354/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2118/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/743/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-22 18:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Remove unneeded broken test case.

This test case appears to be broken and unneeded. It is trying to test
nova.tests.rpc.fake which does not exist. It appears to me that what
this is supposed to be doing is already being covered by
nova/tests/rpc/test_fake.py.

Change-Id: I49259841e988b50784f637dac016477f246674f5

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-21 11:32:58.000000000', 'message': "Use SQLAlchemy to drop foreign key in DB migrate

A foreign key constraint needs to be removed in order to succeed in the
DB migration. An earlier submitted fix for this uses a mysql drop
statement. I think it's cleaner to use sqlalchemy to do this, as it's
done this way in other version migrations as well. Fix for bug 907254.

Change-Id: Ib021e0ddb2c80ee63888435a9e3761c053534160
"}, {'created': '2011-12-21 16:59:37.000000000', 'message': "Use SQLAlchemy to drop foreign key in DB migrate

DB migration. An earlier submitted fix for this uses a mysql drop
statement. I think it's cleaner to use sqlalchemy to do this, as it's
done this way in other version migrations as well. Fix for bug 907254.

Update: IBM from 1928 called, they want their 80 CPL limit
back. - on a more serious note, fixed jenkins PEP8 failure

Change-Id: Ib021e0ddb2c80ee63888435a9e3761c053534160
"}]
commit_message:
Use SQLAlchemy to drop foreign key in DB migrate

A foreign key constraint needs to be removed in order to succeed in the
DB migration. An earlier submitted fix for this uses a mysql drop
statement. I think it's cleaner to use sqlalchemy to do this, as it's
done this way in other version migrations as well. Fix for bug 907254.

Update: IBM from 1928 called, they want their 80 CPL limit
back. - on a more serious note, fixed jenkins PEP8 failure
Update2: Replaced tab by a spaces
Update3: Don't do Foreign Key stuff if the engine is sqlite
Update4: Add myself to the Authors file
Update5: With the correct mail address

Change-Id: Ib021e0ddb2c80ee63888435a9e3761c053534160

subject: fix bug 907125
messages:
[{'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-21 10:01:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm finding it hard to match the changes in the code to the descritpion that this fixes a memory leak.  

Given the number of issues we've seen in SQLalchemy around unexpected lazy loads can you give a better explantion of what this fixes and how please."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-21 13:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Joe, please submit this against the master branch first or, at least, provide an explanation of why the fix isn't required on the master branch

See our policy on the stable branch here: http://wiki.openstack.org/StableBranch

"The branch is intended to be a safe source of fixes for significant issues which have been fixed on master since the release."'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Mark,

I concurrently submitted a patch to master (https://review.openstack.org/2498).  The code base for nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py in master is very different then in stable/diablo, so any patch would be different for each branch.

Phil,
I will give a better explantion of what this fixes and how.  I based my patch on the other two bugs in SQLalchemy around unexpected lazy loads and tested the fix.  I will do a further analysis of the problem.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2011-12-22 02:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

bug is difficult to reproduce in a repeatable fashion since this is a race condition.  While I can reproduce the bug (sometimes) the nature of the bug is making it difficult to pinpoint the cause.

Further details on the bug can be found at https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/907125'}]

fix bug 907125

messages:
[{'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2011-12-21 05:24:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Given the complexity of code in this area, and that this has been a recuring issue over a period of time and appears to be some form of race condition (we found that any change in the code around this areas could appear to make the problem go away), can you provide a more detailed explenation of what conditions lead to the error and why this definatly fixes them.

-1 not beacuse I don't want to see this fixed, but because I want to be sure that it is fixed, and fully understood."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2011-12-22 02:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
fix rebuild sha1 not string error

fixes bug #889164
The sha1() parameter is converted to a string
before calling the funcion.

(cherry picked from commit 17ae2d2662ca9af6eee0cf96fe48d3951593dc6b)

Change-Id: I9cb6ff43c106c214e027d3bdacb795b4b0269f94

Generate instance faults when instance errors

Currently adds all exceptions having to do with a specific instance that are
generated in compute manager to the instance faults table.

Change-Id: Idf92348c6896b0bf0f26d3a0dbd4a48a4c1d4329
