subject: Remove plugin pip-requires.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1, 'name': 'James E. Blair', 'email': 'jim@acmegating.com', 'username': 'corvus'}, {'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 233, 'name': 'Brad Hall', 'email': 'brad@nicira.com', 'username': 'bgh'}, {'_account_id': 490, 'name': 'Sumit Naiksatam', 'email': 'sumitnaiksatam@gmail.com', 'username': 'snaiksat'}, {'_account_id': 704, 'name': 'Edgar Magana', 'email': 'emagana@gmail.com', 'username': 'emagana'}, {'_account_id': 1549, 'name': 'Tyler Smith', 'email': 'tylesmit@cisco.com', 'username': 'tylesmit'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Can we get this pushed in? We haven't had a working venv build for quantum in over a week."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So - pip-requires files are only for and only used by developers for doing local testing in a venv. They are not used by the end user or consumer of the software and are not used to express the depends for that purpose. That information is held in setup.py.

I think we should put the full set of depends needed for running unit tests in the root tools/pip-requires. It's not an imposition for devs, and it has no bearing on installed things.

If ncclient is not needed by the local testing virtualenv, there is no reason for it to be in any of the pip-requires files.

Things that are required for plugins to operate should be in their setup.py file.

I would actually like to revisit the nested-package structure here at some point."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm not sure where ncclient should end up (maybe in a README)? but the rest of it looks fine."}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

For the nested package structure -- I think one of the items we're doing for e3 is going to be breaking out client into a separate repo.  After we do that only the plugins will be nested and we can discuss whether they get their own repo as well.  I'm hoping by the time essex ships we will have a compliant (non-nested) package structure :)"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The ncclient is not required for the tests, however it is required when the nexus plugin is used. Hence, it was put here.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Adding to my earlier comment, what is thought on including plugin-specific dependencies? That is the reason why we put these separate pip-requires. Even if this is not a requirement for the tests today, it could be in the future.'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I dont feel very comfortable with this change as well. The NX-OS driver will completely fail if ncclient is not installed. I second Sumit on his comments, i think we should leave it as it is right now as move it to tools/pip-requires.'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

There is a typo in my previous comment. I wanted to say, that we should leave  it as It is right now or we should move it to tools/pip-requires with the rest of libraries dependencies.'}, {'account_id': 1549, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

If the bug is that the OpenVSwitch pip-requires was re-requiring SQLAlchemy, why do we need to remove the Cisco pip-requires and break the plugin if it's installed (or run) from the source?

If we MUST remove plugin-specific pip-requires, we should at least include all of the dependencies in the main pip-requires since we're distributing the plugins as part of the software itself."}, {'account_id': 1549, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved

We'll move instructions for installing Ncclient to the README for now."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/quantum-pep8/91/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/22/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/quantum/116/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'message': "Remove plugin pip-requires.

Fixes bug 905576.

The cisco plugin included ncclient, but does not use it when testing.
The openvswitch plugin included SQLAlchemy which is already required
by quantum itself.

I've also changed the install_venv.py script to only look at
tools/pip-requires, so that it behaves more like the rest of the
OpenStack projects.  In Jenkins that's the only file we look at
to see if we need to rebuild the virtualenv, so it would be best
if the project only hade one pip-requires.

Also added .gitignore to ignore files created during testing.

Change-Id: Ic460452ec89aa8377c975ca63b57563119860e6b
"}, {'created': '2011-12-21 18:15:19.000000000', 'message': "Remove plugin pip-requires.

Fixes bug 906636.

The cisco plugin included ncclient, but does not use it when testing.
The openvswitch plugin included SQLAlchemy which is already required
by quantum itself.

I've also changed the install_venv.py script to only look at
tools/pip-requires, so that it behaves more like the rest of the
OpenStack projects.  In Jenkins that's the only file we look at
to see if we need to rebuild the virtualenv, so it would be best
if the project only hade one pip-requires.

Also added .gitignore to ignore files created during testing.

Change-Id: Ic460452ec89aa8377c975ca63b57563119860e6b
"}]
commit_message:
Remove plugin pip-requires.

Fixes bug 906636.

The cisco plugin included ncclient, but does not use it when testing.
The openvswitch plugin included SQLAlchemy which is already required
by quantum itself.

I've also changed the install_venv.py script to only look at
tools/pip-requires, so that it behaves more like the rest of the
OpenStack projects.  In Jenkins that's the only file we look at
to see if we need to rebuild the virtualenv, so it would be best
if the project only hade one pip-requires.

Also added .gitignore to ignore files created during testing.

Change-Id: Ic460452ec89aa8377c975ca63b57563119860e6b

commit_message:
Move failed instances to error state

On instance creation there is the possibility of
an instance raising. This would not cause the
instance to be moved to the error state. This
patch fixes that. lp885323

update 1: fixing exception handling
update 2: preserving the individual messages
update 3: rebase on master & fix spacing

(cherry picked from commit c04b431cd63f4d934f40dd1f62a9107ae6dfde90)

Change-Id: I7584b527e408c08014f1b6a8abda343f1e2aa3b8

commit_message:
Explain how replication works more clearly

A replicator creates an extra replica when it detects a remote disk
failure. However, when it fails to create a replica due to other
reasons (e.g. entire node failures), it doesn't create another replica
at all.  We should explain it explicitly so that users can know it.
This fixes bug 906976.

Change-Id: I2f56428ccbbb0cf0d8538ca6e08f7da71257e661

Updates swift docs to use correct release PPA.

Changes swift doc references from defunct ppa repo swift-core/ppa to
new swift-core/release repo.  Fixes lp bug 905608.

subject: Remove unnecessary use of chmod as root
messages:
[{'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:25:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The only caveat with this is that if the sshdir exists with wrong permissions, it now won't be corrected.
Note if we assume there is now existing directory,
then the chown is not longer needed either?

BTW it seems like mkdir -p -m... should warn if existing directories don't have matching permissions.
I'll discuss this upstream."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:33:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh. That's a very good point. Let me abandon that one and think about it a bit more."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2011-12-21 16:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Proposed patch creates a corner case.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-21 15:59:09.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unnecessary use of chmod as root

Reduce exposure by not allowing to run chmod as root, through
the use of the right mkdir options to do the right thing in one
shot. Fixes bug 907396.

Change-Id: I02fa0a4effcd4d668ba1b3751601eff7b91d6f39
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary use of chmod as root

Reduce exposure by not allowing to run chmod as root, through
the use of the right mkdir options to do the right thing in one
shot. Fixes bug 907396.

Change-Id: I02fa0a4effcd4d668ba1b3751601eff7b91d6f39

commit_message:
TempURL and FormPost middleware.

Docs included in swift.common.middleware.tempurl and
swift.common.middleware.formpost

FormPost is getting there. Still want to do more unit tests. Found
quite a few bugs this round.

Change-Id: I94b4fc0de24ab8bbac32d507c6db204eb6594ce7

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-08 15:41:09.000000000', 'message': "Fixes bug 888649

Change exception.VolumeIsBusy to derive from NovaException instead of
Error, so that an 'unexpected keyword' exception is not thrown when
the exception is raised with keyword parameters.

Add unit test to confirm that the 'unexpected keyword' exception is not
thrown when the exception is raised by nova.volume.driver.VolumeDriver

Responded to reviewer observations, fix pep8 errors in tset_volume.py,
added email address to Authors file.

(cherry picked from commit e0ef89f091a77a25fa9bcfd466159e101cb42c56)

Change-Id: I15464cb0cf72a2c71f430e4c8c5c2b27cd4e2ef9
"}, {'created': '2011-12-16 17:21:44.000000000', 'message': 'Backport "Fixes bug 888649" to stable/diablo

Orig Commit Message:

Change exception.VolumeIsBusy to derive from NovaException instead of
Error, so that an 'unexpected keyword' exception is not thrown when
the exception is raised with keyword parameters.

Add unit test to confirm that the 'unexpected keyword' exception is not
thrown when the exception is raised by nova.volume.driver.VolumeDriver

Conflicts:

	nova/tests/test_volume.py

Cc: stable-maintainers
Change-Id: I15464cb0cf72a2c71f430e4c8c5c2b27cd4e2ef9
'}, {'created': '2011-12-16 17:27:21.000000000', 'message': "Fixes bug 888649

Change exception.VolumeIsBusy to derive from NovaException instead of
Error, so that an 'unexpected keyword' exception is not thrown when
the exception is raised with keyword parameters.

Add unit test to confirm that the 'unexpected keyword' exception is not
thrown when the exception is raised by nova.volume.driver.VolumeDriver

Responded to reviewer observations, fix pep8 errors in tset_volume.py,
added email address to Authors file.

(cherry picked from commit e0ef89f091a77a25fa9bcfd466159e101cb42c56)

Change-Id: I15464cb0cf72a2c71f430e4c8c5c2b27cd4e2ef9
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes bug 888649

Change exception.VolumeIsBusy to derive from NovaException instead of
Error, so that an 'unexpected keyword' exception is not thrown when
the exception is raised with keyword parameters.

Add unit test to confirm that the 'unexpected keyword' exception is not
thrown when the exception is raised by nova.volume.driver.VolumeDriver

Responded to reviewer observations, fix pep8 errors in tset_volume.py,
added email address to Authors file.

(cherry picked from commit e0ef89f091a77a25fa9bcfd466159e101cb42c56)

Change-Id: I15464cb0cf72a2c71f430e4c8c5c2b27cd4e2ef9

The API documentation states that the Location header should be filled
with the URL of the server. This change implemnts this for both the
create and rebuild actions.

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-20 20:35:21.000000000', 'message': 'Consistently use REBUILDING vm_state

There is both a vm_state and task_state called REBUILDING, which was
used inconsistently. This resulted in a rebuild action returning
"ACTIVE" for the status instead of "REBUILD" like the API
documentation states.

This change drops the task_state in favor of making all of the code
use vm_state

Change-Id: I56b4b6fd4d02b75c6270fc91cdec1902e7794cf1
'}]
commit_message:
Consistently use REBUILDING vm_state

There is both a vm_state and task_state called REBUILDING, which was
used inconsistently. This resulted in a rebuild action returning
"ACTIVE" for the status instead of "REBUILD" like the API
documentation states.

This change drops the task_state in favor of making all of the code
use vm_state

Change-Id: I56b4b6fd4d02b75c6270fc91cdec1902e7794cf1

commit_message:
Fixes the catalog return in d5_compat calls.

The service catalog previously returned by the middleware was identical to
diablo return value.

d5 uses service types as dictionary keys to index the service catalog, which
return a list of endpoint dictionaries.

Change-Id: I80ca604a4e65fd5838bb8242d655eb692e3cbe03

commit_message:
Make UUID format checking more correct.

This patch uses the same logic from glance to verify if a UUID is
properly formed.  It just tries to build a uuid.UUID from the string.
A test case has been added which previously would have failed, but now
passes.

A second test case has been added that verifies that the result of the
gen_uuid() function is considered valid, as well.

Change-Id: I33fe37b23ef03eda0f0e9d69afb601ca260aabde

commit_message:
Add 'discover' command for Keystone discovery and version listing

Added @unauthenticated decorator to mark subcommands that do not
need authentication. And checks to skip authentication for these
commands.
Added novaclient.keystone to setup.py

Change-Id: Id2fd60af305c30a950bdbae8f897192bfae4d797

messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-15 06:58:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(5 inline comments)

I'm starting to -2 things with obvious problems.  No offense.

Minor things inline.  Further information about my simple_tenant_usage.py comment where we have context.is_admin() checks:

From what I can tell, we have bugs when admin_api is enabled right now... in that we would allow normal users to do things like 'pause', etc.  I see absolutely no context.is_admin checks in admin_actions, for instance, although they exist in simple_tenant_usage.  That may be the only place they exist.

Should we remove the current context.is_admin checks from the admin extensions and figure out a way to specify this at a higher level?  Maybe it's an argument to find_factory() that gets passed to extension __init__()s?  There'd be a number of __init__ methods to change... and it feels somewhat hacky (hmm.. somewhat), so I don't know about it.  Just one idea.

Adding context.is_admin() checks to every single method in the admin extensions seems kinda redundant and someone could easily miss it when adding something in the future."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-15 14:10:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-15 14:10:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-20 16:53:30.000000000', 'message': "Bug#898257 support handling images with libguestfs

http://libguestfs.org/ provides both utilities and libraries
to manipulate image files containing various operating systems.
It supports various image file formats and so will expand
the formats and guest types supported by openstack.
It does have extra overhead in that it starts a VM to
access the image. This has both advantages and disadvantages.
Also qemu-nbd is not supported on some systems like RHEL 6.

* nova/virt/disk/base.py (img_handlers): Add guestfs to the default
list of access methods to try, to act as a fallback.
* nova/virt/disk/guestfs.py: A new plugin class to provide support
for libguestfs mounting.
Note we use the guestmount utility, as a non root user,
so the user will need the ability to use fusermount, which
is often provided by being a member of the 'fuser' group.
In future we might use the guestfs python module to give
greater granularity of control over the image.

Change-Id: I2e22c9d149fff7a73cd8cebaa280d68d3fb9096c
"}]
commit_message:
Bug#898257 support handling images with libguestfs

http://libguestfs.org/ provides both utilities and libraries
to manipulate image files containing various operating systems.
It supports various image file formats and so will expand
the formats and guest types supported by openstack.
It does have extra overhead in that it starts a VM to
access the image. This has both advantages and disadvantages.
Also qemu-nbd is not supported on some systems like RHEL 6.

* nova/virt/disk/base.py (img_handlers): Add guestfs to the default
list of access methods to try, to act as a fallback.
* nova/virt/disk/guestfs.py: A new plugin class to provide support
for libguestfs mounting.
Note we use the guestmount utility, as a non root user,
so the user will need the ability to use fusermount, which
is often provided by being a member of the 'fuser' group.
In future we might use the guestfs python module to give
greater granularity of control over the image.

Change-Id: I2e22c9d149fff7a73cd8cebaa280d68d3fb9096c

subject: Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods
messages: [{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2011-12-20 17:01:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nI sent this against the diablo branch in error'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-20 16:53:25.000000000', 'message': "Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods

Rather than providing two mutually exlusive image
access methods (loop and qemu-nbd), try each in turn.
This is to prepare for a follow up patch which will
add libguestfs as a method to try.

* nova/virt/mount.py: A new Mount class to abstract the
devce allocation, partition mapping and file sys mounting,
for each access type.
* nova/virt/disk/loop.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide loop back mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/nbd.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide qemu-nbd mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/api.py: A new file containing the nova.virt.disk
module interface.
(img_handlers): A new list of access methods to try,
with the order being honored.
(_DiskImage): An internal helper class that uses the plugin classes
above, to provide the operations available on a disk image file.
When mounting, iterate over each access method until one succeeds.
If a hint is provided about a CoW format image, the list of
methods to try will be reduced accordingly.
Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, errors are collated and raised.
Interveining errors are logged in debug mode for successful mounts.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.
* nova/utils.py (trycmd): A helper function to both deal with,
commands that issue ignorable warnings to stderr,
and commands that EXIT_SUCCESS while issuing errors to stderr.
nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py: Adjust for the moved virt.disk package

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7
"}]
commit_message:
Bug#898257 abstract out disk image access methods

Rather than providing two mutually exlusive image
access methods (loop and qemu-nbd), try each in turn.
This is to prepare for a follow up patch which will
add libguestfs as a method to try.

* nova/virt/mount.py: A new Mount class to abstract the
devce allocation, partition mapping and file sys mounting,
for each access type.
* nova/virt/disk/loop.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide loop back mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/nbd.py: A specialization of the base Mount class
to provide qemu-nbd mounting support.
* nova/virt/disk/api.py: A new file containing the nova.virt.disk
module interface.
(img_handlers): A new list of access methods to try,
with the order being honored.
(_DiskImage): An internal helper class that uses the plugin classes
above, to provide the operations available on a disk image file.
When mounting, iterate over each access method until one succeeds.
If a hint is provided about a CoW format image, the list of
methods to try will be reduced accordingly.
Note expected errors are no longer raised as exceptions during mounting.
Instead, on failure to mount an image, errors are collated and raised.
Interveining errors are logged in debug mode for successful mounts.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Adjust the function parameter
names to be more general, rather than referencing specific
implementations like 'nbd' and 'tune2fs'.
Simplify the destroy_container() by storing and passing
back a reference to the _DiskImage object, which has the
necessary state to unmount.
* nova/utils.py (trycmd): A helper function to both deal with,
commands that issue ignorable warnings to stderr,
and commands that EXIT_SUCCESS while issuing errors to stderr.
nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py: Adjust for the moved virt.disk package

Change-Id: If3a4b1c8f4e2f2e7300a21071340dcc839cb36d7

subject: Add a console output action to servers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 112, 'name': 'Jesse Andrews', 'email': 'anotherjesse@gmail.com', 'username': 'anotherjesse'}, {'_account_id': 357, 'name': 'Devin Carlen', 'email': 'devin@openstack.org', 'username': 'devcamcar'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}, {'_account_id': 1155, 'name': 'sleepsonthefloor', 'username': 'sleepsonthefloor'}, {'_account_id': 1205, 'name': 'Jake Dahn', 'email': 'jake.dahn@nebula.com', 'username': 'jakedahn'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-10-25 14:45:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Would it make more sense to put this in a more generic consoles extension? The existing consoles controller needs to be converted into a true extension anyways, so do you think you could do it as part of this blueprint?'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-10-26 19:44:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Heyo,

So we're going to take a more complete look at the current consoles api stuff and put some thought into improving/generalizing what is currently there. I think the current stuff is xen specific but should be generalized.

A few other blueprints which pertain are: 
  - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vnc-console-cleanup
  - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/xenapi-text-console-support

It also looks the ajaxterm and vnc methods have been removed from the servers.py, so we'll look into pulling those items into a general/overall consoles api.

Are there any other items you can think of which need to be added/improved/thought about?"}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-10-26 19:45:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

repost of links: 


A few other blueprints which pertain are: 

* https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vnc-console-cleanup
* https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/xenapi-text-console-support'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-10-26 20:12:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That sounds awesome. Feel free to generalize the extensions you already have and get that in sooner rather than later if it's something you need."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-10-31 18:39:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

This will need updating now that the extension refactoring has landed

Also, what would you think of a blueprint to move the length argument down to the level where we actually *get* the console output? I'd prefer we don't potentially pass around giant blobs of console output through the message queues that we're mostly going to throw away"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-11-18 17:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me - I can understand that it could be further optimised and/or merged into a more general console extension - but there is an urgent need to plug this gap compared to EC2.

I'd also like to see this backported to Diablo.Stable"}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-11-29 18:10:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Phil,

If you are urgently in need of this, I recommend just taking the code and applying it as a patch for now.

I'm still thinking about the generalization/refactor of the console stuff, and I don't think we want to get locked into an interface that is not desirable for the future.

Abandoning this review, as it should have been back in october."}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2011-12-06 21:38:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've spent some time looking at vnc and text consoles, and am now of the opinion that the console log is a different beast, and should be kept separate from interactive consoles.  Although they sound related, interactive consoles are generally streaming services, versus one-off requests for data.  

Although one could envision console-log as a streaming services, I'd push that off for now.  So perhaps re-open this request?"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-08 19:45:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That is a good point you bring up. I'd be fine adding this as an extension with the understanding that it won't be used as the basis for a more complete consoles api. 

What do you think, Jake? Looking over the code again, there are a few changes you'd need to make. We can talk offline to get those fixed."}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 21:34:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Restored

Everyone's opinion has changed, bringing this back."}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 21:34:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 21:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:02:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-08 22:17:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Just a few things."}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1205, 'date': '2011-12-08 23:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-09 13:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ok, the community has spoken :) The code looks good and it passes smokestack.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2011-12-09 21:46:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'm still concerned about passing around a large blob of text that we're going to truncate at the API. Any way to push the length argument down?"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-10 20:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

jake is going to take a look at sending truncate info all the way down'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-19 21:46:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-19 21:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Add a console output action to servers

Relates to blueprint osapi-console-log and bug 876809. Adds equivalent
of euca-get-console-output to openstack api as an extension.

Change-Id: Ia71361ebbec820616a3007e216b0b9ff98d43541

Added: ./keystone-manage database goto <version>

- Jumps to a given version without performing migrations
- Analog of `UPDATE migrate_version SET version=<version>;`

Change-Id: I682d3c2d83b22bcd30e672a11a35c8804dd5a1ea

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-19 16:05:06.000000000', 'message': "Contract fix: change IDs from xsd:ID to xsd:string

- xsd:ID cannot contain the ':' character. It also can't start
  with a digit a hyphen or a period. xsd:string is more approriate
  to allow integer IDs to be presented as string.

Change-Id: I4a761e8ebaaf18981c5e42a6f0e042f94b0e6035
"}]
commit_message:
Contract fix: change IDs from xsd:ID to xsd:string

- xsd:ID cannot contain the ':' character. It also can't start
  with a digit a hyphen or a period. xsd:string is more approriate
  to allow integer IDs to be presented as string.

Change-Id: I4a761e8ebaaf18981c5e42a6f0e042f94b0e6035

subject: Don't start the metadata service if the metadata_port is set to zero
messages:
[{'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 05:33:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-19 11:05:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-19 14:51:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-19 15:27:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-19 15:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark: Fixed pep8 violation (that'll teach me to merge manually!)

Julien: A zero/empty value for the host could well mean "listen on all", like a 0.0.0.0 listen value.  A zero value is invalid as a port though.  The intention here is to allow the metadata service to be disabled, rather than trying to protect against invalid input.  I think the correct thing would be to interpret an empty host as the wildcard, but that's a different patch!'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-19 15:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 357, 'date': '2011-12-19 18:41:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not submit

Hey Justin, this change is not required as there is already an official way to disable the metadata service (or any api endpoint):

From nova/flags.py:

DEFINE_list('enabled_apis', ['ec2', 'osapi', 'metadata'],
            'list of APIs to enable by default')"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-19 19:56:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

alternatively you can also start the individual apis, instead of running them combined in one process with:
nova-api-os
nova-api-ec2
nova-api-metadata'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-19 21:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Cool - thanks guys... both are much cleaner options!'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2011-12-19 21:47:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-19 03:47:53.000000000', 'message': "Don't start the metadata service if the metadata_port is set to zero

The compute metadata service relies on Linux iptables (so requires root permissions); it might not be useful for all installations (as it's an EC2 artifact).  Make this optional.

Change-Id: I01a25201ec720a5056efd29a553223a25914e708
"}, {'created': '2011-12-19 15:27:49.000000000', 'message': "Don't start the metadata service if the metadata_port is set to zero

The compute metadata service relies on Linux iptables (so requires root permissions); it might not be useful for all installations (as it's an EC2 artifact).  Make this optional.

Change-Id: I01a25201ec720a5056efd29a553223a25914e708
"}]
commit_message:
Don't start the metadata service if the metadata_port is set to zero

The compute metadata service relies on Linux iptables (so requires root permissions); it might not be useful for all installations (as it's an EC2 artifact).  Make this optional.

Change-Id: I01a25201ec720a5056efd29a553223a25914e708

commit_message:
Do no depends on argparse for Python >= 2.7

Python >= 2.7 has argparse has a builtin module, so there's no need to add
it to the this list of requirements.

Change-Id: I647cec70a564b1d184f0cb2aca6caf4d6478c403
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

commit_message:
Support for unscoped admin tokens

- Fixes bug 887877
- Updates to sampledata to not scope admin/serviceadmin tokens to customer-x
- Fix 'undocumented' bug in keystone-manage that fails to handle 'None' correctly for tenant

Change-Id: Iaa7f8897c79ca5e4811d1f15a1b307ae1313b656

subject: Contract fix: IDs are not Ints, they are ID or string types
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2011-12-17 20:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ziad - why are we making this a UUID?'}, {'account_id': 5, 'date': '2011-12-17 21:57:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We're not making this a UUID (at least not in the API spec).

See here for the reasoning of why did this:
- we add a string UID to the database schema
- For deployments with the integer ID, we copy that into the UID field
- For deployments where the ID is a string (cactus and before Diablo) we copy that into the UID field
- We use the UID field in the URL

That will allow migrations into Keystone and you can decide in your data import what value to make the ID that shows up as the REST URL.

For new entries, UUID was the easiest way to generate uniqueness, but we can make it anything else."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2011-12-19 13:22:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-19 13:29:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful

commit_message:
Specify -t rsa when calling ssh-keygen.

Some operating systems (e.g. Illumos) don't default to RSA.  Probably safer to specify it anyway, even on Linux where it defaults.

Change-Id: I6f1364e6ff79a9c9a38007611b8df3af1b2dc645

commit_message:
Fixes deprecated attribute access.

Fixes bug 898510

I did a hasattr check whenever the code tries to access
the message attribute of a BaseException.

Since openstackx, glance, and quantum implements their exceptions
with a message attribute, I thought keeping the message attribute access
was logical.

Change-Id: Iabe986359077d11bb4bdae15f9e7d6db2aecdbb0

subject: First commit "deleting-compute-node-table"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 321, 'name': 'Lorin Hochstein', 'email': 'lorinh@gmail.com', 'username': 'lorinh'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1075, 'name': 'Kei Masumoto', 'username': 'masumotok'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-11-28 14:11:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Kei,

I'm seeing a couple unit test failures with this branch:

IntegrityError: (IntegrityError) column name is not unique u'INSERT INTO instance_types

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3536/"}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2011-11-28 14:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

From the Essex design summit, I remember Sandy mentioned that we were planning on moving from using periodic host capability updates to using the database for updating the scheduler on the state of the compute nodes.  

Is removing the compute_nodes table being done in coordination with this plan?

(Added Sandy as a reviewer on this).'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-01 10:53:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2011-12-01 11:34:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

What's the relationship between this change and these changes?

    https://review.openstack.org/#change,2004

    https://review.openstack.org/#change,2003"}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-01 11:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not submit

Sorry, the compute node table is definitely back in use again. We found that the periodic updates were not fast enough when the scheduler was busy and need to use the compute node tables (for now anyway)

I think we can re-evaluate this branch after we perform the work outlined here:
http://wiki.openstack.org/EssexSchedulerImprovements'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-01 14:30:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Kei, re: your email:

Q1. Can you tell me a branch URL of
<http://wiki.openstack.org/EssexSchedulerImprovements>? I would like to
see what is going on in detail.

There isn't one yet, we just came up with the plan last week. Starting coding now.

Q2. When your branch will be merged? Essex2 or Essex3? I would like to
make new plan following your schedule.

Ideally some branches should be for Essex2 but might spill over into 3.

Q3. Compute node table colums will be dynamically changed? If compute
node tables is used from now on, table colums are very important.

No, no plans to change the table columns. We're going to make a new CapacityCache table which will replace our use of ComputeNode, but I think other schedulers may be using ComputeNode too."}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-01 22:54:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Sandy, 

Can I ask you little more? Originally, this BP aims 2 purpose.
1) Following existing implementation of scheduelr(i.e. compute sends its capability to scheduler)
2) Fixing improperly memory calculation in scheduler(ex. nova.scheduler.driver.has_enough_memory). 
Regarding to 1) above, I understand I won't make it. now I am thinking whether I can perform 2) above or not. 

Q4: What is the relationship between CapacityCache table and ComputeNodes table? the contents of Column is different or CapacityCache is just a cache of ComputeNode table?

Q5: Updating those table has been done through notification mechanism, Correct? In other words, those table are only updated only some event(lauching/terminating instances etc.) occurs."}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-13 07:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-13 08:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-13 14:43:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Can I ask you little more? 

Sure, answers inline ...

> Originally, this BP aims 2 purpose. 
> 1) Following existing implementation of scheduelr(i.e. compute sends its capability to scheduler) 
> 2) Fixing improperly memory calculation in scheduler(ex. nova.scheduler.driver.has_enough_memory). 
> Regarding to 1) above, I understand I won't make it. now I am thinking whether I can perform 2) above or not.


The branch I'm working on is here which is intended to solve problem #2
https://github.com/SandyWalsh/nova/tree/capacity_cache

> Q4: What is the relationship between CapacityCache table and ComputeNodes table? the contents of Column is different or CapacityCache is just a cache of ComputeNode table?

The ComputeNode table contains a row for each ComputeNode running in a deployment. Capacity (formerly CapacityCache) contains the available capacity of each host in a deployment. Previously it was 1 row per InstanceType per Host, but that has changed. So, now that you mention it, perhaps we can merge these two tables?

> Q5: Updating those table has been done through notification mechanism, Correct? In other words, those table are only updated only some event(lauching/terminating instances etc.) occurs.

Correct, though it's also updated in the scheduler when an allocation is made. We may have to initialize the row when the Compute Node starts to prevent getting out of sync with reality (such as when an operation fails)"}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-14 11:10:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hello Sandy, thanks for your reply!

I read your branch, Your work looks like nova.notifier.notify() can be called from everywhere in compute manager, and notify() try to insert values into DB. Your work is almost done?

If so, my patchset 4 in this MP is already 99% following your work. Therefore, I would like to make forward this patch as other MP, and I will fix to follow your work later (I am expecting total amount of fix is withiin 50 lines, then.)

 I am thinking above because I just want to have many chances to get reviewed ^^; so if there still be any inconvenience for you, please let me know.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-19 04:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Withdraw proposal'}]

commit_message:
Fixed how to add how to endpoints.

The documentation on how to set up endpoints was incorrect. In particular:
- When endpoint templates are global, you don't need to manually add endpoints,
but the docs had the user add endpoints anyways.

- The syntax for adding endpoints was incorrect, the second argument is an
endpoint template id, not a string.

Change-Id: Icdd1076f30cb254b5992e488d647fd769636ba13

Boris,

Thanks for this! However, it looks like the fix for this bug might have already made it to master. Did you mean to submit this change to a different branch?

I suppose even if you did it might be better for the different branch to cherrypick the fix from master.

Just for context, currently in master the function looks like:

 452     def _prep_block_device(self, context, instance):
 453         """Set up the block device for an instance with error logging"""
 454         self._instance_update(context, instance['uuid'],
 455                               vm_state=vm_states.BUILDING,
 456                               task_state=task_states.BLOCK_DEVICE_MAPPING)
 457         try:
 458             mapping = self._setup_block_device_mapping(context, instance)
 459             swap, ephemerals, block_device_mapping = mapping
 460         except:
 461             msg = _("Instance %s failed block device setup")
 462             LOG.exception(msg % instance['uuid'])
 463             raise
 464         return {'root_device_name': instance['root_device_name'],
 465                 'swap': swap,
 466                 'ephemerals': ephemerals,
 467                 'block_device_mapping': block_device_mapping}'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:20:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

agree with mark, looks like you were beat to it. I made a comment in case you proceed."}, {'account_id': 1904, 'date': '2011-12-17 22:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Already fixed'}]

subject: Acknowledge rpc messages after they are completed.
messages: [{'account_id': 616, 'date': '2011-12-17 06:44:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nWhoops! Accidentally pushed a changeset for a different change proposal with a new change id. Abandoning this one.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-17 06:40:43.000000000', 'message': 'Acknowledge rpc messages after they are completed.

This change causes rpc messages to be acknowledged only after they
are processed rather than eagerly. The idea is that the messages are
not acknowledged during a shutdown.

This is not necessarily the ultimate model we should adopt for rpc.
For instance we really need to think about requeueing and retrying
messages that fail. But it is a step in the right direction that
makes it possible to accept an rpc message without necessarily
starting to process it immediately (as in the case where you need to
wait on acquiring a lock).

Change-Id: I72c95c6f0e928cd29cd96f1f8879b724b63288c2
'}]
commit_message:
Acknowledge rpc messages after they are completed.

This change causes rpc messages to be acknowledged only after they
are processed rather than eagerly. The idea is that the messages are
not acknowledged during a shutdown.

This is not necessarily the ultimate model we should adopt for rpc.
For instance we really need to think about requeueing and retrying
messages that fail. But it is a step in the right direction that
makes it possible to accept an rpc message without necessarily
starting to process it immediately (as in the case where you need to
wait on acquiring a lock).

Change-Id: I72c95c6f0e928cd29cd96f1f8879b724b63288c2

commit_message:
avoid error and trace on dom.vcpus() in lxc

This fixes bug 903943.  If you used lxc, you'd eventually
see stack traces in nova-compute due to use of dom.vcpus().

Change-Id: I8ff4e973d33eef3df116feb237b2febc8e6a59b5

subject: Added jquery and js on load to autoselect Bug #897066
messages:
[{'account_id': 494, 'date': '2011-12-06 18:38:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

a couple style bits look a little unusual to me"}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2011-12-06 18:48:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Seconded on Termie's style notes, also this could be abstracted to a more generally useful bit of javascript that focuses the first form field on any page. Something like:

$('input:visible:first').focus()

Then it could live in the main javascript file.

I don't love inline javascript in templates on a general basis."}, {'account_id': 543, 'date': '2011-12-06 18:59:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In response to focusing on the first form element: there is really no way to do that reliably that doesn't, on occasion, end up moving the cursor while the user is trying to do something else. If you set the focus when the javascript parses you must do this inline right after the input element is defined (which is messy) or if you wait for $(document).ready() then you increase the chances that the user has already hit the tab key to move to another field (or taken some other action that will be interrupted by the re-focus).

The best option is to make sure the tab order of the fields is correct and let the user tab in to the first field."}, {'account_id': 2135, 'date': '2011-12-16 21:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-06 06:59:10.000000000', 'message': 'Added jquery and js on load to autoselect
Bug #897066

Change-Id: Iec330e46bd40515e34e542f826569fc7d4a27e70
'}]

subject: Pull resource extensions into APIRouter
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1132, 'name': 'Brian Waldon', 'email': 'brian@waldon.cc', 'username': 'bcwaldon'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 22:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Kevin, could you explain what the benefit of this is? What problem is this solving?

Thanks,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-15 23:23:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I realized after I had hit "git review" that, although I had updated the commit message, it was still a bit confusing :)  This is the first part of removing extensions middleware, and, by extension, lazy serialization middleware.  The goal is to move extensions into the API itself, and doing so solves some problems—not the least of which is the ugly hack I had to use to get lazy serializations working in the first place.  (Lazy serializations are required because we also have *request* extensions, which wrap an already-existing resource from within the extensions middleware.)  Without this refactoring, there are limitations on at least action extensions that block other stories...'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-16 14:04:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So I'm still curious how making the ExtensionManager a singleton relates."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-16 14:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In order to look up the resource extensions (for now) or request or action extensions (in future), it is necessary to have access to the extension manager.  The only reference to it currently is stored in the ExtensionMiddleware.  Since we're not doing away with the ExtensionMiddleware in this patch, and since the APIRouter needs access to the ExtensionManager, we need to ensure that we have the same object for both.  I believe the easiest way to accommodate this is to turn it into a singleton.

(By the way, I should have—and may still—updated the summary to say "move resource extension setup into APIRouter.)'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-16 17:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-16 18:46:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

OK, understood. lgtm. Thanks for the followup explanation.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-16 19:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2011-12-16 19:59:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Don't really know much about the extension mechanism, but seems fine to me. A little weeping over the Singleton though."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/292/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2055/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/680/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-16 20:04:57.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Pull resource extensions into APIRouter

First step in refactoring extensions to do away with the extensions
middleware, which is needed to get rid of the lazy serialization
middleware.  Converts ExtensionManager into a singleton to inhibit
double-loading of extensions.

Change-Id: Ia561d601df1a8c72c734c9426270268c1be13c3e

commit_message:
Format keystone-manage output better

This makes the output of keystone-manage list commands much
prettier:
$ ./keystone-manage tenant list
---------------------------------------------------------------
| Tenants                                                     |
---------------------------------------------------------------
| id                               | name           | enabled |
---------------------------------------------------------------
| e028069d28a5440c9028aa1c5111cef6 | customer-x     | True    |
| 01ad238f97a648709e68f3148b157f88 | ANOTHER:TENANT | True    |
| 67ce3d68bc49427abed2c409a2213b3c | project-y      | False   |
---------------------------------------------------------------
It also starts a unit test to test keystone-manage.

Change-Id: I0e679795d6050ed401609fce3de0c16e234d21da

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 91, 'name': 'Alvaro', 'email': 'aloga@ifca.unican.es', 'username': 'aloga'}, {'_account_id': 209, 'name': 'Josh Kearney', 'email': 'josh@jk0.org', 'username': 'jk0'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 518, 'name': 'Soren Hansen', 'email': 'soren@linux2go.dk', 'username': 'soren'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 706, 'name': 'Brian Lamar', 'email': 'brian.lamar@rackspace.com', 'username': 'blamar'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1419, 'name': 'Mike Pittaro', 'email': 'mikeyp@LaHondaResearch.org', 'username': 'mikeyp-3'}, {'_account_id': 1669, 'name': 'Julien Danjou', 'display_name': 'jd', 'email': 'julien@danjou.info', 'username': 'jdanjou'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:50:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Looks good; inline comment has a thought I'd like you to follow up on, though."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:57:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2011-12-05 21:52:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I don't see any problems in the code"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-06 11:44:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Not keen on this kind of flag proliferation. How about we just add a --debug flag?"}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2011-12-07 09:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Rick, for me it is OK. Personally, we prefer to always reload the file if it has been modified, but I do not know if that is the desired behavior in a production environment.

Mark, what about a "--libvirt-debug" or something similar ("--debug" seems to general for me)?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-07 11:30:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You know, maybe the right thing here is just to load the template each time we launch an instance

I don't see any particular reason to cache the template - if it was intentional, it seems a little like premature optimization to me. It's hardly the most expensive or error prone part of launching an instance?

Soren - can you remember why you did this?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-07 15:49:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Clearly the current behaviour is bad (caching without checking mtime) but this fix is not correct indeed.

The template should be loaded each time and IF it is cached, then the mtime should be used as reference."}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:19:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've a fix ready for the mtime issue, but I'd like to know which is the desired behavior for the template (re)loading before submitting the change.

 - Case 1: The templates are loaded only once when nova-compute is started (as they are now). There should be any extra flag(s) to switch to case (2), as said in the bug/wishlist report.

 - Case 2: The templates are cached when nova-compute starts and if the mtimes  differ when an instance is created, they are reloaded from disk."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-07 17:23:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Personally, I favor option 2; I see this as a long-running process, so there should be a way to reload the template files if necessary, yet we should still be efficient about doing so.'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2011-12-07 18:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

+1 on Kevin'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-07 21:19:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm 99% sure it wasn't intentional to make these templates 'cached'. My vote is for just making a property out of the XML variables and reading them *every* time. We can add a flag later if someone is booting so many instances that it's detrimental."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:07:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

"I'm 99% sure it wasn't intentional to make these templates 'cached'. My vote is for just making a property out of the XML variables and reading them *every* time. We can add a flag later if someone is booting so many instances that it's detrimental."

Agreed, loading every time seems fine for now.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-07 22:09:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

'}, {'account_id': 91, 'date': '2011-12-09 09:55:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-09 16:20:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Fixes bug 723235

The XML templates have been converted into properties, thus we can
compare the mtime of the XML templates (libvirt and cpuinfo) each
time they are needed, checking if they have been modified and
reloading them. Added a function to read cached files.

Change-Id: I6cf0229c6435300e73f9d9a6b10b0bf9bf144a55

not exist.  Added the proper code for it to determine whether the
instance was actually created in the DB or not and how to find its ID.

Note: there's some pretty nasty stuff in here, but unavoidable without
larger changes.  I'd like to hold off on these larger changes, because
the problem should be solved with some of the scalability work coming.

Tests included.

Change-Id: Ief5fde8128437c9dc257af9c4d0c2950d0962ce5
"}]
commit_message:
Fix scheduler error handler

Fixes bug 904971

Scheduler error handler was looking for instance_id when it may or may
not exist.  Added the proper code for it to determine whether the
instance was actually created in the DB or not and how to find its ID.

Note: there's some pretty nasty stuff in here, but unavoidable without
larger changes.  I'd like to hold off on these larger changes, because
the problem should be solved with some of the scalability work coming.

Tests included.

Change-Id: Ief5fde8128437c9dc257af9c4d0c2950d0962ce5

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 22:55:12.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure fkey is dropped before removing instance_id

This fixes Bug #904888

On MySQL databases that use InnoDB by default (ie, at the point when
database is being first migrated), extra care needs to be taken to
ensure FKs are dropped before columns because they are not automatically.

Patch from Adam Gandelman and Scott Moser.

Change-Id: I32919a46bb76f524e064098738ad98248b2f1c0e
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure fkey is dropped before removing instance_id

This fixes Bug #904888

On MySQL databases that use InnoDB by default (ie, at the point when
database is being first migrated), extra care needs to be taken to
ensure FKs are dropped before columns because they are not automatically.

Patch from Adam Gandelman and Scott Moser.

Change-Id: I32919a46bb76f524e064098738ad98248b2f1c0e

subject: Use iputils-arping package for Ubuntu Oneiric distribution
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-06 23:09:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm

Sounds like it might be good to propose this as a fix to the ubuntu packages as well (if they haven't been switched already)."}, {'account_id': 1981, 'date': '2011-12-07 03:43:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As it turns out Ubuntu already handles this.  By default the system installs `iputils-apring' along with `network-manager'.  In fact, when you install `arping' the system removes both `iputils-arping' and `network-manager'."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2011-12-15 18:13:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good catch.  We normally don't run network-manager installed anywhere."}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-16 00:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-16 00:03:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-devstack-merge/37/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-16 00:03:45.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-06 19:11:34.000000000', 'message': "Use iputils-arping package for Ubuntu Oneiric distribution

Turns out the `arping' package, currently installed by the script,
is incompatible with `network-manager', the default network configuration
package for recent Ubuntu distributions.  (Losing network connectivity
on a reboot after running `stack.sh' is a little disconcerting.)
Forturnately, the `iputils-apring' package provides the same functionality
and is compatible with `network-manager' so install that one instead.

Change-Id: Id6e89cdf3e590481f870127697baa453b34fbc24
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Use iputils-arping package for Ubuntu Oneiric distribution

Turns out the `arping' package, currently installed by the script,
is incompatible with `network-manager', the default network configuration
package for recent Ubuntu distributions.  (Losing network connectivity
on a reboot after running `stack.sh' is a little disconcerting.)
Forturnately, the `iputils-apring' package provides the same functionality
and is compatible with `network-manager' so install that one instead.

Change-Id: Id6e89cdf3e590481f870127697baa453b34fbc24
Signed-off-by: Don Dugger <donald.d.dugger@intel.com>

database is being first migrated), extra care needs to be taken to

Change-Id: I32919a46bb76f524e064098738ad98248b2f1c0e
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure fkey is dropped before removing instance_id

This fixes Bug #904888

On MySQL databases that use InnoDB by default (ie, at the point when
database is being first migrated), extra care needs to be taken to
ensure FKs are dropped before columns because they are not automatically.

Patch from Adam Gandelman and Scott Moser.

Change-Id: I32919a46bb76f524e064098738ad98248b2f1c0e

subject: Refactor vm_state and task_state checking
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-13 23:49:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:26:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

looks good. waiting on a result from smokestack to approve.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approved

Nice Refactor'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:45:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/252/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2016/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/641/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2011-12-14 00:45:58.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 14:57:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So... one of the things I liked about the previous branch was that it was easy to see the state transition map for expected/allowed VM states and a server action. With this patch, in order to see that state transition map, I have to scroll through the methods in the compute API and look at the params for all the decorators to divine that information.

Just sayin.. :) It might be good to add to the docstrings in the api module that state transition map so there is a single easy place to see that information.

Cheers!
jay'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 15:45:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

One of the things I disliked about the previous patch was how I had to go searching in a different file to figure out what was allowed/disallowed for a particular method. (So yeah, the complete opposite of what you want)

It also lent itself to forgetting about certain methods. For instance, a decorator was added for delete(), but no blocked states were added to state_checker.py, so it allowed everything.

What you're looking for might be better served with a tool to parse the .py file to obtain the information."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 20:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Really? A tool to parse the .py file looking for decorators?

I suggested adding the state transition table to the docstrings in the .py file. Why is that such a terrible suggestion?

-jay'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I wouldn't call it "terrible", but it does duplicate what's in the code into the documentation. It leaves it vulnerable to becoming out-of-sync and misleading. (DRY)'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:38:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Frankly, that's the case with all manner of documentation.  I have to agree with Jay here; documenting the state transitions isn't a terrible thing"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:41:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Isn't the API the appropriate documentation?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:54:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Isn't the documentation the appropriate documentation? ;)"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2011-12-15 13:26:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I wanted to chip in here with a couple of points as the author of the original blueprint:

I don't have a problem with the refactor as such (I think what Johannes did is quite elegent and I can see its easlier for programmers), but I do agree with Jay that losing track of what actions are allowed based on the current state is a problem (as the users of the system will need that view).   Maybe we should extend the returned message to let the user know what the valid states are - much more helpful that just saying that they can't do what they're trying to. 

My second point is that it would have been nice / helpful if the review had remained open for tad longer (esp as it was on something that had only recently been submitted) to let the orginators express an opinion ?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-15 21:24:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The authoritative source for what actions are allowed in what situations should be the API documentation. Users shouldn't need to look at code to figure it out."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-13 23:39:30.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor vm_state and task_state checking

This branch refactors the recently merged code for checking vm_state and
task_state. The list of allowed states is merged to the method being
checked, more methods are being checked and cleans up the general usage
of them to be easier to read.

Change-Id: If6130dbab947f7bd037e37af9827b6a7c9a193d4
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor vm_state and task_state checking

This branch refactors the recently merged code for checking vm_state and
task_state. The list of allowed states is merged to the method being
checked, more methods are being checked and cleans up the general usage
of them to be easier to read.

Change-Id: If6130dbab947f7bd037e37af9827b6a7c9a193d4

commit_message:
Ensure foreign key is dropped before removing instance_id column

This fixes Bug #904888

On MySQL databases that use InnoDB by default (ie, at the point when database
is being first migrated), extra care needs to be taken to ensure FKs are
dropped before columns because they are not automatically.

Change-Id: Ic180031dc6406cba127c8dd5204150e4e015cb22

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 18:51:25.000000000', 'message': "Fixes LP Bug#901534 - Lost properties in upload

Adds test cases that verify the bug behaviour.

Adds some logic to the main API images controller
update() method that does the following:

* If an image file is being uploaded, do not purge
  existing properties when updating metadata. The idea
  behind this change is that a very common scenario is
  to register an image entry with Glance with some
  properties (like instance_uuid, instance_type, etc) and
  then immediately upload an image (usually snapshots).
  We don't want to mark deleted the originally-registered
  properties during the image upload, which was what was
  happening.

* Add ability to force Glance NOT to purge properties
  when calling PUT /images/<IMAGE_ID> if the
  X-Glance-Registry-Purge-Props: false
  header is passed.

Change-Id: Ie66af8f052ab40d5dca7a3235fdbbb7de20372de
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes LP Bug#901534 - Lost properties in upload

Adds test cases that verify the bug behaviour.

Adds some logic to the main API images controller
update() method that does the following:

* If an image file is being uploaded, do not purge
  existing properties when updating metadata. The idea
  behind this change is that a very common scenario is
  to register an image entry with Glance with some
  properties (like instance_uuid, instance_type, etc) and
  then immediately upload an image (usually snapshots).
  We don't want to mark deleted the originally-registered
  properties during the image upload, which was what was
  happening.

* Add ability to force Glance NOT to purge properties
  when calling PUT /images/<IMAGE_ID> if the
  X-Glance-Registry-Purge-Props: false
  header is passed.

Change-Id: Ie66af8f052ab40d5dca7a3235fdbbb7de20372de

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 17:34:54.000000000', 'message': "Switch disk_config extension to use one DB query

A response through this extension can have many servers and making one
query per server can slow down response time dramatically. This change
switches the extension to use one DB query instead of many queries.
It also avoids queries when the key is already populated, such as when
the results include responses from a remote zone.

This change reduces a 'nova list' of 21 servers from 14 seconds to 1
second on my (relatively slow) development system.

Change-Id: I8476dbca0f87ff2a3d69bd7b8f51c296e41e3388
"}]
commit_message:
Switch disk_config extension to use one DB query

A response through this extension can have many servers and making one
query per server can slow down response time dramatically. This change
switches the extension to use one DB query instead of many queries.
It also avoids queries when the key is already populated, such as when
the results include responses from a remote zone.

This change reduces a 'nova list' of 21 servers from 14 seconds to 1
second on my (relatively slow) development system.

Change-Id: I8476dbca0f87ff2a3d69bd7b8f51c296e41e3388

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 16:01:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes bug 887402

Change utils.execute to accept a list or a single integer in
check_exit_code.

In libvirt.disconnect_volume() return codes 0 and 255 are both valid
for logout/delete, where 255 is returned if the volume is already
disconnected.

Also includes a fix by Dan Prince for a regression introduced by
the above fix (bug 904560)

Change-Id: Icffeb0fe8269a02d95ac6ed180ba0bb9f458a6ed
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes bug 887402

Change utils.execute to accept a list or a single integer in
check_exit_code.

In libvirt.disconnect_volume() return codes 0 and 255 are both valid
for logout/delete, where 255 is returned if the volume is already
disconnected.

Also includes a fix by Dan Prince for a regression introduced by
the above fix (bug 904560)

Change-Id: Icffeb0fe8269a02d95ac6ed180ba0bb9f458a6ed

commit_message:
Switch disk_config extension to use one DB query

A response through this extension can have many servers and making one
query per server can slow down response time dramatically. This change
switches the extension to use one DB query instead of many queries.
It also avoids queries when the key is already populated, such as when
the results include responses from a remote zone.

This change reduces a 'nova list' of 21 servers from 14 seconds to 1
second on my (relatively slow) development system.

Change-Id: I8476dbca0f87ff2a3d69bd7b8f51c296e41e3388

Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 927, 'name': 'Gabe Westmaas', 'email': 'gabe.westmaas@rackspace.com', 'username': 'westmaas'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-12 18:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hm... so I do mirror the concerns you expressed offline about lost messages if you restart compute.   I also worry about greenthreads stacking up in compute manager if something gets stuck.

I do like the changes to _spawn.  I don't see much reason to wait for boot in the background... when the compute manager is already working on spawn in its own greenthread.  So, I see those changes wanted no matter what.  One difference in behavior is that now exceptions can be thrown and they'll carry back up to the callers of _spawn...  where I think the prior behavior caused them to be ignore.  I think this is better behavior and I thought Ewan had a patch for this, too, but this is a larger and better fix.

My initial instinct on how to fix this would have been to have 'delete' check to see if the instance is in a certain task_state and mark something in the DB that it should be deleted.  The certain task states could then check for this and delete the instance themselves if they see it.  Or... change delete to not actually do anything but mark the DB record as deleted.  Then a periodic task goes around deleting the instance when the task_state is in an appropriate state.   I think we have checks to disallow things like resize when instances are not in a state ready for them already.  Anyway... just things to think about.

I'm going to stew on this, possibly see what feedback is like here, and vote later..."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 20:01:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-12 20:13:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm a lot more comfortable with this change to solve the delete race condition.  I think we can look at the other issues separately.  I'd maybe get concerned that we'd end up with things in BUILD forever that we couldn't delete...  but your changes to vmops.py will now guarantee an instance goes to ERROR state with any exception thrown from what I can tell (the except catching in _run_instance)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 20:45:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 494, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:16:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:25:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

inline.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Shoot... race condition.  The inline comment i had was that the str() == "None" thing was just code that was moved.  However, i'm guessing it really should have been if vcpu_weight is None in the first place.

Since the code was just moved and the patch isn't meant to address that.. I'll +1'}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:36:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

We already have cases where instances get stuck in build states, does this do anything to address the proliferation of those cases?  I'm worried that this may cause more cases where a temporary operational issue multiplies the need for operational intervention to clean things up."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Have you seen this branch?

https://review.openstack.org/#change,1695

ARe there potential conflicts in methodology between the two? They both seem to be solving similar problems.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 21:40:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

It helps make some build failures move to error state correctly by making some of the agent related work in the XenAPI driver synchronous and fall under the existing exception handling.

This patch also has the added benefit of fixing a reported bug. If we still have cases where builds fail to move to ACTIVE or ERROR, then we should open up bugs and fix them.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-12 22:05:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I wasn't aware of change 1695 before. I think it could solve the same problem (but it ignores delete right now). With some cleanups and fixes, it might make this change moot.

I'll put a -1 on this change for now pending the outcome of 1695."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 15:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 16:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 16:42:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 17:22:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-14 17:29:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-14 17:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

Nice cleanup of the code. However, unless I'm mistaken, there is an infinite loop possibility in the code (and the original code AFAICT)...

What happens if the instance never gets to RUNNING status? The loop just continues with no timeout.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-14 17:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Jay:  Yeah, I stewed on that as well.  However, I think it's always the case that Xen puts the instance into 'running' state if you've called 'VM.start".... which just means the VM has power.  Although, I wonder about the case where we're booting PV.. and xen can't read the filesystem to find the kernel.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 18:20:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I went back and forth with adding a timeout to that loop. It's theoretically possible for an endless loop, but I couldn't figure out what an appropriate amount of time to wait is. It seems risky to guess what an appropriate timeout would be.

Any ideas?"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-14 18:26:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: No score

I'd create a flag for it.  From what I know, it really should go to RUNNING within a few seconds....and if it doesn't, I don't see how it would ever do so.  Since RUNNING just means the VM has power, it should only take a few seconds for xen to find the kernel, put the state to RUNNING, and start booting it.  So I think a default flag value of something like 30 seconds would be a good start.  Probably a good idea to add a debug log message before the loop and after the loop so we can get a real gauge on it?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2011-12-14 21:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-12-15 04:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Still thinking about timeout?'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2011-12-15 14:57:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:
